The only thing that was irritating was the fact that the exhaust fan came on evvvvery time you turned the light on in the bathroom.  Geeez.  My boys had a blast in the pool and the whirlpool.  The hotel was pretty centrally located to every place we went.  The price was very reasonable.

hotel_name: Holiday Inn Express & Suites Indianapolis Dtn-Conv Ctr Area
review_content: Holiday Inn Express is usually not on my radar as a hotel of choice. But after a family gathering here last weekend, I must say I'm pleasantly surprised! The hotel itself appears very new and shiny. The rooms are all very spacious and clean. The mattress was great! I even found a *good* pillow to lay my head! That is a huge plus in my book. Breakfast was of the usual "hot" breakfast items included with the stay...nothing to write or complain about. What I will say is how the breakfast/lobby area is decorated. They must have used a professional decorator for this. The look is polished, cozy, yet not over stuffed. I even liked the tastefully decorated Colts blue Christmas tree! If you are here for a Colts game, you are in luck. It is directly across the street from the stadium. But if you are here for some of the downtown bars and restaurants...it is not so ideal. The hotel is about 3 big blocks from Circle Center--a pretty painful walk in the cold or rain. Parking is not convenient if you take your car. Once the spots in the small hotel surface lot are taken, you get to park in a city garage behind the hotel. We were faced with the same dilemma. But we happily settled on going next door to Tavern on South so all is not lost.Oh My, I stayed here last week when I was in town for Thanksgiving........Two incidents happened that I believe are unacceptable.1. In the first few minutes of being in my room. The front desk called and said my phone was dialing 911. A gentlemen came up and "fixed it". This is not a good feeling. I ordered food and went to bed.2. When I woke up in the AM. I went to take a shower (this was my first time in the restroom). What I saw on the toilet seat is unacceptable. I have attached a picture.I have contacted both the hotel, and hotel chain about the incident. Here is what I received back.....Thank you for contacting Guest Relations regarding the Holiday Inn Express and Suites Indianapolis Dwtn City Centre. I am very sorry to hear about the condition of the guestroom/bathroom which caused your stay to be less than satisfactory.It is IHG's goal to consistently provide superior service and accommodations and your comments are very important to us. The feedback we receive from our valued guests, like you, enables us to target problem areas, and take the necessary actions to ensure similar situations can be avoided in the future. We appreciate the candid feedback we receive and welcome any opportunity to improve.In addition, in an effort to retain your patronage and demonstrate our concern in this matter, I would like to enroll you in our IHG Rewards Club program. I would also like to issue 2,500 points to your account, on the hotel's behalf. IHG Rewards Club Points can be redeemed for free nights, merchandise, and more. For complete details and member benefits, you may visit ihgrewards.com. If you would like to accept this offer, please reply to this email so I may complete the enrollment process. Once complete, I will advise of your new IHG Rewards Club number that can be used when making future reservations.HAHAH, Not the answer I was looking for....We travel to nearly all of the Saints away games and try to stay near the stadium. We were there for the preseason game in August and had a great experience.The rooms were comparable to the JW Marriot down the street and the service was excellent. I also like that you don't get nickel-and-dimed to death with fees for wifi and so on. The staff was excellent and we were routinely greeted enthusiastically by lots of them - even in Saints jerseys :-).And it is right across the street from the stadium. Good thing because it rained that day as we were leaving.This is a great little full service hotel.It has a great central location to downtown and it's very easy to walk to many places. The staff is very helpful and very courteous. I've enjoyed my stay here for the last eight days.Hotel definitely appeared nice. Day time front desk were very helpful and nice. Around 1 am my fiance was woke up by bites and lumps all over we actually saw bed bugs and told the overnight staff. The problem. He stated "I'm sure they're not bedbugs we haven't had a problem with that in a long time and if it's any bugs I'm certain it's something other than bedbugs" he refused to come look at all the bugs in the sheets. I'm assuming in order to avoid admitting they were in fact bedbugs. Anyway he offered another room but by 2 am and dealing with a attitude from him as if we were annoying him we decided to leave. Not saying we won't stay at another hie just definitely won't in downtown indyExperience was excellent! Very accommodating and friendly staff at the front desk. Free breakfast was tasty and we were said hello to by almost every staff member we encountered! We visited another HIX in Greenfield, IN and encountered the same thing! Nice work, guys. We are very much appreciative!As Holiday Inn Express Hotel's go, this one is top-notch. Good service, GREAT room, good location (right across from Lucas Oil Stadium - I mean right across the street) and decent parking. The rates are very reasonable and the breakfast was piping hot.When travel takes me back to downtown Indianapolis, I'll be staying here.Stayed here for almost one week with a conference. The entire staff was extremely courteous, accommodating,and welcomed me regularly. Room was very clean, spacious, and the hotel's location was fantastic. Walking distance from everything in the downtown area. I highly recommend this place!Average at bestThe Hotel Clerk was not the friendliest person, nor did she bother to look for the key that was left for me by my room mate earlier that evening as I arrived later - at least not until I called my room mate who told me it has my NAME ON IT - then she found it.We had a suite and it was ok and it was clean, however, the bathroom smelled like piss. That was room 506 or 504 whatever the number around the corner from the elevator.The breakfast was not really something to get excited about - fake eggs, a pancake machine, juices, fake sausage, bascially stuff I do not eat.The worst part, aside from the heavy smell of piss in the bathroom, was the parking. Had the parking been better I would have given 3 stars. If you are lucky to get a spot in the lot outside, you are one of the few. They share the City parking garage that is behind the hotel, but the entrance is almost a block away - extremely inconveneient - especially if you forget something in your car. You literally walk through an alley (that is a pass through for vehicles) and around a corner as there is only ONE entrance - and of course it faces the Comfort Suites Hotel and not the Holiday Inn...If you to stay in Indy, I would suggest the Conrad! FAR better hotel than the Holiday Inn! My first time in Indy and I REALLY liked the nightlife and Restaurants! VERY good!5 stars for a Holiday Inn? Everyone was extremely friendly and courteous, from the staff checking us in, to the housekeeping crew, to the shuttle driver, to the people working the breakfast area in the morning. Location is south of the convention center, short walk to one of the entrances, right next door to Lucas Oil Stadium, the rest of the immediate surrounding area is questionable, but there is a great little bar next door also. The room was clean each time we came back, towels were fresh, A/C & heater worked properly, room was spacious (we did get a suite). All in all, this place was pretty darn good. Oh and the internet worked perfectly for us, and we were on the 6th floor. I would definitely stay here again if I was going to the convention center or the Lucas Oil Stadium, if I were here just visiting, I might choose something a little closer to the center of downtown Indy, but even the walk back I made at 3:30 am felt safe.Thanks to hotwire for the amazing stay I had did this hotel. The room was very spacious and clean and everyone was very courteous. Definitely stay here again.We decided to stay at this hotel at the very last minute. Upon arrival at around 1130pm we went to the front desk and no one was there. After saying "excuse me is anyone here" a bunch of times we were finally greeted by a very rude host. Ok, you work in a service industry you should at least be nice. This guy actor like he was doing us a favor by letting us stay at this place. Obviously we thought we must of woken him up and didn't want to have to do his job but whatever, we are tired and just want to get to our room.So that night we wanted to get a bottle of water and we went the vending machine and put the money in, pressed for the water and a diet coke came out! Wtf!!! Again, whatever!Next night, lets try to go to a different vending machine on a different floor to get water, 5th floor.... no water. 4th floor.... no water. 3rd floor.... no water.... 2nd floor guess what? no water and not only that it ate the money!!So we go down to the front desk and of course, no one there. We say " excuse me ", "hello", over and over and finally Mr. Happy face shows up again and says he was on the phone with a total rude look on his face. We tell him that all the vending machines are out of water and it ate our money. He looks at us like we are Martians and says "yeah we are out of water" and tells us to grab something else from the cooler by his desk. How is a hotel out of water? The room was clean and the maid was nice and everything else was terrible.Oh I almost forgot, the complimentary breakfast was brutal!! Fake eggs, a machine that makes pancakes that taste like rubber, bacon with fat all over it!!! That's from 7am-10am, and right at 10am the girls come out of the kitchen and take anything left from breakfast. I saw a girl getting coffee and she turned to get the sugar and BAM!!!! the kitchen girl grabbed the coffee pot! NEVER, NEVER, NEVER will go back there!Clean and efficient. However, the coffee was cold.The room was clean and comparable to others. Parking cost $14! The clerk said all Indy hotels charge...but why not be different? The shower sometimes lost a little pressure and made noise but it was still a nice shower. The pool area was clean. The pool was excessively filled with chemicals. They have a whirlpool too which is rare these days. The breakfast was decent.The room itself isn't bad - the king nonsmoking room comes with a Jacuzzi, the bed was comfortable, and the room was clean and satisfactory. The internet, however, was not. On the third floor (out of six total) the connection was so poor that my laptop could barely detect it, and could not connect to it whatsoever. From the lobby, however, the internet is fine. Also in the lobby is a microwave for anyone to use, and there is a small store that sells frozen dinners and other travelling needs. From the room you can hear doors slamming in the hallway. The parking lot is extremely small - what seems to be part of the parking lot on one side of the building is actually reserved parking for a restaurant. Those who can't fit in the lot must park in a small garage next to a neighboring hotel. However, what I feel that I must mention is the swimming pool/whirlpool area. The first floor smells strongly of chlorine, and the pool itself is disgusting. The water was green, and, as I discovered, salty. What I thought was rust or chipped paint at the bottom of the pool actually turned out to be loose dirt. The whirlpool was also green and salty, and when the actual bubbles were turned on, the pool made a loud grating noise over which no conversation could be held (I think it had to do with a low water level - the noise came from holes near the top of the pool that seemed to match the ones underwater that made the bubbles).We chose to stay hear because we were going to the Monster Jam show at Lucas Oil Stadium. We were suprised at the low rates for a hotel right across the street from a venue. The hotel and room were clean and well maintained. The breakfast was more than I expected. Overall we enjoyed our stay and would definitely stay her again. One tip: if you are driving to the hotel, there is more parking in the garage to the Southwest of the hotel. At first I thought it was just the lot next to the hotel and that filled up fast.Pros:-The room was clean-Our jacuzzi suite; the tub was awesome and worked properly unlike other suites I've had at other hotels.-Location was right near everything we wanted to see in Indianapolis-The shop with essentials, and some basic food was nice. Decently priced and not completely marked up.Cons:-Waiting 10 minutes to check in at 6:30 PM. Nobody was at the desk, and as other employees walked by, they said nothing to us, and didn't bother to try to find someone or offer to.-The walls were very thin. Everytime someone would turn the water on for the tub or shower on either side of us, it would keep me awake, and I'm not exactly a light sleeper.-14 bucks to park in a lot that had maybe 20 spots was a joke. What's with this new trend of charging for parking at hotels? I'm already overpaying you. It didn't even say anything about it on their website either.-They had a shuttle, which was 5 bucks each way. And on a Saturday night and you end at 9:45? Why bother?-Their breakfast was okay. The pancakes out of the pancake machine were weird in texture and rubbery. I just stuck to bagels, the cinnamon rolls were awesome, and some biscuits and gravyBeware the parking scam!! They won't tell you when you make the reservation, but when you arrive to check-in they charge you $12 / night for parking. I can understand why they charge during football games (because the hotel is literally next door to Lucas Oil Stadium) but when i checked in, it wasn't even football season!!! :) To their credit, after some complaining they removed the parking charge.Not quite "holiday inn express" quality. The pool had no chlorine, and both of the two treadmills were broken in the workout facility. Rooms were nice and clean...no problems there, which is most important. Free WiFi.The check in clerk was nice, but I was amazed how long her boss Patsy let the line get before she decided to help. Then the maintenance man closed the pool for 5 minutes yet put a sign up at 8 am that it would be closed until 10 am. After voicing my annoyance to check out clerk I left annoyed when her response pretty much "sorry" not understanding I dressed my two children for a morning of swimming only to find out upon check out the pool was only closed five minutes. After filling out survey hotel sent and sending a complaint Patsy emailed me apologizing saying she gave me 3000 extra priority club points. I wanted to respond telling her she was part of the problem but I'm not sure it's worth it. It's ok but over all I was very unimpressed with management.

We had an absolutely phenomenal stay here. The hotel itself is beautiful, with each room uniquely designed to fit into the footprint of the building. Our room was spacious and comfortable, with a large bed and euro sofa, allowing for us to relax comfortably as if it was our own living room. The temperature was in the 60s even though we stayed in December, allowing us to truly appreciate the great Broad Ripple neighborhood; there were so many restaurants and bars in close walking proximity, and the trail directly behind the hotel was perfect for exploring. The continental breakfast was also awesome, with local yogurt, and delicious breakfast breads!Hotel Broad Ripple is a delightful mix between a B&B, hotel and lodge. It takes the best of each of these and combines them into a welcoming overnight experience. You walk in and immediately smell a woodsy scent, like fresh-cut pine or oak -- I don't really know my woods. But it's that all-natural scent that immediately conjures up memories of nights spent in Gatlinburg or a forest or on a mountain.And then there's this great lobby area with wine at night. When I walked through it at different times I found guests chatting each other up, getting to know each other. So ... a lodge.But then again, this lodging option is in what looks like a former single-family home. The signage is minimal. You have to know where you're going to find it ... or have a good GPS.My room door was within 10 feet or so of the check-in desk, and there are no phones in the rooms because you could just peek your head out of your door and ask the front desk clerk.  From what I could tell each room is just a bit different, some with balconies and some bigger than others. My room had a large brick focal wall, a vintage green sofa and a beautifully tiled shower.And when I checked in, I got a hand written note, welcoming me to Hotel Broad Ripple. So ... a B&B.But the amenities seemed to go above and beyond a B&B. There's free continental breakfast available at the small restaurant across the train tracks from Hotel Broad Ripple. I didn't get to try it out, but the clerk pointed out that it was next to the train caboose behind the hotel. Each room has its own bathroom from what I could tell. And you have privacy from other guests. So ... a hotel. Some other things I liked about Hotel Broad Ripple:* My room had its own Keurig with a few complimentary K-cups, including two teas and a coffee.* Coffee was also available for free in the lobby.* There's a small private parking lot in back of the hotel.* It's within a short walk of some of the best places in Broad Ripple. * The wifi was fast, free and easy to connect to. My room did not have a small fridge, which I wish it had, but besides that, my experience with Hotel Broad Ripple is one that I would happily repeat. I must remember this for the next time I'm in Indy.Broad Ripple has some cute little hideaways, I'm learning. I have passed by Hotel Broad Ripple on a few of my long walks on the monon, but had no idea it was so cute inside!I really like the decor; the owner did a great job of finding things of great style while maintaining a good balance. There are great views of the heart of Broad Ripple.  My favorite room was the suite, which could fit about 4-5 people easily. It was very open, great decor and much space. The bathrooms in the suite were great and left me most impressed They had modern features with all the extras in the bathrooms. Another idea for Hotel Broad Ripple is that the owner is willing to have group rent out the lobby for gathering. She didnt make it sound like it would be too much on the wallet. This space is very spacious, has great sitting and offers a bar.If you are coming to Indy and want to focus on the Broad Ripple idea OR what a place for a cool staycation, I think Hotel Broad Ripple would get great!Such a lovely little oasis!Yes, it's a bit from the airport, about a $30 Uber ride, but totally worth it if you want a personal, relaxing, and gorgeous spot to spend your time in Indy. Expect a cozy, welcoming, charming, nine room boutique hotel when you arrive. Yes, if you drive by quickly, you will miss it. The entrance is in the back so it's not obvious from the road. This is a spot you would see on Airbnb and add to your wish list. It has a contemporary lodge-like feel and was decorated for Christmas and it was lovely. I could sit here for days and think of adjectives to describe this spot but you really have to see it to believe it. When I arrived they were not full for the evening so they showed me Room 1 and 8 so I could choose, how nice? I went with 8 as it was away from the road and had a gorgeous deck. It was very spacious. The bathroom was lovely, only thing I would have liked more was a bathtub; I personally love taking baths in hotels. The bed was so very comfortable. So comfy that I had to force myself out of it. This was a super quick trip for me so I was very bummed I didn't get to hang out around this lovely inn. Next time I am in the area, expect me back here! The hand written note upon check-in was a lovely touch. There is also a free continental breakfast available at a restaurant right out back, a super quick walk outside the back door. I was unable to check it out as my stay was so short. If you are looking for a very personable, welcoming spot, this is it. Take a break from the hustle and bustle and get your relax on. Thanks for the hospitality, Hotel Broad Ripple!I live in Broad Ripple but don't have enough space in my home to host guests from out of town. Hotel Broad Ripple is a life saver! It allows family and friends to stay close but still have their own bed and comfy surroundings. The furnishings and decor here are adorable. Feels like a bed and breakfast with all its charm, but has modern touches like a Keurig, flat screen, and keycard entry for all rooms. My mother is visiting this weekend, and this is her first stay. She loves the big bathroom and sitting area of room #2. We had breakfast this morning with some yummy local treats like Traders Point Creamery yogurt and butter, and all the stylish plates and glasses. The staff is friendly but not overly chatty if you prefer privacy. Plenty of parking, and a great location for walking access to lots of restaurants, bars, local shops, and the Monon Trail.wowee wow wow!   I attended the Yelp's Winter Whiskey Party at the Hotel Broadripple.  We were able to get a tour of the place including 3 of the rooms.  This place is so exquisite.  Each room is decorated to the nines, rustic, shabby chic, hoosier.  The hotel owner was present and she is just wonderful. You can see the passion that went into her design.  This would be a great place to stay for business travelers, for out of town family members, or even for a great staycation.  I can't wait to stay here sometime for a little R & R!Hotel Broad Ripple is a beautiful ecletic hotel nestled on the Monon trail in Broad Ripple. On the outside it looks like a home with bridges to other houses...but once you enter you will be greeted by a cozy warm and well decorated hotel. Its a cute boutique hotel that offers the hominess of a hostel with the cleanliness and sleekness of any modern hotel. This is definitely a hidden gem of Broad Ripple...Awesome little hidden gem. We were just passing through town on a road trip and stayed here for just one night. Wish we had stayed longer! Room was beautiful (as was the lobby/bar). Great shower! Comfiest bed! Nice little hip neighborhood to explore right across the street. Free breakfast at the coffee shop. Would highly recommend.Many of the other reviews have already detailed what is so wonderful about the Hotel Broad Ripple, but I just wanted to add my voice to the chorus.  My husband and I loved every minute of our almost four-day stay there.  The service, amenities, decor, location...all top-notch.  We stayed in room number 1, the "smallest" (one queen bed), which was still a decent size, not cramped at all and perfect for a couple or a single.  It has a lovely sitting area and a large bathroom with a huge shower.  I can't recommend this place highly enough.This place is best for grown ups (carefully chosen word). Great location with easy foot access to many restaurants, pubs, shops, and town is right down the bike/foot path. Lovely host, decor and modern rooms with open yet cozy and nostalgic feel. Best of all worlds. Modern fully-accessible temp control and TV, French country feel with exposed brick accent wall and talk/vaulted ceiling and large modern bathroom (rm 2). For groups there is a lovely open room near the entrance to hang out or grab continental breakfast or last drink of the evening. Also recommend Public Greens restaurant within walking distance or for desert Monon Food Company. Looking forward to our next stay.I visited the Hotel Broadripple last night for Yelp's Winter Whiskey event and this place is definitely on my list of things to do. While a boutique style hotel, you can definitely tell that the owner put a lot of thought into the furniture and decor of the hotel. She is very personable and shared little tidbits of special pieces around the hotel. Plus the art work is for sale! We listened to a lady from Buffalo Trace give a small presentation about the bourbon brand and it was fascinating to see the other people's reaction to bourbon. The Wick's Pies were also amazing (especially since I normally do not like pies).Great unique hotel. Great staff and amenities. Perfect location right on the monon trail. You can walk wherever you need to go in broad ripple. We love to bring our bikes and ride the trail to downtown or to Carmel.I am a business traveler that visits Indianapolis once a month. I usually stay at a marriott courtyard. A business associate and friend recommended the Hotel Broadripple. What a refreshing difference! If you travel often, you know how seeing the same hotel decore begins to wear on you (i am looking at you green leaf picture in every marriott bathroom).  The Hotel Broadripple offers a unique blend of classic style with all the modern hotel amenities.  No expense was spared when they built this place.  Booking online was easy and the staff was great. Doug checked me in and was very down to earth and personable. The free breakfast offered at perk up across the street was great. A huge departure from the joe vs. The volcano intro assembly line vibe at the big box hotel bistros in the morning. Thanks Doug and Hotel Broadripple!Right on the Monon trail.  Stayed here for the Indy 500.  Great hotel.  Great staff.  Trendy hotel.  Beautiful balconies.  Features great local art on the walls of the hotel rooms.Hotel Broad Ripple is a beautiful, boutique-style hotel fashioned from two homes. The decorations are contemporary and spot-on for details, the rooms are tasteful, welcoming and very comfortable and easy to kick back and relax in. When not in-room, the common area/lounge offers wine and cheese plates in the afternoon/evening and a very simple, yet delicious and fresh breakfast in the morning. Within walking distance is all of Broad Ripple; from the lovely Monon walking/biking trail to scores of quant shops and eateries. A little further walk or an easy/short drive is the main street of the more commercial (and college life) area of Broad Ripple with more shops, pubs and restaurants. And an easy 15+ minute drive you can be in any of the great Indianapolis cultural/zoo/canal/art/and everything districts. HBR is well worth the stay...the first, second and third and beyond trip. Make a reservation today--I know I'm ready to go back!What a great place!  This place had just opened up a few months ago and we stayed here after going to a race in Indianapolis.  The hotel has  B & B style suites with very friendly staff and just a short walk to the bustling downtown Broad Ripple main streets. There is a walk/bike path right to the back door and a nice assortment of restaurants, shops and bars.  Continental breakfast free, just across the bike path. Lots of style in this hotel with a small town feel.  We will stay here again!My husband and I stayed at Hotel Broad Ripple on NYE.  We used to live in Broad Ripple, so this area of Indianapolis holds a special place in our heart.  While we were living there we saw it being built, so that's how we found out about it.  We were beyond impressed!  For starters, the hotel is beautiful and has amazing curb appeal.  It is seated in the perfect, walkable location in Broad Ripple and boasts balconies for guests to enjoy the views.  We stayed in room 3 and LOVED it!  It is beautiful, sleek and elegant.  It was also on the top floor which we loved.  It really was as if we were staying at a home away  from home.  The staff member was very helpful, but we rarely saw him which also made it feel like we were right at home.  The hotel has a bar area in the lobby where you can hangout.  This is also open to the public, so my husband and I plan to enjoy this feature of the hotel in the future.  Overall, we cannot rave about this place enough!  We have suggested it to so many people and plan to return.  It is unlike any other spot in Indianapolis.  Thank you Hotel Broad Ripple for the most wonderful stay!I've stayed in 100s of hotels around the world, so I have high expectations and a broad perspective on what makes a good one. And HBR is it! Several of my family members and I stayed here in June for a family reunion and we were all pleased. Brett, who handled all of our reservations and checkins, went out of his way to make us comfortable. We had a chance to chat with the owner who was very sweet as well. The rooms are in spectacular shape and so well decorated you'd think you were in Paris. You cannot beat the location either. I grew up in Indianapolis and know all the neighborhoods well; for business travelers, tourists, or natives coming back to visit, Broad Ripple is a great place to be. While plenty of cafes/bars are a short walk away, the hotel itself is very quiet and feels tucked away. Bonus points for the large grass area where guests can hang out, socialize, read, or just enjoy the view.choose the hotel broad ripple for its off the beaten path charm, and this cozy and welcoming spot did not disappoint. Away from the keystone avenue chains of hotels and same-o, same-o eating establishments, this hotel feels like a good friend's cottage. The lobby is open and welcoming, the check-in friendly and efficient. The owner, manager comped me an upgrade as census was light on a Tuesday. My room featured a very homelike rich blue decor with a soft headboard and some funky art above. The bathroom is huge, marble and features kohler-like fixtures. Big fluffy towels abound. My room didnt quite get dark with all of the wonderful blinds closed and there was some road noise to contend with. The neighborhood feels comfortable, you dont feel like a tourist walking across the old railroad spaces now repurposed as a walking and running trail, to the 4 or 5 restaurants filled mostly with locals. I will make this my fixed base of operation on future Indy excursions!

My first experience at a B&B and I loved it!  I would suggest the experience to everyone.  This one in particular has lots of room options, some with shared bathrooms and some with private (all the ones I saw had fantastic, giant tubs just calling out to me for a bubble bath).  The rooms were cozy and clean.  The house also had several other rooms to explore, full of board games, books, a piano, and photos with lots of history.  It was so neat to have those open areas to meet and chat with the other visitors.  The social aspect of a B&B is the extra oomph I have been looking for while traveling.  Sharing breakfast with perfect strangers at the family dining room table was so fun! It was cool to read through visitors messeges in the guest book in each room too.The guy running the place was sweet as ever.  He served a simple but tasty breakfast on the weekday.  Bummed I missed out on the big meal on the weekend.   Everything went just as smooth as ever which made all the difference since we had a wedding to focus on.  My only complaint it the lack of parking.I admit that the price seemed too good to be true; however, when looking for a place to stay for 5 nights, it seemed quite reasonable. The "lower level entrance" should have been my first clue that it's actually in the basement of the inn, but I didn't pick up on that. The inn's website explains that the Garden Suite "...offers a tranquil seclusion as well as a private bath. A heavenly queen bed, kitchen, desk and bistro table make this a serene escape for business or pleasure."There is nothing tranquil about this room. It is directly beneath the kitchen/dining room, and it's like staying in your parents' basement during a family reunion during which no one sleeps in and they all stomp around in the kitchen above you while you are trying to sleep in. Additionally, the stairs to the room are treacherous, at best, and if it's snowy, you track in all of the rock salt and there's no door mat to wipe your feet on. In fairness, the rest of the inn looks lovely, I would definitely not recommend the Garden Suite, however. The location, however, is great!This was such a beautiful b&b! Had such a great experience for my first time staying at a bed and breakfast. Definitely recommend this place to anyone! Only reason I won't give a five stars in water pressure went in and out and breakfast was just ok.This must be one of the best little gems in Indianapolis!The building is lovingly restored to the craftsman/revival style.  The downstairs common area is classy, elegant, yet homey at the same time.  I was attracted to this B&B due to their lovely lofts.  I dont know why they do not post more pictures of these lofts on their website.  They are so cute and cozy!  Each is furnished with a full kitchen set up.  We stayed in the NE loft.  I loved sleeping in the loft "in the sky" (see my pics).  The two person Jacuzzi tub was a wonderful bonus.  We also loved the complimentary snacks and refreshments and breakfast.  Although the full breakfast is only served on weekends; we met a spread that is way more than the typical "continental" breakfast on Monday morning.  The inn is also on the bus line and only about a half mile from downtown.  For about the same price as a typical downtown hotel room, minus the daily parking rate of $15-25; plus the snacks and breakfast; there is definitely value in staying in a B&B.  We would definitely come here again the next time we are in Indi!Oh my!  Here for a conference. I booked everything late and was struggling to get a place to put my head for around $100 a night. Then I came across Stone Soup InnI could not have been more happy. I was able to secure a loft and it wad truly delightful. Decent bed for two (I was on my own!) a fridge, oven, microwave, sink, cupboards, great subdued paint and lighting, writing desk, walk thru closet/passage to own bathroom with very clean toilet, shower, basin and room to spare. The atmosphere is very old world - charming and homely. Very tastefully decorated in proof correct fashion. Free snacks and tea/coffee was another bonus. The booking people were very thorough and because I was arriving around midnight, were careful to explain how to get my key and how to find my room. I would love to come back here and sit on the porch in summer!Been here twice and love love this place a lot. Its the only bb I've been to and both times me and my wife really enjoyed instead of that other place were they don't even cook breakfast for u there. I love the loft rooms there nice and comfortiblr . I have only like two complient s I have was that their is only small movie.choices. and the tubs are kind of small but who gives a crap about that. This is a wonderful getawayThis place was a total win for me.  I was in town for a small conference and the hotel was sold out.  This place came up on Trivago, and after a little review, I thought I'd give it a try.  The cost was less than the conference hotel, and the experience was so much more!One of the things I love about staying at local inns/B&B's is that they can offer more flexibility than your typical hotel.  I was able to request my own check-in time and did so, requesting a time shortly after lunch, a time when most hotels "can''t guarantee."  I was also able to hang around and get some work done in the morning before my meeting with no firm checkout/the cleaning staff hovering.  The accommodations were great.  Warm and homey but not homely.  Classy, clean, and tasteful.  My room (NW Loft) had a living space, kitchenette stocked with non-food supplies (which I wasn't expecting), separate bathroom, and lofted bed.  I could have slept all morning as the loft was cozy, dark, and warm.  I peaked in some other rooms when I checked in, and they all shared these positive qualities.  There are also common areas inside and out, if you were with a group and looking for space to congregate, or read by yourself.  The building had rfid entry and rooms were deadbolted.  While there are hardwood floors, rugs keep things quiet and my general experience is people at these types of places are respectful.  Tom, the innkeeper, was friendly and conversational during breakfast and check in.  Breakfast was continental (during the week) which was great for me and included fresh fruit, cereal, bagels, muffins, granola/cereal bars, yogurt, and I think I saw boiled eggs.  It's a full breakfast on weekends.  There's an communal area to sit, or you can take it back to your room.  There's also a butler's pantry with snacks and beverages available.The location was easy to find, offered convenient parking, and was in a cute neighborhood.  I also was able to walk to Mass Ave in about 20 minutes.  Also walkable to the downtown area or a easy/affordable cab ride.  The only downside some might see is that there were quite a few stairs.If I'm back in Indy, I would first check to see if this place is available!It is in a bad part of town, it's old and weird.  I don't know how else to put it.  I am literally bewildered why other reviewers referred to the lofts as either cute or cozy.  The rooms are small, dark, and creepy.  The furniture is so uncomfortable, like patio furniture.Super relaxing spot & about .5 miles away from Mass Ave. which has a ton restaurants, bars, shops, etc. I stayed in the Blue Room which was perfect for someone flying solo. This room has a steam shower. Nice addition but a lot of steam and so much so I had to crack the shower door open. This is really a minor quibble as the staff was super helpful about recommendations around town.This is a hidden gem located north of downtown. Walking distance to a wonderful treasure trove of restaurants and quaint shops on Mass Ave.The rooms are elegantly cozy and full of antiques. I loved hanging out on the huge wrap around porch sipping wine from a bottle that I ordered from their sister Inn.The Villa. I was thrilled to find a Lilly pond stocked with koi fish and surrounded by blooming tulips and a bench for sitting.My room was very cool as it featured a steam bath. I purchased some aromatherapy oils from their spa located at The Villa and loved using them in the steam shower as it was pretty rainy and chilly weather. This was a special treat for sure!The next morning my breakfast was pretty impressive considering that I was told that during the week it was continental. I was only expecting coffee, juice and cold cereal but there was yogurt, fresh fruit, bagels and some yummy muffins. Wow!I will definitely tell my friends about this place. I loved it!  WendyA strange location, but a great little addition to the Old Northside.I was here a few weeks ago with my boyfriend, and we had *the most amazing* time! Nate, the innkeeper, was so courteous, friendly, and warm. The house itself is charming and adorable. The NW Loft was more than we could have asked for -- honestly, I can't say enough good things! Honestly, we always hated leaving our room when we HAD to go out and meet friends and family!  Quiet, close to some great things in Indy, pristine, cosy -- we can't wait to go back! Nate, thanks so much!!After a very long, but joyous day, my wife and I came here for our wedding night. Located in the old historic district, this old mansion was perfect for us. We had eaten at St. Elmo right before we got there, and so it was about 8:00 by the time we arrived. The inn was hidden behind large trees, and had a small parking lot. We walked up to the door, but it was locked. We rang the doorbell. We heard a scurry throughout the house. Eventually the door opened and there stood a quirky woman, somewhat out of breath. "Hello," she muttered. "Welcome to the Stone Soup Inn." She looked every which way and seemed somewhat nervous. "Let me show you around."So she showed us the inn and told us what we could expect. It was a great, rustic place. It had antiques all around, and the rooms were well decorated. The woman was super nice. We finally came to our room, the Lilly Room. It has a bay window with a bathroom that has a two person jacuzzi. We had a small refrigerator with complimentary drinks. The best thing is that we practically had the place to ourselves. That next morning we went down to the dining room. (A room with a small dining room table) and ate breakfast with a man from Canada and a man from France. One man was here for a conference, the other for a wedding. A delightful conversation occurred. In the bedroom, there is a book at the foot of the bed which allows everyone to write their story. It was great to read everyone's stories. The place had a baby grand piano if you would like to play it, and they also have a library with books and DVD's in it.It was a wonderful place and a wonderful experience. The perfect wedding night getaway.What a great experience we had at the Stone Soup Inn. Honestly I just picked this place to stay for a night in Indianapolis because it was the cheapest place that I could find that was close to downtown, what we got was a great experience. The house is beautiful and located in a quiet neighborhood. We got one of the lofts and had tons of space. The room included a full kitchen, a dining table and an area with a couch/tv. There was tons of common space with free drinks, snacks and things to do laying around everywhere (I probably had more than my fair share of M&Ms). In the morning the breakfast wasn't anything extraordinary but there was plenty of food and the staff was beyond hospitable. There is nothing to complain about here. Everyone who works there is nice and is available 24/7 for anything you could need. They have a private driveway that you can park on and the price is more than reasonable. I'd recommend this place for everyone who wants to stay somewhere near downtown even if you aren't looking for a B&B.I've stayed here twice, both during large conventions, and had phenomenal experiences both times.  The location is beautiful, the service impeccable, and the food delicious.  The cheaper rooms are a real deal ($85 when I booked), though I hope one day to be able to afford the more luxurious options.  The downstairs living room is fantastic for entertaining friends, more like a home than a hotel lobby.  The outdoor patio perfect for sitting and reading a book with your morning coffee.  I've recommended several family members to find an excuse to visit Indianapolis just to stay here.My boyfriend and I stayed in the SE loft. It was so cozy and quaint. There was free M&M's , popcorn and pop. The breakfast was really good. I recommend getting the room with the jacuzzi. Well worth the extra money.

Extremely friendly staff. Very clean. Pots and pans could use an update. It made cooking things difficult with warped pans. Housekeeping cleaned my dishes while I was gone. Unexpected, but I was grateful since I ran out of time in the morning prior to leaving. Gas grill on the patio for use. Not much in the local area though. Had to drive just about everywhere.Hotel stay 05/28/2015. Terrible experience. We picked a Residence Inn because we were traveling with pets, and my husband is a Marriott Gold Elite Rewards member. So, we booked the hotel using rewards points, but did pay the non-refundable $100 cleaning fee (no argument there, we've paid it before at other locations). Carpet in our room had multiple stains everywhere and once I went to get in the shower, it started to hold water and not drain properly. I literally took a shower in water that not only was from me, but judging by the lack of cleanliness, only God knows what other filth I was standing in. There was even a leftover hair on the bathroom wall. Lastly, left on the vanity was shampoo and a body wash. No lotion or conditioner either. Thankfully I had packed my own conditioner, but I must admit, I do enjoy the little things like their lotion they use in the rooms. On 06/03/2015 my husband reached out to Marriott Customer Service via phone. We were assured the concerns were forwarded to the hotel and that since this was a "service issue" this location would be the best to handle the complaints. I know, from my exchange with the Marriott group via Twitter that there was a delay and their CSR was still needing to work with the hotel as of 06/11/2015, which is also when I was assured "We are aware of the issues and assure you that somebody from the hotel will be reaching out to you."  Yep, still waiting. You'll never get our business again! Sad because Indy is such a great place to stop between Michigan and St. Louis and we do travel quite a bit. Additionally my husband does business in Indy at least once a month. Oh, and there are really only two reasons you got one star. # 1 ~ Yelp won't let me give less than one star. # 2 ~ Your waffle maker made the PERFECT hotel waffle, though since there was no attendant to be found to help with the broken batter dispenser, I'm complimenting the chef of said "perfect" waffle .... ME!First off this place is filthy see the pictures! The food is badly prepared, slow coming and will give you bubble guts. I've had hospital food at a state run nursing home better than this place. We paid in advance and had no choice in the stay as it was the closest to our destination. The first night we RAN to Kroger bought bleach, sponges, rags and air fresheners because this place reeked. I stayed up half the night making our room sanitary for our kids. I refused to sleep or allow them to enter the room until I bleached all surfaces and hand mopped the areas.The carpet hasn't been vacuumed since the place opened. They cleaning crew or whoever they were was using a swifter sweeper on the floors...REALLY?!!The staff there is plenty handy but they don't actually work there. Think "Orange is the New Black," meets the old bathroom in "Saw" dirty. There was long brown, black and brown hairs everywhere in the refrigerator, sinks, shower, toilet, sheets, desk, even the ice machine. The dishes were put away DIRTY with food crusted on them. There was food crumbs in the cabinets. Spiders everywhere, one so big it crunched when killed. We bought sheets, asked for new towels and wore shower shoes. I was not taking any chances with my families health.The tub was so dark it looked like a football team had just ran a play on it. We have a long history staying with this brand of hotels as it has the small kitchen, usually clean, family friendly, great value and well run but this one is bottom of the barrel horrible. Also stay out of the pool and spa the water was dingy and oily. The water looked brownish blue. REALLY?!! So disappointed, upset and disgusted in this Marriott hotel. I expect quality like what I've received in the past. Where is the corporate office and who is the District Manager for this region? This is a travesty!It's easy to find, situated amongst other airport hotels. Check in was a breeze although it was 1am local time.  Rooms was clean & adequate.  Furnishings were fine, modern & contemporary.  I can't give it a four star because of these issues:  toilet paper was super thin, no lotion provided, & remote control for tv needed new batteries...My wife and I spend spent two nights in this property, three days apart.  The first night was barely acceptable.  The second night was a disaster.General comments:  This property is dirty and dark.  The floor in the breakfast area (and in front of the registration desk) was sticky from spilled food from 7 a . m. until after 3 p. m.  There was spilled food throughout the breakfast area every time I checked.  There was very little variety and the food that was offered looked awful.  Waffle battered was splatter all over the place.  There were no serving pieces in any of the jars of raisins, sugar, or other items to be sprinkled on cereal. I could say more but I think you get the picture.There seemed to be a very large staff available in the morning but I saw no evidence of them working.  Instead, they were having a fine time talking with each other.The carpets in the   rooms look like they have never been cleaned.  The rooms smelled musty, there was a large red stain on the white comforter  in one of the rooms we were in. There was a scarcity of kitchen items  in all of the rooms we were in.The rooms offered the comfort and atmosphere of a 1960s college dorm or maybe a cheap music camp for teenagers...uncomfortable seating, a desk placed against a window that allowed the sun to glare into my face and tiny televisions.Those are the general comments that apply to both nights we stayed there. The specifics of our second night are considerably worse.We arrived for checkin around 3 p. m.  Monday July 6.  The floor in front of the check in desk was so sticky I kept doing a little dance so that I would not permanently stick to it.  We were sent to a room in a reasonable amount of time...and saw when I unlocked the door that the room had not been serviced.Not a good thing, but not a disaster.  And the desk clerk was up pretty quickly with a set of keys to another room.The disaster started around 10 p. m.  Our room was over the patio/entrance to the swimming pool. There was a large group on the patio, making a great deal of noise.  My wife called the desk and was told by Trey the pool and the patio closed at 11 a. m.  Not great since we had an early flight from IND to SFO the next day but reasonable.  I called again at 10:50 to confirm that the patio/pool would shut down at 11 p. m. and was assured by Trey that the people on the patio knew they had to close down at 11 p. m.  So when things did not shut down by 11:10 I went down to the desk to see Trey.  He explained the parents on the patio had asked him to keep the pool open and he had agreed.  He also informed me that the patio was a "public area" and that there was nothing he could do about the noisy party.I went back to the room, conferred with my wife and called down and got a new room.A whole lot of inconvenience and unhappiness could have been avoided if had Trey dealt with us honestly from the beginning.  We could have asked for a new room an hour earlier if we had been told the pool was going to be open late and the party on the patio did not have an end time.All of this is totally inconsistent with my experience with Residence Inns.  We have used these properties in multiple states for at least the last 10 years and this is the first negative experience ever.  In fact, we spent the night in between the stays at this property in the Residence Inn in Columbus, IN and had an outstanding experience.I was so close to making this a 4 star review but some things just don't make the cut - like taking a cold shower in the morning. The hotel itself is fine. There are 2 buildings and I stayed in the one opposite the main building where the pool and gym are located. Like another Yelper commented, the gym was a warm 76 degrees, despite the 68 degree setting. Good sweaty workout so I was forgiving. The room?  Nice digs. Good space. Then I went to shower at 6:45 am before I headed to the airport and shivered in cold water as I finished rinsing. I stay in hotels for 3 reasons: sleep, convenience and showers. 3 stars, no more.**This is an update to a previous review. Although I will stick to my comment about the quality of the coffee, I have to say this is hands down the best service I have ever received at a hotel. Our group was having a difficult week and ALL of the staff made us feel like we were at home. This is priceless when you are on the road for extended periods of time. The last few days a new employee named Rachel went out of her way time after time for us in the most extraordinary and thoughtful ways! John was also very helpful with checkout, giving me plenty of time when I had a million emails to send and still pack and was losing my mind.The one star off is for general out-datedness (remodel coming soon) and the coffee. Also I think some of the down pillows really need to be replaced. Didn't get a chance to try the gym unfortunately :/Overall a pleasant stay and would highly recommend this diamond in the rough!I am tempted to rate at 4 stars because of the sauna -- I mean gym. We asked to have the heat turned down from 79 to something more reasonable for our workout, but no one delivered. That aside, the rooms are clean and massive, beds are comfortable, staff is friendly, but the BEST is the breakfast. Waffles, coffee, cereal, hot plates with eggs, sausage, etc, fruit, pastries, hard boiled eggs, and more. You can take anything to go, and it's all fresh. Makes all the difference starting the day!I was skeptical upon arrival then pleasantly surprised. This is not a 4 Star hotel but I was tempted to give a 4 star Yelp review. I didn't because of the appearance and cleanliness of some of the common areas (lobby restroom, elevator, hallways and gross chair in my room-see pic). That stuff would cause me to give a 2 star rating. I gave 3 stars because the employees were all very helpful and nice plus very accommodating. Also, the breakfast was good for a free breakfast-and I'm picky about food. It was not bad! The location is nice for the airport but not for dinner options unless you like unhealthy food.Stayed here a few days ago on my way to Florida. Based my choice to stay here on reviews, and I was not disappointed. I stayed in a two bedroom suite.  It was clean and roomy. The pool was nice, clean and we had the place to ourselves! The hot tub was hot and clean. The staff was super friendly and accommodating. I didn't give 5 stars because they need to update a few things. We left before breakfast, but I heard it was good. They also have an airport shuttle.Although this a typical Residence Inn, the service here was great. This review could have easily been a one star review if it wasn't for the fantastic service!It started out we had just arrived at the Indy airport, we called the hotel and they said the next shuttle would be at 8:30pm. As 8:30 approached we were still waiting on bags, a couple came out, so we sent my dad to the pick up area in hopes of catching the shuttle and we'd be a few minutes behind him. Unfortunately, when we got there the shuttle was already pulling away. So we planned on the 9:00pm shuttle.9:00 pm rolls around no shuttle.... 9:05.... no shuttle so I call and turns out the shuttle didn't leave for the 9:00 round... not sure why but we were all getting frustrated by this time. So JD(or JR... I'm bad with names) tell us to go ahead and get a cab and they would pay for it... the bad thing was there were 4 of us and 7 bags, so we were going to fit in one cab.The cab experience was a NIGHTMARE... the cab drivers were crazy. Fast forward to arrival at the hotel. The cab drivers are CRAZY they refuse to let us go into the lobby for the money and say that we have to pay and no third party. JD comes out to settle the crazies... but they get crazier... he appologizes profusely and pays the unprofessional cabbies. Says he sorry and even gave us a bucket of beer so we didn't have to leave the hotel. It could have been a really bad night and the staff at the Residence did everything they could to make it better. They even apeased my father after the whole ordeal, which is hard to manage! The only thing that could have made this any better is if they could have gotten the cabbies deported... they don't belong here... they were horrible... but that is for a different review.I recently stayed at this hotel, and to be completely honest, my experience was pretty awful.  That said, I don't really fault the hotel completely, as my issues were largely related to the abnormally cold weather and snow storm.  Despite that, the hotel offered a various generous amount of points to help make up for my poor experience.  Also, the real reason I'm even doing this review is the fantastic response from an email I sent to the hotel GM.  I'm in the process of planning a wedding, and have found it unbelievably common for businesses to be too busy to bother returning emails and phone calls.  In light of that, I was amazed and impressed at how quickly I got a response.  Thank you for showing there are still businesses that care about customer service!Huge thanks to the management.I had to wait for a co-worker to come out of her room.Two and a half hours I sat in the lobby watching TV and surfing the net.The staff was very friendly.I even hit up the breakfast bar and no one complained that I was not staying there.(Do note that I am GOLD with Marriott. So I feel that I have paid my dues to earn a free snack.)I will stay there next time I am in town longer.Location, Location, Location!Just off the interstate and well located if you are traveling through, or need to be at a variety of different places in the Indy area.  There is NOTHING close by, which is fine.The place at first glance is well taken care of, but second glance could use a little more care, not the freshest of the Marriott properties I have stayed in.   Hotel taxes seem to be high, but the cost of hotels in the Indy area for some reason are generally higher than elsewhere in the country.The pool and hot tub are nice, and the free breakfast is very good.  This property and the other Marriott next door (either a Fairfield or a Courtyard) share a parking lot. and are off a road, that is off a road that is off a road that is off the highway.  Not super easy to figure out how to get into if you arrive late at night.Stayed here one weekend.  Was very pleased.  The room is quite comfortable and well laid out for an extended stay.  You don't feel claustrophobic like in some hotel rooms.  The TV swivels so that you can enjoy it either from bed or from the sitting area.  Very very nice kitchenette that comes stocked with plates and utensils and such.  Top of the refrigerator was a bit dusty so housekeeping might want to keep an eye on that.Just your typical residence inn, exactly what I had expected from them!It's pretty decent price, two bedroom $189 right by airport, have a shuttle that actually runs early (5am) unlike all the other hotels we called in the area! They didn't start until 7am! The hotel itself is great but the shuttle driver needs to be taught what her job is!!   We had a 6:15 am flight. We went downstairs around 5, the shuttle was parked outside so we got into it. The shuttle driver was at the front desk talking to the clerk. We sat and sat and sat. Finally we got out and said something to her like umm we have a flight we need to get to. She acted like WE were being the rude ones disturbing her!!! She moseys out to the shuttle and we leave. She seems to be taking a while to get to the airport, like she's doing it on purpose to make us late. We look at our map on our phone and wonder what the hell is she doing?! When we finally get there it's too late, we get booked on a later flight. We call the hotel and ask if the shuttle can come back, they say yes its on the way. We wait for about 30 or so then call again. The clerk says well you have to call for the shuttle. WHAT?!! We did call you?! So we wait a tad longer and still no shuttle. We finally get a cab and ask the clerk at the hotel if the hotel will cover it because we've been sitting here for an hour waiting for the shuttle! She says yes. So we go back to the hotel and try to relax. The shuttle gets us to the airport in time later that day. It's a great hotel to stay at just don't rely on the crappy shuttle lady to get off her butt and do her job!Rooms and decor is a  bit outdated but comfortable.  There was only one trash can in the entire "suite" and it was in the kitchen. I, personally thought it was strange that there was not one in the bathroom. It was annoying to walk into the kitchen to throw away a tissue every time I blew my nose (which was often b/c I was getting sick).  There is a decent breakfast buffet (free).  The downer for me was that the coffee was terrible, TERRIBLE. So bad that I took 2 sips and did not finish it. I am not too picky when it comes to coffee (especially in the morning) but I just could not drink this.  We were told that there was a shuttle to the airport every 30 minutes. We came down to eat breakfast and catch the 9am shuttle (for our 10:35 flight).  At 9:10 still no shuttle. I go to the front counter and asked the lady when we could expect it. She said "Oh, I shouted "anyone for the shuttle" a few minutes ago and nobody answered so I told them not to come"  Um...we'd been sitting right there for more than 30 minutes and never heard her "shout" anything. My bad.  She did call another shuttle that showed up within 10 minutes and we made our flight just fine. I suppose I might have been too focused on my terrible coffee to hear her "shout."Overall, an okay experience. The bed was comfy, so that is good.

We stayed here on a Friday night for a party that was in town. I have to say the location is excellent, very convenient to many restaurants and activities downtown (many within walking distance). The hotel is actually connected to Centre City Mall, The Artsgarden, a parking garage and multiple restaurants.The hotel staff were very friendly and our room was ready when we arrived to check in. The room was clean - the bathroom could have been a little cleaner for my taste, but it was okay.  The vents were very dirty in our room, and someone had put a towel over one of the vents in the bedroom for some reason and the housekeeping staff did not remove it before we arrived. So it really just needed a once over by the housekeeping staff. Again, its convenient and an excellent location to many things downtown.  We actually walked to several restaurants and a couple of bars after our party.Update: I've been contacted by the hotel and they more than made up for the rate disparity issue that I had when making online reservations.  I guess I should not have taken no for an answer from the sales department while there. He also said they are on an approved renovation plan, so hopefully future stays will eventually be better for visitors to downtown Indianapolis.The embassy suites were very nice hotel to spend the weekend at. The room was big and clean. The mattress on the pull out couch was a little rough/spring like feeling so I just slept on the actual couch. The managers reception was very nice to get soda and popcorn and other snacks. The elevators were very fast and parking was easy to do on site in the garage. The location is perfect for downtown the hotel is connected to circle centre mall, colts grill. Walking distance to the circle monument, canal, very close to the baseball stadium and the convention center was just a few blocks over. Great location to get to things downtown.Serious moisture problems coming from the windows the condensation would even drop down onto the bed and you could see where it had caused damage on the walls. Possibly mold. ** Update: Contacted Hilton Customer Care to notify them of the issue and they refunded me one nights stay including taxes to me mailed to my house. That's why I love Hilton. Hopefully they fix the mold issue now for everyone else!!Stayed here recently during a conference.  Staff were great.  Rooms were spacious but dated.  Scraped my leg on the 2x4 sticking out from underneath the bed. Looked like it was used to brace the frame.  Convenient to downtown venues and restaurants like other downtown hotels.  The entrance is a bit unconventional.  There is no entrance facing the street, and yo to go up an escalator to get to the front desk or take the elevator by the restaurants on the corner.Managers happy hour in the afternoon and breakfast were great.If negative stars were an option the embassy suites would get that rating from me.  Mold mold mold! Leaky windows and black mold growing everywhere.  I switched rooms and wasn't even given a refund or credit. It wasn't just my room either, we had 10 people check in and every room on the east side had mold issues.Mediocre hotel. The inside first impression was very nice but the rooms are outdated and small for suites. The bathrooms are so small that when you shut the door there isn't much room to move. From 5:30-7:30 they had a nice managers reception with free beer, wine, or well drinks and snacks such as chips and dip, vegetables and dip, salsa and popcorn. But If you're a smoker you are out of luck because you have no choice but to walk the long path out of the hotel down the car ramps/steps to the street to smoke. Over all it was okay. But I wouldn't book this hotel again.Television stations are terrible. With children this is an important amenity. All HD were freezing up. Windows were all fogged up and dripping condensation. Free food was okay but a mad house getting to it.I arrived a little after 5:00 PM. Apparently, there was some sort of special event going on as there were a lot of police officers downtown, and I could not use my Hilton Honors points to pay for the room. The attached parking garage was marked as being full except for hotel guests. I entered the garage and found it was under construction with lots of narrow passageways. I went up ten floors and back down ten floors. There were no available spaces, anywhere, even for hotel guests.  I exited the parking garage and the attendant told me there was no available valet service, I would have to pay $4 for the privilege of not parking in the garage, and could not leave until I paid the $4. The $4 fee is apparently for parking, which I was not successful in doing. I believe that charging money to someone for entering a parking garage when there are no spaces available borders on the criminal. I then called the hotel and asked where I should park. I was directed to the garage for the Circle Center Mall, about a block away. After finding my bearings and avoiding the homeless people downtown, I walked through the rain to the hotel and climbed the stairs to the entrance with my luggage (the entrance is hidden and not very pedestrian friendly). Upon checking in, the desk clerk asked whether I was parking a vehicle with the hotel. At this point, I told her I had paid $4 to not park my vehicle with the hotel because their garage is full, and I was disappointed that they let anyone (not just hotel guests) park in their garage. Her story completely changed and she told me the hotel does not own the parking garage and has no control over it. Very hypocritical to treat the parking deck as belonging to the hotel until there is a problem. The manager's reception was mediocre--yes, you get free booze, but they ran out of the mix for the featured cocktail. They also ran out of potato chips! The snacks provided were carrots, celery, broccoli, ranch dressing, crackers, salsa, potato chips, and popcorn. At other Embassy Suites locations, I have had things like hot queso and chips. The rooms are very noisy thanks to the open atrium design. I think they have added ceiling fans in the bedrooms to attempt to drown out the noise. This is like putting lipstick on a pig. If you are in the suite part of the room and close the door, you will probably be fine. If you are sleeping on the fold-out couch in the living room area, bring your earplugs, as the noise is deafening!  The desk and rolling chair in my room were extremely worn, and the toilet flush handle was loose. Someone's hair was on the temperature control for the shower, and the shower turned cold for no reason while I was using it. When I turned it up, it became warm for a few minutes, then became scalding hot. This hotel is probably due for a makeover, but given my experience, I don't think I'd stay there even if it were made over. One plus, the wifi does not appear to be capped to 1-2 megabits per user, as I have experienced in other hotels. When I checked out, nobody asked how my stay was, otherwise I would have brought up the parking issue again.I give them a four but most of that is based on a free upgrade to a penthouse suite. The regular suites are a little dated but they do have a lot of perks that are included with every stay at embassy suites. Free cooked to order omelette station which they will do with egg whites if you ask. The normal juices fruits bacon sausage etc... They also have a managers reception aka complimentary drinks and simple snacks. As a whole the staff is excellent they moved my packed up belongings while I was at work and upgraded me to the penthouse free of charge. With my permission of course. Sign up for hilton honors and even if you don't stay with hilton brand hotels often you still get little perks like bottled waters at check in and points per stay. Make sure you set up your preferences online because usually there are registrations double and triple point promotions.They will not back date the promotions so make sure you check and register before check in. Once you check in it's too late. Just a weird hilton thing that they don't bend on.THINGS WERE GREAT, until they weren't. Pretty hot and bothered by it still, as this is a fresh situation, but they are LIARS here. Said we'd get more pillows, no. Said there would be complimentary breakfast, nada. Validate parking? Nope. Overall, terrible experience.I went to this embassy Suites Hotel located in downtown Indianapolis where the parking garage sign said  full. But the parking attendant told me to go through because there were plenty of spaces available. It took me about seven minutes to go through the parking garage to determine that the only spots available we're near construction sites. I decided I didn't want to park my car where they were repairing the garage so I left immediately.  Within seven minutes is what it took me to get through the parking garage I was charged four dollars because I couldn't find a parking spot.  The parking attendant told me that the sign says full and then they only let you through at no charge for five minutes. She then called a supervisor because I said I wasn't going to pay. The bottom line is they charged me four dollars for seven minutes to determine there was no parking when the parking attendant told me there was.If this isn't unethical I don't know what it is.The location is great, but that's it. The check in line was extremely long, and no rooms were available when I arrived. Moreover, they had no process in place to contact guests when the rooms were ready, you just had to check back frequently. The room was spacious; however, there was a hole in the wall behind the suite door. We left for our event, and then ate at the restaurant downstairs before returning to the room. The waitress was a bit too homespun to be working at an Embassy Suites lobby restaurant. As she approached our table after we waited several minutes (so much so that my husband asked if we needed to go to the bar to order), I was looking at pictures I'd just taken at the event we'd just left on my phone. The waitress told me to get off my phone and talk to my husband. We uncomfortably laughed it off and ordered. The food took more than 25 minutes to arrive at our table. I ordered an extra meal to go for my daughter to take back to the room as it was late and she had to leave early in the morning. She was not there when we ordered but arrived to pick up her food and ended up waiting with us for some time. When the food arrived, the waitress brought hers as though it was not to-go because she was there. So then we had to wait for the to-go plate so she could leave! My family took turns going to the bar to get refills on our soft drinks.My teen daughter was to sleep on the sofa bed. When we opened it up, you could feel the springs with your hand without even pressing down. Also, there was no blanket or extra pillows in either of the closets. We called the front desk to have them bring them up, and just told her to join us in the bed until they came up. This was a good thing, because they never came.On a trip to Indianapolis, to attend a firefighter conference we chose the Embassy Suites, Downtown and we were not disappointed.  The hotel was quiet, clean, and met all of our needs. We will be sure to select this hotel again if we return.  Fiction, Faith & Foodies BlogI always like Embassy Suites. This one is conveniently located close to the mall and also the convention center. After visiting the Westin and Marriott as well as the JW Marriott, I probably would need to rethink which hotel I would stay in next time. I was upgraded the first day to one of their top floor suites. Very nice 2 story suite with separate walk in shower bathrooms and a kitchen area. The bad part is they don't get hot water on the top floor so I ended up taking a cold shower. Moved to a lower floor and was much better. There is no lobby bar per se. The sports bar is attached, but not quite what I was looking for. Staff was friendly. The fitness center was quite small forcing me to do most of my exercising outside around the area.Location of this hotel is fantastic, but the property itself seems old and in need of renovation. Lighting in the main living area of the rooms is extremely dim and adds to the feeling that the place is "old". New furnishings and modern lighting would do a lot to help spruce it up.I was actually pleased with the location, price, and service.  Yes, the hotel needs an update, but as a hilton gold member they upgraded me to a suite on the 20th floor.  Wow, loft, patio, great view.  The staff were very nice and pilot.  I would stay here again.  Shout out to Cameron at the front desk for his guest service and knowledge.So not impressed.A friend and I stayed here the night before the Indianapolis Monumental Marathon. She sprung for a suite, which was quite large, but obviously needed work.  The carpet was peeling up in the main room thanks to water damage, and there was green mildew or mold growing in the bathroom. It was also freezing in our room, despite turning up the thermostat.The vents also might as well have been intercoms to the room above us.  We heard the rowdy bunch word for word, and eventually smelled their cigarettes, too.  I called down to the front desk and they took care of it, until the behavior picked back up at 3 a.m.  Perfect for a pre-marathon slumber party.It does get more than one star simply because the breakfast in the morning hit the spot for a solid meal before running for several hours. Also, the manager took pity on us and let us use the gym facilities to get ready before we left town after the marathon.Overall, this hotel needs some work, big time.I stayed here 5 nights during a work conference. My experience was excellent. The hotel treated me to free wifi my entire stay,  although the wifi did not work in my bedroom, only in the living room. My suite was very nice.  There were 2 tvs, a fridge, and a microwave. The bedroom had a sink in it,  as did the bathroom and kitchen.  The bed was comfortable.  The soap, hair products, and lotion smelled great.  Every morning there was free hot breakfast. It included scrambled eggs, bacon,  sausage,  potatoes,  french toast,  fruit, yogurt, bagels and cream cheese, toast, muffins, cereal, oatmeal, and an omelette station! There was also fruit juice, soda, coffee, tea, and milk. Additionally, every now and then there were special items, like breakfast burritos. The free breakfast helped me cut down on costs considerably and was extremely convenient.  Just as exciting was the nightly manager's reception from 530-730. There is free booze the entire 2 hours! The free booze included red wine, white wine, and white zinfandel. Well drinks,  including mixed drinks. And 3 types of beers on tap. There were also snacks, but nothing substantial. More like pretzels, popcorn, tortilla chips with salsa and cheese sauce, and vegetables with dipping sauce. The hotel has a business center with computers you can print from for free. There is also a pool and a decent sized fitness center with nice equipment. The design of the hotel does amplify sound, and from the 14th floor I could hear the loud drunk people in the lobby late at night. However, when I was in the bedroom with my door closed I could not hear them. The meeting facilities were ample and nice. Hotel staff was helpful and very friendly. I would stay here again should I return to Indy.A great place to stay!!clean, fun, beautiful. Large rooms with suites: living room and bedroom. The rooms have two sinks one in the bathroom and one outside for a vanity. The living room has lots of seating and a microwave, sink, and fridge. 5:30-7:30 free cocktails, drinks, and snacks!Hot continental breakfast in the morning! And there's a pool! Fairly inexpensive for a downtown stay!
review_content_20: This embassy suite was the least favorite of all the many Embassy Suites I have  visited. The entry from the garage is awkward. No elevator to the main lobby, it was challenging to venture up the small escalator with my bags. The managers reception is usually a big perk and I was embarrassed as I raved about it to my fellow guests. No refreshments were out just dip, no chips or veggies. The breakfast in the morning was lacking in quality. The Cincinnati Suites are wonderful. This location is in much need of a renovation. The other Indianapolis hotels in the downtown area might be a better choice.A step below other Embassy Suites I've stayed in. This hotel is in poor condition. Noisy and the entrance is a dirty alley. be warned that there is no way in without going through a smoky entrance. The best thing is the buffet breakfast.Out of all the hotels in the area, Embassy Suites was a solid $100 cheaper than the rest. It's located right smack in the middle of Downtown, so if that's your destination then I would recommend. The gym is nothing to write home about but it is clean and has the bare basics. Never crowded but there was always someone else in there. The staff was incredibly kind and welcoming. I felt like everyone was going out of their way to help make your stay enjoyable. Some things to note are that breakfast is free and every night from 4:30-7:30pm there is a free reception which includes a light snack and booze. Every night I was here it was packed but seemed like a fun environment. The rooms were huge and relatively clean. Walk in and there is a small living room with a TV then the bedroom is right off of it and had a very comfy king. Views were nothing too great but it was nice to have a lot of natural light.I called the front desk to ask how much wifi was and they told me $10/day. 10 seconds after I hung up they said they could give it to me for free if I used a pass code: embassy110WiFi coverage was spotty/slow in the room itself but faster in the hallways - making it less than ideal. If you want to do any major surfing, I'd suggest going to the lobby or Panera next door.Came here with my wife and a coworker.  We booked on Priceline because we were going to a conference and had to stay near the convention center.   So because it was priceline they gave us both handicap rooms, where the shower sucked in both rooms.  Old smelly furniture, dirty carpets.  Guess they figure handicap people don't care.  Both rooms (on different floors) were FREEZING!!, and you cannot adjust the temperature because its between seasons and they depend on outside air only.  When we complained they promised to send up a heater.  After 3 calls they still never sent one up.  Its now day 2 and its still freezing in here.  The "free breakfast" was equal to the price.  Their claim to fame is that they will cook to order an omelet..big deal!  Ive eaten at lots of Embassy Suites before, this was the worst.  The internet is $11.99/day and if you can stay connected for more than a few minutes youre lucky.
