Which is fine - we are in a train station but let's not butter it up on the website, marketing team.The rooms are on the smaller side, b/c of the age of the building, I assume, but it was comfortable.  I however missed the oversized comforters that I get at JW and Marriott. I love those down filled cozy beds and Crowne just has a heavy blanket.  So there was a touch of "lower end" in that regard.Check in was easy and the front desk staff along with the valets were wonderful.For $79/night I thought it was an awesome deal -- for more, I'm not sure I would stay here again.Take an old train staion, hotel, turn it into a hotel, and add in a few railroad cars into hotel rooms - inside the hotel, then finish it off by adding skywalk access to the convention center and Lucas Oil Stadium and you have a great place to stay in Indy. Factor in friendly and courteous staff, clean rooms and ample room supplies and you have 5 stars. The fitness room has 3 treadmills and a cable weight machine, a small business center, clean pool and on-site restaurant/bar compliment the experience.Downside:  The interior lay-out can present a challenge getting from point A to point BWe stayed in the Charlie Chaplin train car and our friends stayed in a regular room. The train car was double the price of the regular room but inside you couldn't tell the difference. The train car is way over priced. They used to have themed rooms but now all the rooms look the same. It's a nice hotel but over priced. I wouldn't stay there again or at least not pay extra for the train car room.We hosted a meeting at the Crowne Plaza for 35 of our volunteers. Everything was set as requested. There was continual support throughout the event. The food was amazing. The staff were available and quickly replied to any needs we had. They were personable and made the experience great for the facilitators as well as the attendees. Thank you!I have never been happier checking out of a hotel than I was the morning leaving this dump.  Don't confuse this for even the worst Holiday Inn Crowne Plaza in the country.The people here could not care less how rude they are to you, and they have no systems in place, at all, to take care of the simplest things like service breakfast or getting a package, or fixing their internet.  The Internet tech said the wireless wasn't working because I had somehow connected to a router on the 7th floor.....there are only 2 floors.  The manager was apologetic and said she would reduce my rate from $229 to $179....that never happened, so I went to the front desk to explain and the girl would probably still be standing there staring at the computer and shrugging her shoulders had I not just walked away.  I called down at 10:30pm to see if a package had arrived and they said they would have to call me back, which they never did.  I went down in the morning to ask for it in person and the girl stared at me like I was asking for her firstborn.  I could tell it was going to take a while, so I nicely asked if she could get it and I would be back after I walked down to a real hotel to get breakfast...she scowled at me and rudely suggested that she was just making sure I didn't need anything else.  I was being nice, she was full of it.  Ironically I was there for a wastewater show....my toilet was backed up the whole stay and I asked them to fix it at 6:30am.  When I returned at 4:30, exhausted, just wanting to lie down, the room was being made up and the maid had to call down to get the toilet fixer guy to come up.  Breakfast....joke.  Please help by getting another hotel to move in here....do not stay here!  $229 plus tax is ridiculous for this dump.First and last time staying here. Worst check in policy I have come across ever. Staying here for a wedding party. I will continue to stay at the JW on my future trips to Indianapolis.If you decide to stay here and the lobby puts you on the first floor you are screwed. You can hear anyone's conversation that walks by your room.  For us we stayed right by the pool and 10 teenage girls went to the the pool at 9am & woke up our whole room because they were so loud. I would not recommend staying here Bc of this reason.Very cool hotel - an old train stationed that's been transformed into a hotel. It even has a train inside the hotel that's been converted to bedrooms. However, my biggest problem is that my room walls were paper thin. I could easily hear conversations going on in the adjacent room.This is the creepiest hotel ever. The concept of rehabbing an old train station into a hotel sounded cool but staying here was a whole other trip. The statues are creepy as they placed right in front of your room. The first two nights, I had a pair of nuns and the front desk just around the corner from my room. After a leak in the HVAC, I was moved to a room near the pool, near other statues including a little girl standing on a beam above my head. Customer service here is mediocre. The front desk staff are constantly clueless and rude. The housekeeping staff only clean parts of your room while throwing away items that aren't trash (like my commuter mug!). The only bright side is the maintenance crew-- Richard, who came to assess the leak, gave me a dinner comp ($75 for two at the Pullman lounge) for the hassle. Lastly, I found myself feeling super hot every night due to the bedding. Other colleagues staying at the hotel felt the same way. Really odd.I dreaded my stay at this hotel. The concept of being at a train station is neat the first night but the train station and the rumbling of the trains definitely got old after the second night. I could not get a full night's rest staying at this hotel. You could definitely feel and hear the trains going by. I stayed here for a week for a work event and I wanted to go home so badly. Also the creepy white statues in the hallways were weird too.
review_content_20: Enjoyed a wedding and wedding reception at this unique venue. Nothing else like it in Indy. Love the atmosphere!I live in Indy, but a friend was having a bachelorette party, so a group of us decided to stay in a hotel, so we could have a good time. I've been to the Crowne Plaza before, for an even in the conference rooms. I am touched by the charm. I remember when Union Station re-opened, and they had all these "historic" statues all over the place, and there are still a few in the hotel lobby area. Unfortunately, Union Station is no longer open in the capacity that it was. There are trains in the hotel, where you can stay in rooms. I think this would be awesome for kids. They also have an indoor pool. The hotel does seem a bit dated, though. The rooms need an overall facelift. Very convenient location for our purposes, though. I have to say, we were sooooo loud. We did not get any kind of warning or have an altercation like the one mentioned below (that sounds like a totally horrendous experience). I thought the bed was comfortable, but it was firmer and some people may not like that. I thought the accomodations were kinda sparce-no microwave or fridge. Otherwise, excellent stay. Additional note: there is parking in the Pan Am Plaza garage(underground), which is literally right across the ally/drive of the Crown Plaza. It is a bit expensive, but only $20 for 24 hours. I mean, it is literally like a 5 minute tops walk from the hotel front door to your car.Beautiful hotel. Historic building. A dream location for train enthusiasts and those who are lulled to sleep by the rumble and screech of freight trains a few yards from your window. The website fails to mention this. But they make you sign something at checkin that basically says you know the trains will keep you awake all night and they aren't responsible or refunding anything based on that.Nice people equals four stars.  I had a crappy stay and management apologized, they bought me the beverage Platinum members get.  I think it's the duty of a reviewer to comment as such correcting the review.  Give the parking garage people hell for me regarding no elevator!I stayed here for two nights during a tech conference being held in the same hotel. I was very pleased. They are in the midst of renovations, so there was some noise and the pool was closed. However, those mere minor concerns and really didn't affect my stay.The room was clean and well appointed. I had everything I needed. There are even rail cars inside the hotel converted into guest rooms, a very unique feature. There are many restaurants and a shopping mall less than two blocks away and this part of Indy is very walkable. Lucas Oil stadium is right next door. The conference itself was held in a converted train station attached to the hotel--very elegant.Most importantly, the staff were fantastic. From the valet concierge who fetched us a luggage cart when we arrived to the maintenance worker who ran an extra power cord to our table at the conference, the staff, one and all, went out of their way for us.You can do a lot worse than to stay here.Fair statement: the building is very neat. They did a great job of renovating the train station into the hotel. A child would love to stay here.I had to sign a waiver upon check in that I was made aware of the fact it is located adjacent to a live railway. I woke up a couple of times a night to trains. I can't say I recommend it given the difficulty of sleep.Went for one night to enjoy a wedding at St Johns and a reception at the grand hall . I would say this was a terrific experience . The food was good (except the cake was a bit dry but I'm not sure it was their fault there ) when it comes to the reception and yes it looked well coordinated and well done with a great amount of effort . As for the hotel and its rooms I would say it wasn't bad either but it was a bit dirty and other than that I got nothing to complain . Overall a solid place all around . The icing on the cake ? The trains and clever statues inside .We came for a weekend and while the hotel is quite beautiful the noise level from the other rooms and lobby were loud, wait staff in the hotel restaurant rude. The valets seemed to be the only staff actually courteous and respectful often appearing to be the only ones with customer service trainingWe've been there twice - both in winter and summer. It is conveniently located downtown - and on a weekend - easy to find parking. There's valet parking; but you only need it for weekdays.My wife and I stayed with our 10 year old and 16 year old. We highly recommend the train cars. There are a few restored trains - where you sleep in a train car. The room was a decent size; and the kids loved the atmosphere. Unlike the people complaining about noise and the trains passing by, in the train car, we couldn't hear a thing. The decor in the hotel is set with white mannequin-like figures throughout. Really gives a neat atmosphere. The desk people were helpful. Easy walking distance to anything fun in downtown Indianapolis.Downsides: skip the restaurant; don't know why you'd go there anyway with such good choices not far away. Don't expect much from the pool. It is there; it is small; the kids used it briefly.I stayed at the Crowne Plaza Hotel during the NCAA Regionals. I had booked the room in advanced and paid a good price considering the events that occurred during the weekend.After reading previous reviews, I made sure to request a room near the swimming pool. Best decision ever! I was never bothered by train noises during the entire stay. The bed was so comfy and the room offered the needed basics (note: room does not have a fridge or microwave).The hotel itself is very unique with some great charm. It's conveniently located to Lucas Oil Stadium and completely within walking distance to great restaurants/bars in downtown Indy. The staff was extremely friendly and helpful. One evening I needed a cab and the staff offered a ride in the hotel car! Very considerate and I greatly appreciated the assistance.I truly enjoyed my stay and look forward to visiting Indy again and staying at the Crowne Plaza!I stayed here recently after a job interview. I gave this place 3 stars because I think it's a great place to stay for the price if you're wanting a spot in the downtown area. If you happen to be a train enthusiast then this is a place for you. Trains are rolling in and out of here all the time. At first I thought it was a small earthquake, but then remembered that it was a train station. After the first train it didn't really bother me. Also the beds were so-so and the furnishings were probably nice when they were first purchased, but have started to show their age.All in all this hotel seemed like a great bang for your buck if thats what you're looking for.The people were so friendly, and I commend them for this. However, we had a few issues at the hotel while I was here for a work conference. A group of employees got stuck on an elevator, no warning given on the trains coming through, a fire alarm going off with no indication of whether we should be evacuating. This hotel was a fun shtick with the train scenery, but it definitely isn't everyone's cup of tea. A few antiquated features could be updated, but the staff is great.I gave this hotel four stars, but 3.5 would probably be more appropriate. The rooms are nice, but a bit dated for what they cost. The beds are SUPER comfortable though. The restaurant is a bit small, but the food options are decent. I didn't get a chance to interact much with the staff, but they were friendly enough when I did. The hotel's best feature would be its location. It is very conveniently located (attached via skywalk) near the Indiana Convention Center and downtown Indianapolis. Also, very short walks to both Lucas Oil Stadium and the Bankers Life Fieldhouse.I LOVED this hotel!! I had a room that overlooked the pool & it was gorgeous! Everything about the hotel was gorgeous!! I would DEFINITELY stay here again & again...next time I am hoping to get the train room! They told us about the trains, but we never heard any of them. The room was super clean, the beds were comfy, & the decor was modern & fantastic!! It is within walking distance to everything!! If you come to Indy....STAY HERE!! Also the staff was incredible!! The manager that we had a check out was awesome & super bubbly....valet had my car cranked & at the front of the hotel when I was leaving....they even opened the door for me!! Couldn't ask for a better stay!! OH & I almost forgot to mention.....I asked for a late check out & that was no problem! & FREE WIFI!!!!I would prefer to give this hotel zero stars but one is the minimum.  DO NOT stay here!  Let me just tell you about my joyful experience at this disaster of a hotel.  First, we get there and only one elevator is working for the entire facility and stairs are nowhere to be found.  The 80's decorations are disgusting but tolerable.  What is not tolerable is visiting the hell-hole of a restaurant only to be greeted by a blondish-green mullet of a lady that hasn't gotten laid since the mid 90's at a Josh Groban teen concert.  When I made eye contact to request some service I thought she was going to shoot me or poison my food.  She did bring our waters within the first 30 minutes so maybe I should be thankful.  When I ordered my entree she gave me a look of disgust and rolled her eyes.  The food was as miserable as our waitresses attitude.  I looked forward to falling asleep to quickly put this memory in the past only to make it to the room where I was greeted with some pillows that are the size of the square pillows you commonly find on a couch.  They were as thick as they were wide which gave me some neck spasms that I wasn't expecting the day before my half-marathon.  The icing on the cake was when the trains rolled through every hour or so which woke me up thinking an earthquake had just occurred.  The hotel staff in general tried their best to be helpful......Great idea....let's turn an old functioning train station into a hotel.  Way to go Crowne Plaza!  You really nailed that one!  Back to Hilton for Eddie C.The best part of the stay was once we checked out and I saw the hotel in my rear-view mirror........A very family friendly hotel that has been recently remodeled. Stayed in a train car room and my 10 and 7 year old boys loved it.  Staff was all very friendly. Only complaint would be the Pullman Lounge and Restaurant service wasn't very friendly and definitely wasn't speedy. We would definitely stay here again!I stayed in a recently remodeled hotel room which was very nice. I am also a hotel member so I got some drink coupons always nice near heard the train. The place is great location is wonderful and its the oldest train station in the us... You can soon stay in new train cars... Yes, it's under construction right now but will all be so nice soon. The bar and restaurant were great. Thank you had a great stay..My boyfriend and I recently stayed in this hotel following the 2008 Drum Corps International World Finals. We managed to get upgraded to one of the traincar rooms and it was absolutely beautiful. The first night we stayed in a regular room which did not have a minifridge or flat-panel TV like the traincar room. Small but adequate workout facility. The pool is located on the main level and is out in the open, which I thought was a bit strange. The trains rumbling by are a bit unnerving at first but during our 3-day stay I eventually grew accustomed to this occurrence. The staff here was very friendly and accommodating whenever we needed directions or a suggestion on where to order pizza. The hotel is located right next to Indy's downtown area and was within walking distance of everything we wanted to do. Budget for parking ahead of time since it is not included in the hotel price; parking in the ramp next to the hotel was $20/night."WOW !! Do you want to sleep at nite ?? DO NOT STAY HERE !!! The train station is located behind the hotel. It is loud and vibrating day and nite !!! Looks nice but BEWARE trying to sleep !! Would NEVER stay here again!"The hotel is super cute. I stayed here about a year ago while I was in Indy for a week. Parking is expensive, especially when you include tips. However they do have a shuttle service that took me to my office everyday. You can hear trains going through. It was clean and a decent price.(not including parking)
review_content_40: This hotel has a lot of character, complete with white mannequins as decoration (kinda creepy) and an active train station that can be noisy depending where your room is.  Indianapolis is a convention city, and it seems like every time I'm at this hotel, there's a convention going on and the hotel is booked solid... which equates to a lot of activity and noise -- more in the common areas than near rooms, though.  It wouldn't be my first choice of hotel in downtown Indy, but I would stay there again.My in-laws stayed here during DCI weekend, and I also attended the Hall of Fame Induction/Kick Off party at the attached convention center.  The staff at the party was very attentive to the guests.  The hotel room seemed pretty standard for a downtown area, though to a point, I think the place could use some freshening up.  I also hate that the only way you can get in and out privileges on parking is using hotel valet.  My in-laws were interested, but they were full!  They had to get on a waiting list.  They should be working something out with the city for parking validation or something if their options aren't available to appease all guests.Bonus points for location - great restaurants and bars surround the area, and it's a quick walk to Lucas Oil Stadium.I was here for a conference, not as a guest. So let's start out by saying that Heather L's description is dead-on. The hotel is at Union Station, so everything is based on a train theme, beaten to death, revived, then beaten to death again over and over just for fun. As a hotel, that might be fun, but as a convention center, OMFG it just plain sucks. Here's why.Because this is basically a converted train depot, the space is small and not designed for what it is. Conventions are NOT meant to be held here, but are forced to be anyway... the result? Booths that are tiny (8x8 vs. the standard 10x10)... booths spread out literally all over the complex, in the hotel and throughout the adjoining "grand hall and convention center" which spans two blocks and two floors, so confusing that even a map won't help you find what you need... stairs interrupting everything... old elevator shafts in bizarre places... poor signage.... cramped space outside for drop-off/pickup/valet.The train theme might make for an interesting hotel stay, but it's a convention nightmare.Got a pretty good nightly rate using Priceline for a last minute business trip to Indianapolis.  Overall the hotel was worth the rate that I got, but definitely not worth the rate published on their own website.  The room was a bit dated and from what I could see none of the rooms have an exterior window.  The hotel is built inside an old train station.  There also looks to be some rooms that are actually built inside of old train cars which is pretty cool.  My personal opinion, they can made this place really cool by going with a more modern loft style interior instead of whats in there now, but obviously this was converted several years ago hence the dated look.  And whats with all of the tacky ghost statues of former train passengers and staff?My room was clean but I was placed in a room with an adjoining door to the room next door that had some loud inconsiderate guests.  I could hear the door slam as they kept going in and out at midnight.  Also the Amtrack trains still run some where very close to the hotel as I could feel the room shake and hear a hum as the trains passed by.  Initially I thought it was a small earthquake.  I guess I should have realized that something was up when I saw the little amenity pack in the room that included ear plugs. For the cheap price I got on the room, I guess I really can't complain.My one other gripe was the price of the breakfast buffet.  $15 for a buffet is a bit high for a hotel of this caliber.  And its not like the buffet was spectacular.  It was just your normal breakfast fare; the waitstaff service was good though.We stayed here for five nights while in town for DCI. It was perfect because it is so close to Lucas Oil Stadium. The staff was super friendly and always helpful. They always had good suggestions for food. We stayed on the first floor and felt none of the train vibrations that people talk about. Next year when it is DCI time again I will stay here but get one of the train car rooms.The reason I did not give it five stars because we went to the hotel bar one night to get some food and it took us 45 mins to get a sandwich to go.Just as others said, this hotel is a nice historical site smack in the middle of a train station. This is both a good and a bad thing. The Good: It gives the hotel character and apparently you can even stay in an old train car as your room. The Bad: The vibrations of the train are VERY annoying. Luckily I slept through the train coming through at 1am but some of my co-workers were not as fortunate. However, I did have to experience it during our meeting because the speaker got drowned out every time a train went through. Other than that, the hotel was pretty good. They have free internet, which is always a plus. They also gave coupons at check-in: a free drink at the restaurant and 15% off for the restaurant or room service. The room was a good size, but I was disappointed not to have a window. However, I again agree with previous reviewers that this is not the best venue for a conference. The meeting rooms were small and they could not adequately control the temperature. We had two rooms next to each other; one of the rooms was freezing while the other was sweltering.I will never stay at this hotel again!  I had a horrible experience while in town for a bachelorette party, that happened to coincide with the Summer Celebration/Black Expo weekend. Hotel staff was extremely rude and unhelpful. Manager knew she made a mistake and refused to apologize or correct the mistake- couldn't look me in the eye-a tell tale sign of lying! Staff was disrespectful to our party. I will never stay at this hotel again! I've never been more dissatisfied with a hotel!! Choose another one of the many hotels downtown Indianapolis!To be fair I am writing a review for a stay I had here a year ago...but the experience and follow up of the IHG corporate and the hotel were so disappointing that it still stings to this day.The hotel has potential but is laid out such that the rooms are very disconnected from the lobby area and the feel is kind of creepy.I stayed in a train car thinking that would be a neat experience.  It was small and the novelty wore off pretty quickly.  Hard to have privacy with the blinds not covering the windows well and people walking by.I was staying to attend a reunion which had a couple of guests who drank a little too much.  Instead of handling the problem like a professional business, the staff overreacted, shut down the event, and called in the cops to patrol all night.  The whole experience ruined it for the rest of us and the hotel staff could have cared less.  I expressed my displeasure to the manager by e-mail to get no response, I then contacted corporate and finally got a dismissive letter...after about 4 back and forths...instead of a simple apology...I got a pompus, arrogant response from the manager and from the corporate office.  For a hotel who is in the customer service business this one has failed miserably both at the local level and at the corporate level.  I would recommend staying at a Hilton property or Marriott as they know how to treat their guests and when there is a problem know how to deal with it and not treat their guests like second class citizens.Pass on this place. My company had 10 rooms here for trade show. Everyone complained. It's noisy with trains running through building, frayed grey towels, uncomfortable beds, Very worn and dirty rooms. Light bulbs out in guest room. Lobby restroom smelled like sewage. When I left the bellman called me a green and yellow cab and he got a cut of cab fare.This place is very dirty and worn..Nice hotel, nice staff.  The trains are too noisy though.  Would have preferred to have one of the rooms that was in the train car and perhaps it would have been more quiet.I will never stay at another Crowne Plaza again.  They should definitely give you ear plugs on your pillow at this location. There is a train that is under the building that goes by several times a day and night.  The hotel lied to us and told us that we would be getting a discount on the conference rooms, if we brought our conference attendees to their hotel to stay.  Well we did and they then turned around and charged us a lot to use the conference rooms, which had no water, no service other than getting the tables and chairs to the room for us to set up. We had another meeting set up near the airport and we went tot the Crowne Plaza out there and the service was so horrible! I couldn't believe, one of our attendees went around taking orders for all the tables because they were so understaffed.  The 3 people they had working couldn't do any of the things that they restaurant offered. One couldn't count change and couldn't even bring back the correct dollar amount so we could count the change out correctly.  The manager was trying to make coffee drinks but was obviously not trained in any of it. Just a really bad experience with this company and I will never use them and have already let my corporate accounts know not to use them.just stayed here wed, thur and fri night.i was there for business and thus wanted to get a good night's sleepi did not want to have a place crash after partying at bars within walking distancethe walls are so think you can hear conversations going on in rooms 2 doors down.2 of the three nights it was so loud even at midnight: random people walking down the halls on their cell phone, loudlyteenagers running down the halls stomping their feetsome frat boys coming in at 4am drunk from somewhere in the room next to me.good if you want to party and don't care about getting a good night sleepbad for everything elsei would never recommend this place to anyoneStayed here for a long weekend in April.  The hotel is very clean and the staff was Very friendly and went out of their way to make our stay enjoyable.  We stayed in a train car room one night (yes, a real train car) and a regular 2-double-bed room the other nights.  The train car was fun but is fairly small.  My only complaint is that it is rather pricey.  We paid $229 per night with a AAA discount but that could be because it was NCAA final four weekend and the Women's NCAA teams were staying in the hotel.This place is a fine place to stay if you understand that you are staying in an active train station and your room will shake a couple times a day from trains.  The pullman car rooms are adorable, but very small and narrow.  The front desk and bell desk staff was beyond sweet and helpful.  Wonderful customer service.Upgraded to a train car room for our anniversary stay. Furniture was worn, but the ambience was excellent!  A fun experience hotel stay!We got a deal on this room thru Priceline at the last minute. The price for the room was definitely a deal compared to what I heard the employee quote to someone on the phone upon check-in, but it is important to know that you have an additional $20-30 fee for parking, depending on if you self-park or use valet. Other reviews complained that the train theme was overdone or the statues were creepy, but I didn't feel that way at all. I enjoyed the atmosphere, and found the place to be exceptionally quiet, especially for a downtown of a major city. I did feel a slight rumbling a couple times from the nearby active tracks, but it wasn't enough to make my stay unpleasant, and I didn't wake up from it at all. The room itself was a bit dated, and could use an upgrade, but it was clean, quiet, and I got a pretty good night's rest. Our window overlooked the pool and I was worried about the noise, but promptly at the pool's closing time it cleared out and was no problem. I wouldn't mind staying here again of I got another priceline deal, but there are probably cheaper places comparable in accommodations.I had my wedding here, as a wedding venue it was incredible. The Grand Hall is breathtaking as is the bar. The event went off flawlessly; Megan and Katie were incredibly accommodating throughout the entire year long process, they even added rooms to our block the week of the wedding. Chef Randy made a wonderful meal and incorporated many off of menu requests (creme catalana, spatzel). The sommelier was very knowledgeable and made the tasting experience educational, while also mixing cocktails to our specifications. The waitstaff was incredibly coordinated and we did not have any issues with timing of courses and the large number of tables to be served at once.  as a wedding venue i would give it a five, as hotel i would give it a two. I personally think the ghost sculpture are strange and ugly. The pool is not in its own enclosed area and creates a dampness for the entire atrium.  We were in one of the club rooms and it i believe right up against the train tracks. I wasn't sleeping anyway (it was the night immediate before and of my wedding) but the low rumbling of the train was annoying.Try the Pullman Burger in the bar....It is just wonderful! The ghost statues are a little freaky. But all in all it is a nice place to stay.Our stay at Union Station was about as good as it gets.  The staff was friendly and helpful.  The meals eaten there were good.  We were attending a convention at the Indiana Convention Center, and had a room on the second floor.  We simply walked out our room, down the hall a bit and over the skyway to the Convention Center.  How convenient is that?  No shuttles, no cabs.  I took some advice years ago and always leave a $3 tip for housekeeping with a note of thanks.  Biggest Bang for the Buck I know how to do.  Housekeeping gets the least thanks of any of the Hotel's service staff.  My room is always extra neat and clean, with plenty of amenities, and the staff wears big smiles.  I imagine they keep an extra eye out for my stuff too.  Our stay was during a big convention, and so we paid big bucks for the room.  The parking is $25 a day valet parking (come and go as many times as you like) or down the block to a public facility for $20 a day.  I would give them 5 stars for their service and facilities, but only 3 for value, so overall I am giving them a 4 star rating.Great building full of amazing history. The layout is a little confusing for conferences - we had a hard time figuring it out and explaining where everything was to the attendees - could use a little more signage or a printed layout. Staff was very helpful and friendly. Great location in downtown Indianapolis - very close to everything.
review_content_60: Let me begin my reminding everyone that I originally hail from Wisconsin.  As in: Wisconsin, home of The Gobbler, a motel & supper club that (when viewed from the air) looked like a turkey.  Built sometime in the late 60's or early 70's, The Gobbler embraced the key-party generation and offered such treats as blue, red, and purple shag carpeting, "passion pits," and 8-tracks (but only in the business suites).  The Gobbler, and its demise, have been well documented online, so I'll go no further in the description.  Suffice it to say, though, I've been raised with a natural appreciation for unorthodox theme establishments.Still, it took me a minute to adjust to the Crowne Plaza in Indy.  They have a train theme and, by golly, they are stickin' with it.  I attended a conference here recently, and when I booked my room, I learned that the hotel sits in America's first Union Station.  And that they boast 26 Pullman train car sleeping rooms.   And that the hotel is decorated throughout with white fiberglass statues depicting rail passengers of the early 20th century.  These statues are dubbed, "ghost travelers."  Yes, I did my research.But, as is my practice, the research was half-assed, for I somehow missed the fact that this is still an active railroad station, and freight trains go a-chuggin' through at all times of the day and night.  As my brochure explained it, "the muffled rumbling and subtle vibrations of the trains...enhances the ambiance of staying in our hotel, where you can experience the authenticity of a living railroad station."  OK, but the first time I heard those subtle vibrations I thought someone was wheeling a huge dumpster right outside my room.  Not my kind of ambiance.After a few eye-rolls and "I can't believe this" head shakes, I flipped my bitch switch to the "OFF" position.  The hotel was pretty nice, after all.  There were friendly staff who upgraded me at check-in, even at the government rate, to a suite in the gated portion of the hotel (the rest of you should have worked a little harder, I guess).  There were nice conference rooms.  There was tasty hazelnut-flavored Seattle's Best Coffee with the continental breakfast (which almost made up for the Folger's bullshit in my room).  And there was even a sleep kit containing an eye mask, ear plugs, and a "Sleep Advantage" CD.  Unfortunately, the disc's constant "Whoosh,Whoosh, Whoosh" sounds, coupled with the unfamiliar male voice telling me to "relax [insert name of body part here], coupled with my neighbor playing his CD at full volume, kept me awake far longer than if I've just tried the sleep thing unassisted.Still, this place gets high marks for effort and for its commitment to the theme.  If the Gobbler had shown the same level of committment, it may still be with us today.

review_content: Always love Courtyard. This location was very clean and had a modern feel to it as well. Comfortable bed, and the room had plenty of amenities.I suggest getting the Ginger snap at the bar for a night cap. Did me right!I agree with some of the reviews below. This place is ok. I travel a lot for business and choose courtyards because of the complimentary breakfast and free parking. Well this place has neither. The location is about 5min from the mall and monuments. For $210 dollars a night (including tax, room fee, Parking) I would recommend checking out other locations. On a positive note, staff is great and friendly.This is one of the better Courtyards I've stayed in. The location is great for business travelers to Downtown Indy - depending on the weather, you can walk to the University, the Capitol, the convention center or the mall. There's a "limited" restaurant on site but I don't know why anyone would choose to eat at a hotel when there are lots of restaurants within a short walk. Rooms appear somewhat recently refreshed - I got upgraded (Marriott Elite, holla!) and my room was absolutely huge. Be aware that the front of the hotel comes with great city views but also a fair amount of road noise. It's pretty quiet at night though. My room was very clean and I had two solid nights of sleep.In terms of amenities, they've got a small pool, a fitness room and a business center. The restaurant is only open for breakfast (not free) and dinner/drinks (5-10pm I think). The staff I encountered was really friendly and helpful. I'd absolutely stay here again.Frequent guest going on 10 years. They have updated the place - it was needed. But they also raised the price of parking. No free breakfast or cookies like they used to have. There is help yourself free coffee in the lobby. Lobby area is nicely set up for working. How do I always get a night stomper above me? I always ask to get onto a higher floor but they book up quite a bit. Small work out room but newer equipment. Very nice help at the front desk. We love Jason!Place is ok. Internet is terrible. Here's my result for the enhanced "fast" internet that you pay for.speedtest.net/my-result/...If you need fast Internet to work, don't stay here. Otherwise the location and the rooms are good.Located in the middle of Indianapolis this is an ideal location for people visiting the University or downtown area. Staff is classic Midwestern friendly and it's one of the newer courtyards that is clearly made for the business traveler. The on-site restaurant is helpful but has distinct hours, so be sure to pay attention to that or you'll miss breakfast like I did my last day!My room was clean and nice, beds were fantastic, but I was woken up at 8:00 am by the housekeeping staff asking if I wanted my room cleaned eventhough my privacy lock was on the door. I figured they would go away but they didn't so I had to wake up and walk to the door and answer it and then was already awake. I was looking forward to an extra hour of sleep!The only other down side is that the hotel is located in the middle of a few busy streets. I happened to be on the side of the building facing the busiest street and was awoken at least once by sirens. The hotel apologized and threw some Marriott points my way.I will liekly stay here again as the price is reasonable and the location is great for me.I gotta say, I'm a little underwhelmed. The check-in service was medium and there appeared to be no one running the cafe across the room. The pool was also small, and the gym only had 3 machines. It looked pretty cramped so I opted to skip my workout for the 2 nights we were staying. The room was nice at a glance, but not very functional. The shower was broken the first night and the microwave only popped a fourth of the popcorn bag. The minifridge also froze my soup and it appears that there's no way to change the temperature. The queen bed was very comfortable but again, a little cramped in the room. The pullout couch was atrocious. The mattress sagged in the middle and I could feel the springs. There were also no extra sheets the first night, just a thin blanket I found in the closet. Finally, there was no way to look at the bar menu from the room, nor a listing of popular sights and attractions. Over all, not the best hotel I've been to by far.Just ok, not as nice as the Westin , but cost a lot more. The room had a strange smell to it and the air kept coming on in 40 degree weather. Stains all over the carpet. Gross!!!!One more thing....the internet is HORRIBLE. Very slow, and viewing photos on any site is impossible.I think I got my room on Priceline for around $75 incl taxes, and really couldn't have found a better place for the price. This is a recently renovated property on the perimeter of the downtown core, within easy walking distance to Circle Center and other attractions. The lobby is attractive (for a Courtyard) and my room was very comfortable.Parking was steep at $20/night, but I was here on a Saturday evening so I chose to park at the meters outside the hotel instead, which worked out just fine.I injured myself and the staff was so helpful in accommodating my needs. Everyone was nice - from the housekeeping staff to the maintenance to the staff at the cafe. Good location. The canal is across the street. Grocery store a block north. Easy walk to conference center and mall.The Courtyard Marriott is a discount hotel that exceeded my expectations in all areas but one. The rooms were clean, the layout perfect for a business traveller with lots of conveniently located power plugs, a 24-hour gym, and a nice desk. All staff (from the front desk to the housekeeping staff) were exceptionally friendly and helpful. Despite this exceptional experience, the one downside of this hotel is the lack of a reliable full service restaurant. A cafe serves in its place with a limited but decent selection. My first night I was served by a very professional and prompt staff member. Unfortunately, my second night I was not as lucky. Having ordered and told I would be called in my room when the order was ready, I went down to the cafe 35 mins later only to wait 10 mins to be told my order not only wasn't started, that they wouldn't get to me for another 30-40 minutes.The front desk was very helpful in finding me delivery alternatives and I was able to locate a great Chinese restaurant that delivered to the hotel (Nasia). When I'm away travelling, there are times I just would rather work away at the hotel and not have to fuss about finding something to eat. Because of this, despite everything else that was great about my experience here, I will most likely not come back again. For those of you who don't care about easy access to food, I would heartily recommend this hotel for you.Nice property in town that is close enough to the nightlife but isn't stuck in the middle of the crowds. Rooms are clean, spacious, and parking is available at the property without the fuss that yogurt from the more central downtown hotels. Also a good short walk to the canal and river walk.Nice place, got a cheap rate for a great room!We booked this room for a single overnight stay in Indianapolis, and paid just over $100 after taxes and fees. Not bad for a downtown room!The room was fairly basic, which is exactly what I expect for the amount paid. However, it was very clean and everything was in working order. The WiFi had a nice strong signal and worked flawlessly. We had a corner room overlooking downtown, and it was a nice stay overall. Also, this would be a great place to stay if you are in town for a Colts game, as Lucas Oil Stadium is a few short blocks down the road. Also the hotel had a decent looking indoor pool and an exercise facility, although we did not get a chance to use either.The only downside is that you have to pay $20 to park in the lot.... so in reality you might as well go ahead and tack that on to the price of the room. Still not too bad for a downtown Indianapolis room though. A great experience overall, if we are ever in town again I plan to look this place back up. Good hotels at a reasonable price can be tough to find, and this one is a gem.Note: because I got booted from staying here (per my reservation) I didn't actually get to stay in this hotel. The 1 star is for the following experience...Hi Annie,I'm sorry to report I had a horrible experience with your hotel this past week. I was scheduled to stay for 1 night, Monday May 6th and am a Gold Rewards member. I had a long day of travel, and an extremely important day of executive interviews on Tuesday, and arrived only to be told they were overbooked and had to put me somewhere else for the night. They were nice kids, and definitely apologetic for the inconvenience, but didn't buy their explanation at all, i.e. that they had to let current guests extend their stay or else it was a legal liability for Courtyard. ??? That doesn't make any sense to me; if that were the case, the reservation system for any/all hotels would be moot.In any case, they explained that they booked me in an even better place, with a 2 bedroom suite. (not that I needed it, it was just me, but they were trying to make me feel better.) I asked about distance from the Courtyard since my first meeting was downtown in the morning, within walking distance. She said the other place was "downtown," only a short cab ride away, and was walking distance. This was a total LIE. I was put into the Candlewood Suites, on the outskirts of town, at least 2 miles away. There's no way I would've been able to walk, with my suitcase, in heels, 2+ miles to my first interview. In addition, the quality of this hotel was awful - it was a total dump, not at all what I paid for or comparable to the Courtyard by any stretch, in addition to not being the location I actually reserved my hotel downtown. To top it all off, the iron in my room wasn't working. When I called the front desk, they said they didn't have any spare ones. I asked if they could get one from another guest room, and they said to come down in 15 min and "maybe" they would have one. I was increasingly overwhelmed at my impending interviews and frustrated at the Courtyard for putting me in such a horrible situation. Finally, the next morning when I was packing my stuff back up - had to leave early because I needed to get a cab now that I was so far away - and my hairdryer didn't work. !!! I have long hair and could not show up for my executive interviews with wet hair. I almost started crying, this hotel fiasco just couldn't have gotten worse... but yet it kept getting worse. They didn't have ANY extras, explained that they only had ones connected to the wall, and had no proposed solution. I asked if I could utilize an open room because I needed to dry my hair. They finally agreed to that, so after packing up all my stuff and getting ready had to rush into another hotel room to utilize a working hair dryer. When I got into the cab and arrived at my IV - 5 min late due to the hotel's lack of working equipment - I was completely frazzled and sweaty. None of this would've happened if Marriott had honored my existing reservation and not forced me to stay at a much lesser, non-Marriott property. Completely unacceptable.This whole scenario has left an extremely bad taste in my mouth for Marriott brands. They offered me some points, but didn't make up for the nightmare I had to deal with in an already stressful situation. The last thing I needed to worry about was my hotel or working amenities - I needed to be prepping for my interviews and getting a good night's rest. But due to the lack of responsibility and honoring my reservation [as a Gold Rewards member] I had additional stress added to my plate.I wanted to express my deepest disappointment; it is unlikely I will continue to stay at Marriott hotels if I can help it.Excellent facility. Staff friendly and professional, very helpful. Lovely, spacious, clean rooms. The Bristro has good food and great wait staff. Have been here for 4 days and returning next week.Great staff! Jason the manager needs to stay in a customer service roll. Without being cheesy he genuinely made me feel welcome and went out of his way to help. The bar/cafe in the lobby is excellent. Only place I'll stay, especially for the price.Loved the location! Quiet... but in the city.Courtyards always pass my 4-must-haves.Friendly, shower power, comfy bed, good wireless.The good breakfast kicks them up a notch above normal.I'm a big fan of Courtyards. This is a good one too. They offer good upper medium level of service with clean comfy rooms, friendly staff, and FREE internet which is a rarity at this level. Our room had a few maintenance issues, but all in all was very nice and the staff was friendly and helpful.This hotel was excellent. Stayed here this weekend for Mothers Day and could not be more satisfied. The location to Circle Center is awesome as would be for anyone catching a convention, Pacers, or Colts game. All are walkable.We had a kingroom with a pullout sleeper sofa although we didn't need that much space. The room was in really good condition and clean. Bathroom was large as well as very clean.Hotel does have a hot tub and pool (not used by me) and does seem to have some good meeting space as well (not used by me)They have a shared lot with other hotels and you use your room key to get into and out of the parking lot. Lots of room.The front desk people were very helpful and friendly. I'm going to try and book a room for a Colts game there this fall.A rare disappointment for me among marriott hotels. I stayed here off and on for a week at a time (with a total of about 7 times) from 2007 - 2009 and by my last visit, swore I'd never come back.The hotel is in severe need of updating throughout. The rooms have an overall dirty feel to them, the furniture is not comfortable in the room (except for the newer beds), and their "upgraded" rooms (small junior suites with a fridge) are right across from the noisy elevators and ice machines.I somewhat think that marriott isn't putting any $$ into this hotel with the new set of hotels that opened down the street....which is unfortunately because this is a good central location, close to the IUPUI's campus and the capitol.After other Marriotts in town opened up, I haven't looked back on this hotel.
review_content_20: We came on a weekend with no plan and were lucky to have found an online deal for this hotel.  The location is great and has access to the canal and driving to the other districts.  It's also walking distance to Lucas Oil Field.  The hotel seems to be newer, and the lobby is very nice.  The room was clean, and well decorated, with a couch as well, always a nice feature.  The towels were not soft, the pillows were small and uncomfortable, and the water pressure in the sink was low.  However, these were minor complaints.  The fact that packing is $20 a night was unexpected and for the area, could be avoided.  The staff was very nice.  The young man who ran the afternoon shift at the snack bar was excellent, friendly and on top of things.  All in all I would stay here again.don't repeat this, it's a Great place to have Breakfast during the Mini Marathon & then go watch the runners throw up LOLthe place is clean & the staff is friendlyOK!  Even the best have an off moment.  After being made aware of my problems, the management of the hotel contacted me.  I am confident that any issues are corrected, and that the property is run by professionals!

review_content: Kids, kids, kids, and more kids. The pool had about 60 kids in it. The water was not clear or even appealing. Customer service was average. Mostly, it's the perception of cleanliness. One elevator was out of service, there were piles of dirty linens in the hallways, stacks of supplies (they are remodeling), etc.Not one of our better hotel experiences.This place sucks, you can't use the WiFi and they close the bar at 11; 30 with 35 people in it wanting drinks.I will never come back. R vendors if it's free.My wife and I checked into this Embassy Suite Hotel to begin celebrating a fun filled weekend for our wedding anniversary.  We were greeted with enthusiasm as we arrived.  All hotel staff was great.  Our room was a different story.  The room seemed dirty.  I did not want to make a big deal out of it for my wife's sake.  Upon closer inspection, it was evident not much time was placed in preparing this room.Excessive dust everywhere, dried fluid on end tables, dirt and fingerprints on doors, smears on exit signs, dried fluid running down walls and living room furniture, stains and dust embedded in curtains, yellowed shower curtains, what appeared to be blood stains over mirror, no trash liners, and various colored hairs from various parts of the body on the bathroom ceiling.The bed was also broken.  My wife and I awoke realizing our heads were declining.  I ended up sleeping on the couch alone.This was a disappointing experience.  I expected more considering the $150 per night price.I am sure this was an isolated experience, but truly an unforgettable and uncomfortable one as well.Hmm... don't understand what the other reviewers are talking about. Did we stay at the same hotel?! When I was little, my family and I would come to this Embassy Suites as a weekend getaway, so maybe I have really fond, childhood memories? Nonetheless, I stayed here this past weekend and had a lot of fun.  Haven't stayed here in several years, but it seemed like it might have gotten a face lift fairly recently? The furniture in the suite seemed new - leather chairs, nice table, REALLY comfortable beds. I'm such a stickler for hotel beds, but I was super happy about Embassy's beds. Perfect combo of firm and soft. The pillows... I want to know where they get the pillows. So plush! I love the continental breakfast too. The made to order omelets are delish. Waaay better than your standard toast, cereal, yogurt breakfast that is typically in a hotel.  I also like the ambience of Embassy Suites. It's like a jungle in there! Tons of plants, a parrot... pretty fun. I don't always enjoy staying in hotels - usually they gross me out - but Embassy Suites is great and I really do love this location. When you're looking for spacious, nice rooms and a yummy breakfast and happy hour, this is it.The staff was very unprofessional.  Did not assist with requests for luggage carts upon arrival or departure.  Did not replenish towels as requested.  These are just a few of the things.  Don't do it!I have been having a rough streak with Hilton Properties but this hotel was absolutely fantastic.  From the moment you pull up, it is a beautiful property.  The staff was welcoming and extremely friendly and one of the best things, professional.  I didn't find them joking around, texting or on their cell phone, they were courteous and professional.  The room was clean, well layed out and extremely comfortable.  I think they gave me fresh, brand new towels as I have never felt towels so soft at a hotel.  One of the perks of this hotel is the manager's reception every evening and the free breakfast.  I never partake in the free breakfast but I do with the manager's reception.  The bar tenders, servers and everyone I have encountered at this hotel was very nice.I would highly recommend this hotel to anyone in the area.  It can be a little more pricey than some other properties but it is well worth the price.  This has given me more hope that I just had a few bad experiences with certain Hilton properties and now can go back to enjoying my stays at Hiltons.The service was terrible!  The website advertises  a hot tub it didn't work Luke warm at best colder than pool! No towels and none after 20 minutes walked back to room dripping wet with no towel!  They did try to make it right but still disappointing they kept saying they'd fix the hot tub and never did.  They also never alerted other guests checking inPlease note: THIS IS 4-STARS FOR INDIANAPOLIS RATINGS.  If this were in another city, it would be a different story.  However, I have been greatly underwhelmed with every hotel where I've stayed in Indy (anywhere from 2-4 star hotels).  I have stayed here three times now.  The first time was a 4-5 star experience.  The second time was a two star, at best.  This last time was probably a three star.  Here's the deal though--if you're staying in Indy, stay here.  For the money, there is no doubt that this is absolutely the best value.  Drinks are included in the evening and a decent breakfast in the morning.  The gym is acceptable.  The room service is pretty good.  I've had problems with cleaning before (mildew in the shower, dried liquids in kitchenette, stains on covers).  I've experienced front desk staff who were curt and patronizing as well as some who were plesant and professional.  It is a good place to get away for the night on a budget.  Its a good place for extended business stays.  Its a PERFECT place to stay with your family.  Also, nearly every room has a balcony.  They're tiny, but great for just stepping out and getting fresh air.  BOTTOM LINE: I've liked this place enough to go three times and will likely return again.We stayed here this last weekend for 3 nights.  Embassy Suites are generally pretty decent, and this one was no exception.  The made to order omelet bar is a great thing to wake up to.  They also have a couple hours of free drinks each afternoon, and this include a couple really good tap beers and rail drinks.  Everyone that helped us during our stay was friendly.  Also, in the lobby they have a really cool looking parrot!  As far as the room goes, everything was clean, and the carpets seemed newer.  They could use some upgraded blankets, but that's minor.  I would definitely stay here again if I find myself in Indianapolis.This hotel room passed my cleanliness inspection.  The bed was alright, pretty cozy.  Room was well appointed and everything.  The dude who made my omelette in the morning did a really good job.I don't know if all Embassy Suites are like this, but I actually don't really like the layout of this hotel and how the hallways are all out in the open.  I think it makes for less privacy, personally.My experience was quiet (on a monday night) but I can see how this place could be loud with a bunch of little shits running around.People in other reviews seem to be neglecting one awesome thing: There's a parrot in the lobby!  I think parrots are awesome, and I enjoyed looking at Missy the bird.  I tried to speak to her when I was drunk but she just looked at me.Very nice property! Rooms were outstanding! Don't know how old it is, but everything looked and felt new, very clean and comfortable. Staff was very nice and accommodating. A bit annoying that when I extended my stay at the front desk, they forgot to reauthorize my room key. Got up to my room on the evening after my original reservation was up and the room key didn't work. Had to go all the way back down to the lobby. Oh well, mistakes happen. Breakfast your was average Embassy Suites breakfast buffet fare. Seemed a bit more on the buffet for the weekend. The woman working the omelette station/grille during the week was much better than the guy they had on the weekend. Manager's reception each night was excellent. Nice array of things to nosh on: veges, chips, dip, salsa and popcorn. Alcohol was free flowing: the bartender knew how to pour generously (and he was also very easy on the eyes :-)    ). Definitely wouldn't think twice about booking here again if planning to be in Indy!Last two times the same story, elevator room and very poor internet. It took me 30 minutes to get a connection to write this review. Front desk gave me a 1-800 number to call. Get a better router. If you are on business and need an Internet this won't work.I LOVE the look of the hotel, looks like a mini shopping center, the lobby is like a miniature garden with plants and fountains and the like. They also have a wonderful colorful pet macaw parrot named "Sweetie" she's often in the cage, but allowed out! The breakfast is GREAT made to order french toast, pancakes, and omeletes. Theres also a happy hour, yes drinks and snacks! The rooms are beautiful, designed like actual apartments to help you feel like your still at home and not a actual hotel. The pool is fantastic cool and the whirlpool is the complete opposite, a nice steamy and relaxing hot. Other than that the staff is wonderful, pleasant and always willing to help, always sent us off and greeted us with cheery voices and smiles.There's a O'Charleys, Steak & Shake, White Castle, JcPenny Store, Smoothie King, Sprint Store, Panda Express, & Dennys located within walking distance. There is also a Walmart across the intersection from the street perpendicular from the one the hotel is located on. There's a few good stores in that area tooOne tip is the elevators, there is four and because so many ppl are there its constantly running and comes kind of slow when called. So of course your options are the stairs, where it gets tricky, because some lead only outside, some lead no where at all, and then thats just that BUT here's is a simple secret: If you take the stairs always come out of the stairway on the second floor and walk in the direction of the pool OR the front desk if you havent been to the pool yet, that set of stairs by the pool is close to the entrance and your best bet of making it where ever on time.The room was decent for what we paid for it I guess. Found a cockroach in the bathroom the 2nd day and heat barely worked the whole time we were there. My wife's family kept getting harassed at the pool when they weren't able to produce a room key. Only positive thing was the hot breakfast which is pretty good. Won't be staying here again though.The kids, kids, kids!!! I know we were visiting on a Saturday, but the place was overrun by kids. It wasn't families with 2-3 kids, but families with 7-10 kids each. Despite being told at check-in we had to wear these wristbands for both the happy hour and breakfast, there were tables of 10 kids, none of which had wristbands. The pool was overrun with rowdy kids as well. The elevators were quite possibly the slowest I've seen.  During the morning rush, there where 20 people were trying to get on the elevator, and even the hotel maids carrying a carrying huge bags of towels demanded to get on as well.I've stayed in several Embassy Suites before, and I must say, this was my worst experience yet.  Perhaps we were just unlucky to be there the same time as hundreds of kids, but as I mentioned, the staff didn't seem very friendly either.Finally, despite the fact that it says it is close to the Children's Museum, it's several miles away.  In fact, there is another Embassy Suites which is closer.  I don't think I'll be staying here again on my next trip to Indy.This hotel is very convenient for business travelers in Carmel or anywhere around the north loop of 465.  I stayed here a few years ago and it looks like it may have gotten a facelift since then.  It offers the usual amenities - decent complimentary breakfast and happy hours, nice work area in the living room part of the suite, and medium-sized flat screens in both rooms.  The room and bathroom was clean, the front desk personnel were courteous, parking was free - just a good, decent hotel where I'll stay in the future too.I'm like Meredith, did we stay at the same hotel? We really enjoy this hotel and have had lots of good times here. Great location for what we do in Indianapolis. I await our next trip to compare notes with the others but readers. Our times here have been very enjoyable.Clean rooms, no bed bugs is always a plus.....that is a huge worry here in the Midwest.....staff very friendly, basketball rim outside, ok workout room (nothing special), nice pool and a great sauna! IDK if because i am from Chicago I expect my elevators to be quick, but this hotel needs an elevator upgrade QUICK! These are the slowest elevators ever!This hotel has definitely seen better days.  This hotel is now used by low budget travelers and school groups that need to sleep 8-10 per room.  We stayed on 8th floor.  Getting off the elevator I noticed the dirty carpeting.  Looked like popcorn ceiling had fallen onto the carpet.  The room was OK if you don't mind stained furniture.I did enjoy my stay here.  The rooms were nice and clean and bed linens were fresh and clean.  The breakfast was delicious and I would stay here again.
review_content_20: Bedbug Alert - My first bedbug experience! I discovered bedbugs in my room last night as I prepared to go to sleep. The hotel moved me immediately and offered to accommodate any needs I had, which were none at that time.  I will stay at the property again based on how the hotel management handled the situation. I just wanted to let everyone know to keep an eye out.I got in at 2 am and asked for a room not near the elevator.  I basically wanted a quite room.  The concierge places me right in front of the elevator which i didnt realize until i go t into my room and heard the constant noise.  I cant imagine them accompating anything else if they cant understand a simple request.Seems to be an older hotel, being renovated. but its a place to sleep.

review_content: Spent a week here. decent rooms, nice lobby. Did not try the restaurants. Whole IUPUI campus is covered by free AT&T wi-fi (hotel has wi-fi as well). So that was nice. Parking is kind of a pain in the ass since it is all zoned for the surrounding university. You can pay the valet to take care of your car for you. No pool! What's up with that?This place is no longer open to the public as a hotel. It's been a dorm for IUPUI students since fall 2013. Chancellors restaurant onside is open to the public and is pretty good. Only eat here if you are on campus and can't walk to much better places downtownI had to travel to Cincinnati to work on my rental unit, but it was Saturday and no one could quote work until Monday...so off to Indy for dinner with an old friend from Chicago (its about half way each way).I quickly book a room on an online travel site and though this place was a little bit out of the center of the city, it was a little drive to get down to the happening places.But my friend and I still had a good time. The place is clean and big. Sitting smack dab in the middle of a University, this place is nicer than I would have thought. Big rooms, clean, everything works and looks new. Views out the windows are nothing big, but considering the price, worth it.All and all a good alternative than paying trumped up prices for being close.Not a bad hotel, friendly efficient service, rooms are better than adequate, clean, large bed, car park $18 a day. Room service efficient, food itself was diabolical, overcooked ribeye steak and veggies, not worth $42 at all.Tried the Den, which is a little sports bar, pappardell with goat cheese was delish and worth its meagre dollars. Not much nearby - just a barnes and noble was all I could see. Hotel was $95 a night so overall good value.I read the reviews on here and was a little skeptical about staying here and almost canceled. My friend was staying at the Westin this weekend, so I ended up going back and forth to hang with her via the shuttle. The shuttle is a great service! They take you where you need to go in the city and just call them before 11pm and they will pick you up. I was having too much fun with my friend and missed the last shuttle for the night. ;(I have to say that I liked my double room MUCH better than my friend's king room at the Westin. The bathroom amenities are great and they give you a mat for the shower, not a towel. I enjoyed the coffee provided. The staff that I encountered were friendly and helpful. Parking is $18 a day, but they give you in/out privileges. There is free wifi. I would stay again.Overrated on most of the travel sites. Indy has much better to offer and would suggest unless you are getting an outrageous $, look elsewhere.Nice, clean & quiet. Close to Lucas Oil Stadium and waterfront attractions but I wouldn't walk there in cooler weather or if you have kids--it's not that close. You pay for parking but you would anywhere this close to downtown. Rooms were clean and modernized. You can tell that it's an older hotel but it's been kept up. Can't do much to change bathroom size etc. with remodel. Large lobby with lounge and typical snack store. There is a shuttle that will take you and pick you up from a few specific locations downtown. Overall, I would stay here again unless I could get an actual downtown room at a place like the Sheraton for the same price.Sweeeet surprise of a hotel. All the mod cons, including an HD TV (with, oddly, no HD channels) and MP3 player in the room. Awesome bed and nice views of downtown if you're on the good side and high enough.Staff was very friendly... lobby was way cool. Never got to try the food, but the room service menu was megapricey. for breakfast. I found the usual campus fastfood suspects nearby.But... they lose a star because the official address is not where the hotel is. Actual entrance is really something like 915 North Street. It's bizarre. The hotel isn't on Michigan Street at all.Also, expect $14/night for parking. As this hotel is on a university campus and not in downtown proper, it feels like a bit of a rip-off. I'm not a student... my parents aren't paying, k? :-)I ordered a $13 driver, and they got me a $40 taxi. Not ok, never ok. Train your people. Why would anyone want to spend that much for a shitty cab, when they can get a nicer car or share a ride for $13. Its not like its a nice cab. Anyway, rooms were so-so. Staff was bland, dry, and not helpful. My key stopped working and I was blamed and it took them forever to help me. Also, check in took forever. Shouldn't they have enough people working so there aren't 5 people waiting in line?If I had my choice, I wouldn't stay here again.Was here for a work related conference and my experience was nice enough. The facilities were clean, bed was comfortable, and having eaten all my meals here (they were provided for free by the organization I work for), I can say they were decent enough. I didn't have the time or energy to venture out of this "complex" into downtown, but I understand there is a shuttle. Without the shuttle, I'd say this is only a convenient location for people having something to do with IUPUI. Also, there is free wifi. Finally, a random note about the box lunch the hotel provided me with on my last day--SO pleased to finally get a vegetarian box lunch with a sandwich that wasn't mainly cucumber.I agree with the others. Aside from docking my credit card $75 a day for incidentals, everything else was excellent. The breakfast place on the first floor was awful, though.Booked on hotwire.comVery disorganized and short-staffed. I had to wait in line at reception and it took FOREVER. Then they were supposed to send me a receipt over email because their printers were down, so I had to call and ask for it. Which meant a Loooong time on hold. Also, not very close to city center. Unless they somehow add more staff, I'd stay away.My girlfriend and I needed a weekend away and so we got on Hotwire and snagged a couple nights at this hotel for a bargain. We had a good room with decent amenities. Parking was free at the underground garage and while not convenient to downtown (driving, not walking distance) we couldn't complain too much.The only problems we had were Saturday night and Sunday morning the lobby was roped off because apparently the Indianapolis Colts must've been staying there.Insanely FAB Conference Rooms, i've never stayed at the hotel, no matter what you've heardWorst experience I've ever had at a hotel. I actually feared for my safety at this hotel. Truly astonishing poor front desk and valet service. Vindictive and mean. Internet was horrible. Do not stay here. I could go into great detail but this place is a true dump. Be smart and stay at one of the Marriott or Hilton properties instead.Have stayed here the last five years when going to gen-con, and enjoyed the hotel. However to put it in perspective we only sleep here. We enjoy the walk to the convention center (or the shuttle if it is raining) The first year here we were amazed of the quality of the room, sorry the next years it was expected. We will likely be enjoying a stay here again this coming summer.Nice Hotel and staff. If you come don't use your debit card. Everyday they will authorize your card for $75.00 for incidentals. I was there a week and my card available balance was down $525.00 is was temp., but still.NO HOUSE KEEPING OR ROOM SERVICE!!!I recently stay at University Place Hotel for a convention being held at the RCA dome. When I booked I was told a free shuttle was being run between the hotel and the convention. When I got there and asked about it I was told "Well I wouldn't wait for the shuttle. I haven't seen him all day (it was 2pm). He picks people up and sometimes they want to stop at CVS and stuff, so you'll be waiting awhile." I ended up spending more that $40 on cabs over 2 days because it's too far to walk (20-30 min each way) -- not to mention they charge you $14 a day to park there, and you are near nothing else and the parking is for hotel guests only. Next, we ordered room service. An hour and 15 minutes later they brought the wrong order. I called down and informed them of what our order really was. They brought it up, and surprise!-- some food was missing, no silverware and no condiments! I called again and gave them a list of what they forgot. They came back up with some of it. We just gave in at that point (2 hours after order)... then I got the bill. They billed us someone else's order. Instead of under $20 it was $46.The coup de gra'ce was when we walk in the door the first evening to see that room service never came to our room! I called down and asked that they send someone up. We ditched out for about an hour, and when we came back, there were 3 towels and folded sheets sitting on the desk... next to the tray of room service dishes from the morning-- UNTOUCHED! (I tossed the tray and all the dirty towels into the hall-- they did manage to get that cleaned up by the next morning.)There is no reason to say at this hotel, unless you enjoy being systematically irritated into submission.Just stayed at the hotel on a last minute trip to Indianapolis to watch the AFC Championship game (Patriots vs. Colts). As you approach the hotel from the street, it doesn't look like anything special, but once you step into the lobby you are pleasantly surprised.The hotel looks relatively new and is very well decorated. Rooms were spacious with extremely comfortable beds and a high definition Samsung TV. Good cafe to grab a quick breakfast located on the 2nd floor - $13 hot buffet and $9 cold buffet.Location was convenient to downtown Indianapolis (about a 20 minute walk or a very short cab ride), though not much within a 5-minute walk like other city center hotels.I booked the hotel through Hotwire (didn't know which hotel I was getting until I completed purchase) and paid a total of $90 for this top-notch hotel.Got details of reservation wrong. Didn't help fix. Repeated calls to front desk unanswered. Finally got housekeeping to request a blanket, never delivered. Total and complete disaster. You are an embarrassment.
review_content_20: I cannot believe that this is considered a 4 star hotel (according to Priceline). Horrible service, the toilet was semi broken, no pool or extra amenities and rude front desk personnel.

review_content: This hotel is where it's at! I mean seriously.... what hotel gives you a free happy hour with food and drinks and a free breakfast full of sausage gravy and biscuits, waffles, eggs, bacon, etc. ???? I mean... I've never been to one!I definitely enjoyed my stay here. The beds are comfortable, the amenities are wonderful, and the staff is welcoming. Definitely check out a Drury Inn.Do not stay here if you are prone to seizers!  Smoke detectors are located above the beds and blinks 2 ridiculously bright and sporadic lights all night long.  You can still see the lights with your eyes closed!!  I asked management if they could do something about the lights. Management actually Said "The lights have to blink for it to work. I had to sleep with a pillow over my face. When I got back to my room at the end of the day, they had done nothing to reduce the brightness of the lights.  Instead we found a fold-up bead in the room. (We didn't order a folding bed). ".I will not stay here again.We stayed here for a baseball tournament, my husband is the coach. We brought our 15 month old daughter and she really enjoyed the pool. The staff was so nice and everything was very clean.Had to give 5 stars.The hotel was full of baseball, basketball and robotics teams.The staff did a great job keeping up with the volume in the hotel and remained friendly and helpful.We traveled in with a baseball team (our third travel tournament this summer) and this was definitely the best hotel and experience.Everyone appreciates free snacks and free breakfast and they have guest washers and driers which was helpful.I would recommend the Drury and would stay again.Very friendly and quick check-in.  They do take AAA discount, so I think with 2 adults and a dog ($10 extra), our rate was $121 after taxes & dog fee.  In my opinion, it is a good price if you are taking advantage of the snacks & beverages.  They had hot dogs, chips, salad, Minestrone soup, carrots & celery, baked potatos, mac-n-cheese, etc.  Plus, 3 free alcoholic drinks and free sodas.Beds were comfortable (includes 5 small pillows) on each bed.  Bathroom and room was clean.  Indoor/outdoor pools.  I did not try the Wi-Fi, so cannot comment.  Nice & quick checkout & the Manager was very friendly and said how cute our dog was.  I would definitely stay here again.Called to make a reservation on Thursday night for a Friday check in. Two boys in two with a stop over in Indy. Drury had some good reviews so we decided to give it a shot. Paid $60 less at this hotel than at a different brand name hotel. Way worth it. Very kid friendly. Free popcorn and fountain drinks til 10 pm. Didn't make it for happy hour but breakfast made up for it the next morning. Rooms were decent size. Staff was very friendly. Went for a half hour jog on the treadmill in the workout room. Nothing special but does the trick. Hot tub, indoor pool and outdoor as well. A little perk about this location, there was a TwinPeaks within walking distance. Almost went there to watch the Blackhawks playoff game but I was too tired and ended up watching it in the lobby with another guy staying there. Like I said above, the breakfast was fantastic for a family. I have a 4 yr old and a 1 yr old boy. Both were satisfied. Waffles, eggs, toast, coffee, cereal, fresh fruit, biscuits, and sausage patties. Apple and orange juice. Good job Drury Hotel Indy. Next time we want to go to the Children's Museum in Indy, we will be staying here. In fact, we are going to seek out other Drurys while traveling as well.Very nice hotel. Here for baseball and they have and indoor and outdoor pool + hot tub, free breakfast and dinner + 3 free beverages for the adults. Definitely a top Drury hotelI should give this 5 stars but nothing is perfect. The level of friendliness of the staff especially in the food area, which is a great concept, was over the top. You feel totally welcome. I didn't think this type of service existed any more.
