They noticed a possible error in our reservation and I received a call with assurance it could and would be fixed as well.  In 2011, I am so amazed to say...it was.  Follow through was flawless.  From check in, to extending our stay, locking away our techno gadgets, to gratis water..this is the place we will go to first for business or leisure in Indianapolis.  It was so great, I have purposely starting looking for more clients there!
review_content_80: Just lovely. If I die and go to hotel heaven this is where I shall land. I mean just perfect and plush in every way. Jeez Louise if you don't find the Conrad stunningly perfect I think you must be beyond spoiled. If you be bitch'in about The Conrad you truly be a bitch!One of my favorite places to stay when in Indianapolis. If you are looking for quick and friendly service, the Conrad's staff has it down to a science. There's free wireless internet throughout the hotel. The hotel is near the Circle Centre Mall and the Arts Garden. The Conrad, in my book, certainly lives up to it's 5 star rating.Rooms - well appointed if a little on the small side. A nice king size bed with plenty of pillows, a loveseat, 2 chairs, a desk and a dresser round out the furniture. There's also a 42" plasma HD tv on the wall and a DVD player in the dresser. In the bathroom there's a stand-up shower, full tub, sink and a 15" flat screen tv. The mini bar has coffee and tea available, as well as snacks and drinks.Restaurants - I only ate breakfast at Vitesse, their casual restaurant. I had the continental breakfast each day I was there. I didn't eat at the Capital Grille.We splurged on a night here for a special occasion and it was wonderful!  we had actually stayed here before for work, and we were sad we were there for less than 24 hours.  I do think the valet parking is overkill with all the "nice" cars parked out front, right in the path of the Cultural Trail, but inside is a great experience.  I do remember using the car service when I was there last, which was very convenient, and everyone was very polite.  On their website, you can option to automatically upgrade your room if available for cheaper than if you booked it outright, so we ended up with a corner suite!  Big bedroom with a sitting couch and flatscreen TV, 2 bathrooms, each with a small flatscreen, double shower heads and full size tub (with a detachable spray head and extra high water level safety drain), sitting room with desk and couches and another big flatscreen....it's almost as big as my apt! Housekeeping came by in the evening for turndown service and put out a couple bottles of water and turned on some mood music and lighting in the bedroom.  :)  The bed is super comfy and I walked around in the robe and slippers after my extra long bath during which I watched TV. We didn't partake of anything in the mini bar, but they have full (and mini) bottles of wine and drinks and wine glasses and just about anything you could think of to splurge on, as everything was typically overpriced. what do you expect?  I'd stay here again in a heartbeat and encourage anyone else who can afford it to stay here as well. Oh yeah, we did have breakfast at the Capital Grille (ordering off the menu was way cheaper than booking the room and breakfast package, especially the vat of oatmeal with fixin's for $5!). And of course, there's Tastings downstairs.  Valet parking is $33 for a night, but if you don't wanna pay that much, i'd park at the mall or something for way cheaper.Nicest hotel in Indythe best way i could describe the conrad would be to liken it to an iphone: a neat, amazing little machine with lots of cool perks, but lacking basic functions. the conrad is ~le swank hotel~: huge comfy bed; a soaking tub; bathroom WITH TV (i totally watched it while peeing every time) and phone (no, i have not called while peeing every time); huge-screen lg tv in the room; nice muted lighting as opposed to the usual harsh white bulbs you'll find; verrrry helpful staff (my boyfriend's car battery died in the parking garage, it was less then five minutes for a guy with a little  jumper box to save the day); a super speedy elevator, the fastest in the city according to the guy who helped us with our luggage; and the capitol grille in the lobby has the best onion soup i've ever had.however, ~le swank hotel~: does NOT have free parking (or even cheap parking, but i guess that's typical for downtown indy); no wifi, not even pay wifi, which is almost insulting considering the hampton, multiple drury inns, and holiday inn express we stayed in prior while on the road ALL had free wifi; our lovely dual-head-porn-movie shower leaked alllll over the floor, the seal at the bottom is not so seal-y; the lock on the bathroom door didn't work, it looked like the hole was cut too low for the bolt; and according to the boy, the one-cup coffee maker made crap coffee, though he is a real coffee snob, and apparently has not had one good cup thus far this trip.so probably the biggest gripe is the lack of internet. this is not the 90's, where the internet is a new, exciting frontier filled with magic and wonder and the only porn is ASCII pictures of boobs downloaded over an hour on 28k dial-up. you are ~le swank hotel~, stick some routers in strategic spots and get on the train. re-seal the shower, fix the lock, and we are in super-business.This is probably the best hotel in downtown Indianapolis, and I've stayed at many of them. The room is fabulous, if a bit small. The bed was probably the most comfortable one I've slept on in recent memory. The bathrooms are huge and have both a tub and a shower. Twenty-four hour room service for when you need ice cream and coffee at 2:00 am. There's a great steak place, Capital Grille, on site, as well as another restaurant that I haven't tried. The rooms have mini-bars. The lobby bar is nice. We found the staff helpful during our few interactions with them. On our way out, we asked where we could buy a couple bottles of water, and they gave us bottled water for free.i only stayed there for two nights and i can't evaluate the room service (didn't order any), the restaurant (didn't eat there), or the spa (didn't use it), but the room itself was very nice.  gotta love the flat screen tv in the bathroom, that's the lap of luxury in my book.  i would have liked slightly more extensive exercise facilities (there were 2 treadmills and 2 elliptical machines, so while it was pretty much empty and i didn't have a problem getting an elliptical, i would've been annoyed if that wasn't the case, and there were very few weight machines as well), but that's really my only complaint.  also, i found the staff to be very friendly -- perhaps too much so -- but that's better than not friendly enough.

review_content: We stayed here during hubby's trade show at WWETT 2016.  Great hotel with all the amenities, super convenient to nearby restaurants, shopping mall, attractions, Indiana State Capitol, Convention Center, and Colts Stadium.  The fitness center is immaculate.  Our son enjoyed the heated indoor pool, no hot tub though.  If you get a chance, check out the cool-looking metal pool.  Ironically, I enjoyed the laundry facility equipped with TV and microwave...it's the little things.  Having the ability to wash and dry clothes, especially when traveling with the family is a bonus!    Overall, Marriott's hospitality is exceptional.  The staff are friendly and helpful.  Knocked off one star due to their small and uncomfortable pillows, couldn't sleep well.  Starbucks is located in the spacious lobby.  There are a couple of restaurants to choose from on-site, one is Champions and the other is Circle City Bar and Grill.  We dined at both, each one offers a different ambiance.  I would definitely stay here again once they get firmer pillows =)My company had a function that required large meeting space and the Marriott fit the bill. The location downtown is close to many attractions and people can walk pretty much anywhere.  Although I did not stay in a room I did see a lot of this property. It is some what outdated, the decor needs a facelift.  The carpet is very busy - think early 90's. During the meeting we had lunch. The staff was very attentive and quickly took away empty plates.  The food was good - it was standard hotel catering. When cooking for that many people nothing is going to be horribly fresh. I had chicken and beef. The beef was cooked to medium rare and was tasty. The chicken was pretty dry. The soup was tasty and the salad bar was solid.  The deserts came right out of a box.  The meeting room was plenty big for our group but it was freezing cold and no one seemed to know how to adjust the temperature. For a meeting it was a fine experience.We were staying here the night before a marathon hoping to get a good night's sleep. That did not happen. We'll never stay here again. It was actually the second time we'd been here, the first visit we thought was a fluke. But this second confirmed that this place is in no way worth the money.Pros - 1. It's in a good location, convenient to everything on the west side of downtown Indy.2. It was clean.Cons - 1. We were supposed to have a king bed, instead we were given 2 doubles. The girl who checked us in never bothered to mention that the kings were unavailable.2. The return air vents work like an intercom between the rooms, everything can be heard through them. Some teenage boys decided to have some fun with them by yelling obscenities through the vents so all the rest of us could hear how immature they were. I'm incredibly grateful we didn't have young children with us.3. The thermostat is directly beneath the heating / cooling vent. So once that 3 cubic foot area is cooled to the proper temperature, it shuts itself off and the rest of the room is still stifling.4. The pillows and comforter were are filled with down. I absolutely hate down pillows, there's a reason mankind invented foam pillows. But evidently this Marriott doesn't believe in providing an alternative.Hotel was very clean. We stayed on 14th floor right across from the ice machine. Walls were very thin. We heard Hall noises all night long. View out window was great. Direct view of victory field. All employees were friendly.Meh. I tend to like Marriott's but then realized that I've actually only liked the Renaissance and the Marriott's in "higher end" cities like Maui and Marco. I felt this hotel was your basic run of the mill larger chains. Stayed here one night while traveling through Indy and for over $200/night, I expected more. Our room was actually big enough as we had an end unit (which kept the hallway noise to a minimum) but the bathroom was on the small side. And while our room seemed clean, the bathroom was disgusting as I found some kind of red stain on the toilet base and shower curtain. Housekeeping really needs to step up the game here. My stars go to the valet/bellhop as they were friendly and professional as well as the girl at the desk upon checkin.The front desk staff was friendly. My room was normal, nothing fancy, nothing horrible. The vent in the shower is a little creepy, and the room was supposed to have a microwave but did not. If you elect to buy the wifi you can choose if you want dialup speeds or speeds capable of streaming. I didn't use it so I can't review the actual speeds. Concierge wasn't helpful, wound up using Yelp and Google to find what I needed instead. Checkout was quick and easy. The valet team should train the rest of the hotel staff, these guys provided exceptional service. Despite the fact they had to run to a garage and get the car, they always had it ready for you with the heater on within minutes. They were friendly, attentive, had a sense of humor, etc. For being the ones that have to stand in the cold and run back and forth between a garage, they definitely provided the best customer service.Don't be fooled by the the nice entrance and lobby of this dump. It's a trick...Dark bathroom looks like it hasn't been updated since the 70sHallway carpet smells damp and musty,  the room carpet isn't much better.  ceilings have the 80s style popcorn. Shower is sluggish. Drain stopper didn't work, No hair dryer. Sounds of pipes all night. No ice on our floor or 3 others I checked on, what the fvck.  For the 230 a night,  asked for a refund after being in the room for less than 10 minutes and they refused saying we would be charged the full amount. Would never recommend this place to anyone,  find a super 8 or motel 6, this place sucks.I've stayed at a couple of other hotels in this downtown/convention center area of Indianapolis (the Westin and the JW Marriott). I didn't have very high expectations, as I generally don't for convention hotels, but our stay included a few pleasant surprises which made the experience positive overall.When we arrived, we were checked in by Prince. I don't usually chat with people but he was so friendly that my wife (also very friendly) jumped into the check-in process. He was asking whether we wanted a king room or two doubles and my wife said she really wanted a view. So, Prince gave us a room on the top floor of the hotel with a nice view to the West of downtown. Prince pointed out the Starbucks in the lobby and my wife said she was looking forward to going there asap, so he gave her a coupon for a free drink.Our room was spacious with a nice sitting chair and ottoman, comfortable bed, big bathroom, L-shaped desk, and connectors to hook my computer to the TV (which I did to look at some detailed tables for work).The internet costs $13/day (typical business hotel), but it was fast and reliable and we had no trouble hooking up my computer, our phones, and an iPad and a second computer to the same connection.The cleaning staff was excellent. After our first night we had our toiletries strewn all over the counter, and we returned to find wash cloths placed under each collection of things. A small but nice touch.We had a nice late night snack and cocktail at the hotel bar, had no trouble getting our car or a cab from the valet, walked all over downtown Indy indoors through the convention center's tunnel system, and were happily greeted every time we returned to the hotel.I'm shocked to see so many low ratings here. Our experience was very good.My new husband and I stayed here on our honeymoon weekend and had a great experience.  The only reasons I didn't give five stars were the expensive parking and lack of free wi-fi.We checked in after a hectic wedding day and were very tired.  My husband said something about the wedding and we both laughed.  The person asked if we had just gotten married and actually gave us an upgraded corner room when we said yes.The room itself was pleasant.  We had a king-sized bed and a large bathroom.  The armchair and desk chair were both very comfortable.  The only thing that surprised me about the room was the lack of a fan in the bathroom.  We were very comfortable all weekend and slept well with a minimum of noise until morning hours when people were leaving their rooms.The location of this hotel was excellent for going to Lucas Oil Stadium.  We never even set foot outside when we went to the Colts game.  This was much appreciated since it was quite cold that day.  We used the room service for supper that night and everything was delicious and the temperatures were appropriate for both the hot and cold items ordered.We had to leave early on Monday morning to get back to work (4:30 a.m.) and the valet staff was prompt and courteous.  They even had the heater running for us and helped us with our bags at the beginning and end of the trip.  We had a very nice stay and will definitely consider staying here if we need lodging in Indianapolis again.Lobby and meeting space are very nice. Great employees. Easy access over the bridge to the convention center,  Circle center mall,  stadium, Westin, restaurants,  etc.  Never even have to go outside.  The rooms are TIRED. Refrigerator on top of a counter.  Wasted space in bathroom. You'll feel like you were transported to 2001.  Time for an update.After traveling all day and arriving at the hotel @ 3am Judy was extremely helpful in finding a room with a King bed, even though the room style booked was unavailable.  She went out of her way to find me a suitable room.The room was very nice and the bed by far has been the most comfortable that I have experienced in my many years of traveling.  All the staff was courteous and extremely helpful.  The valet parking @$42.00/night was a little steep in my opinion,  you can self park for 27..00/night in the same garage which has an elevator to the hotel.Has a Sbux, Champions Sports Bar & another bar & grille inside the hotel plus the hotel had an enclosed Skywalk to the convention center.We were in town to attend a graduation at the convention center so the Marriott was a perfect location. The skywalk entrance was great since it was 90degrees out. We actually got the room on Priceline for under $100 which was nice considering advertised rate was $189. Valet parking was $42... And self park was full... Which was surprising given the valet said they were only at 10% occupancy. That's a bit outrageous in my opinion... If I were staying more than one night I would have had to find alternate parking. The room was average... Clean... ample towels...cozy bed. The bathroom was a nice size but it had no exhaust fan!! After showering the mirrors were so steamed you couldn't see in them. Ladies... Bring your own hair dryer... The I room dryer feels like someone's hot breath on you, had no real power to it, but for the night I managed. We did call down for toothbrushes realizing we left ours, the staff did quickly have them sent to the room. Valets were very friendly and helpful. Offered directions and review on local attractions. Overall... What I would expect at a Marriott.I wish I could give this hotel a higher rating because it truly was a pleasure to stay here. From the moment I checked in to the moment I stepped in my cab to the airport I was greeted with a smile and help at every moment. The staff here truly was trained right. It seemed whenever I needed something from my hotel room, to extra soap, to getting on wifi, to setting up my conference room, someone was easily found and ready to help me. I do not think I have ever had a better experience at a hotel than I did on this business  trip. I have 0 complaints which is shocking, something usually always happens. While I have no desire to visit Indy again, if I had to go the Marriott Downtown is where I would stay hands down and without a doubt!I stayed here for business at the end of July. I've never stayed at a worse hotel in this price range.The conference rooms are ok, but forget about getting food/drink service unless you want to pay an enormous premium. There is nothing nearby, so if you're staying and working there, be prepared to have every meal at one of the hotel restaurants. Breakfast $18, Lunch $25, Dinner $25+The room I stayed in was, perhaps, the most underwhelming part of my stay. Ice bucket, small flatscreen, insanely uncomfortable king bed, Low-speed, High cost WiFi($16 per day), and it came complete with two clipped toenails in the bathroom doorway that were present when I checked in and present when I checked out seven days later.Do you like to sleep at a temperature of your choosing? There is a temperature control in the room, but I think it's just for show. I set it to 68 degrees, and my watch read 76. I then set it to 65 degrees, and my watch read 76.Pros: plenty of elevators, so the wait was minimal; hotel food was very good (I was here on a corporate event), very quick and gracious staff. Cons: at 10:00 PM, they had their cleaning staff cleaning rooms on my floor: chattering and laughing loudly, vacuuming, and banging into furniture. I had to be THAT GUY and call down to the front desk and complain (I hate being that guy - but I was tired!). Our room was TINY (especially for having to share with someone else). The rooms need serious updating: they only have those worthless hair dryers that are attached to the walls (my coworker and I were kicking ourselves for not bringing our own);  and no ventilation fan inside the bathroom. Both things made getting ready in the morning a little difficult - you're trying to be polite and respectful to your roommate while still prepping for business appearances. The second day once we had a pre-planned routine down it went smoother. However, this hotel accommodates A LOT of corporate meetings and retreats, so these seem like minor discrepancies they might have addressed and fixed. The staff were very friendly and accommodating. However, during a lunch break in-between meetings, once we had left, the staff rearranged the rooms, setup chairs, etc., to prep for the next meeting. In the process, they moved our personal items (purses, messenger bags) without informing us to take them or where they had placed them. While the staff were very quick and executed the transition well, this was something that caused mild panic when we returned and couldn't find our items - a forewarning would have been the better way to go.First let me state the positive things. The staff was very nice, if not exceptional. Frankly that's harder to accomplish than the things that were not great, so they should be commended for that. My wife booked this room for one night downtown for my birthday. We have two little ones so a night away is like a gift from heaven. The primary thing we look forward to is the sleep. I literally haven't slept past 7am in three years, so this was the greatest birthday present ever. Our room, however, was not conducive to this great gift. My belief is that hotels have to do 2 things well to have a satisfied customer, a great sleep and a great shower. The bed was ok, the pillows ok too. However the room lacked one important feature, the ability to leave a fan circulating the block out the constant activity that comes with a large hotel. I don't think I've ever been in a room that has no fan control feature on a thermostat, but we found it. So instead of a glorious sleep, we listened to our neighbors on the floors around us slamming doors, flushing toilets, and copulating. Needless to say, it wasn't the best sleep of my life. I'm sure they save a boatload on electrical costs with this limitation of the fan in rooms. Not sure it's worth the frustration of guests. If you're looking for a room in downtown Indy where you can get sleep, I encourage another location.I avoided posting this until now because I was trying to resolve it directly with Marriott but since this location is a Franchisee and not owned by Marriott they don't seem to care what happens here which is another reason to avoid it at all costs.I stayed at the Marriott Indianapolis Downtown for the 2015 Final Four Tournament weekend.We placed a total of nine Final Four tickets for the Championship session on April 6th into our room safe.  The safe was securely locked with a personal code and we left the hotel to have lunch.When we returned to our room we noticed that the in-room safe was unlocked and all nine tickets were missing!!!  The hotel sent a security officer, named Thomas Niemeier to investigate.  After an investigation, Niemeier abruptly stated that he had checked with all the members of his security and engineering team from the Marriott staff and definitively, no one had gone into the safe.  At this point, we contacted the Indianapolis Police, who sent an officer that same evening (April 5th) at around 7:00 pm to take an incident report.  Subsequently, an investigation was opened. Five days later (well after we left town), on April 10, 2015, the Indianapolis Police Detective contacted me and stated that the Marriott had admitted to the Indianapolis Police that the Marriott staff had indeed OPENED AND EMPTIED THE SAFE CONTENTS! The hotel claimed that they emptied the safe and threw away the tickets because they believed they were tickets from the previous game which was already played (the date for Monday's Championship session was clearly marked on the tickets).  They told the police that this was accidentally done and there was no criminal intent so the police closed the investigation since they admitted to the action.  We are fairly certain that the tickets were taken and quickly sold to someone (the street value was well over $5000) and that they were not discarded as they are claiming.  If you have ever felt secure leaving valuables in your room safe at a hotel... Don't!  At least not at this hotel. They literally came into our room and during our stay and emptied our safe!If the tickets were truly taken by mistake why were they not held by the hotel and when we inquired hours later given back to us?  Instead Niemeier the head of their "security" team lied to our faces and claimed ignorance at the time.The Indianapolis Downtown Marriott showed a total disregard for our property and were deliberately dishonest about their investigation. The act of the Marriott's "security" team in emptying the hotel safe while it was clear that there were occupants in the room, evidenced by our personal belongings, luggage and a credit card security on file with the hotel, is absolutely unbelievable.In order to replace the nine tickets to the Final Four Championship game, we had to pay substantially more money for significantly inferior tickets.  On April 6th, the ticket market for Final Four Championship tickets increased exponentially.  The negligent and criminal actions of the Marriott's employees made our trip to Indianapolis a nightmare. We have contacted Marriott's corporate office who has since denied ownership for the property since this particular Marriott is a franchise, they take no responsibility.  We have contacted Andrew Seal who apparently is the General Manager of the hotel and have received no response.  Marriott referred us to the franchisee.  Letters sent directly to the franchisee have gone unanswered although their insurance company states they are reviewing the matter.  PLEASE DO NOT STAY AT THE MARRIOTT INDIANPOLIS DOWNTOWN UNDER ANY CIRCUMSTANCES.  What happened to us is a disgrace.  I've never had such a horrible experience at a hotel.  They have admitted fault and don't seem to care.  I would love to see them respond to this online as I can't seem to get a response otherwise.May I just say that if I could give this hotel 10 stars, I would!I stayed there during December and the service, from the moment I walked through the doors until the moment I checked out was unparalleled.  A cheerful demeanor and a smile can really make a customer's day...especially when you are exhausted and have been traveling all day!  I also had to call the Marriott rewards customer service department regarding my account . I spoke to an agent named Lisa.  She's FABULOUS and really went above and beyond!   I wish that all hotels no matter how big or small would take that extra bit...to make their customers feel appreciated!Keep up the GREAT work!There was one and only one negative to my stay at the Marriott: the lack of free wi-fi. It's ridiculous in this day and age that despite paying however much it is for the hotel room, I have to fork over an outrageous fee for wi-fi.Otherwise, my stay was as great as it could possibly be. The lady at the front desk was very polite and actually gave me an upgraded room which was incredible. Quite possibly the best hotel room I have ever stayed in, and that's no small statement. The upgraded room had a bar area, large dining room table, big screen HDTVs in both living room and bedroom, and, my favorite, a piano. That was so very cool, I will never forget my stay at the Marriott because of that piano. (I don't play piano, I just thought it was the coolest thing to have a piano in my room.)The Marriott is about a block away from the JW. They're both nice, tho the JW is certainly newer. Personally, I'd be happy with either, so I'd say go by whichever is cheaper/available at the time. (JW requires you to pay for internet as well fyi).The fiancee and I drove to Indy for Thanksgiving and stayed at the Marriott Downtown.  It was our first time staying there.  The hotel was readily accessible by car.  The hotel common areas and guest rooms were modern and clean.The pros:  Great downtown location within walking distance to Lucas Oil Stadium and Bankers Life (unfortunately the Colts and Pacers weren't playing during our visit), and downtown restaurants and bars.  Affordable room with government/military rate.  The rooms had very comfortable beds and fluffy pillows.  Housekeeping staff kept the room clean and stocked with fresh towels.  Starbucks kiosk, which accepted the Starbucks Reward card, in the lobby.  The cons:  Parking in the underground garage was exorbitant at $30/day.  No free in-room internet ($14.95) unless you're Marriott Rewards Gold level or higher.  Starbucks was only open during the morning hours.  All in all, we had a pretty good stay and it was still cheaper for us than flying.  The next time we're in town, the Marriott Downtown will be at the top of the list of places to stay.
review_content_20: So I will preface this review with noting that I booked this hotel through Priceline's Name Your Price option. I bid on a four star hotel in downtown Indianapolis. This was the hotel I was booked in and it is not a four star hotel and I will explain below. I complained to Priceline citing my issues and they punt it back to the hotel who said they wouldn't do anything for us. The staff at the hotel are nice enough. Everyone is pleasant, says hello and smiles. Their uniforms are worn and tattered much like the hotel. First the common areas: The lobby has stains on the floors near the elevator. The carpets are old and dingy. The pool and whirlpool area has so much potential but is also rundown. The pool's gutters were dirty and the pool is metal, not tile, giving a harsh industrial feel. The hot tub was closed during our stay but I wouldn't go near it if you paid me. Parking is astronomical, especially when you can park at a meter and pay from your smartphone ;) Now our room: drapes, dirty and ripped. Walls, dirty & wall paper was beginning to peel, shower head had some green buildup on it - gross- there was no air vent in the bathroom but some odd vent that was rusty next to the shower head. The bathmat was a rolled up piece of plastic that looked like it was about 10 years old. Hair dryer had no power. The fridge was not cold at all and had mold growing in it (very dangerous for anyone but particularly for someone with cystic fibrosis). We did ask for another fridge which was brought up but it never got cold-we had to keep medication on ice for the two nights we were there. There is no free in room wifi or even bottled water. There is a vending machine on every floor but we had to go to three floors before we found one that worked. I think Priceline just looks at a brand name for its star system and not the actual hotel. There is  a newer hotel , the JW Marriott across the street  & I am sure that's got to be a 5 star. We stopped in a couple of other hotels since we'll be back in Indy soon  and the Westin next door and the Hampton  nearby are both much cleaner and you get free wifi in your room!! Imagine that!!! I'll post some pictures of our room & you be the judge. Four stars?!? I think not!! We've stayed in a three star Raddison in Racine, WI every year that is way cleaner and offers more amenities.The staff was amazing.  Katie at the front desk was personable and helpful. She was wonderful, you should hire like 30 more of her.  The Valet staff was great as well.  The not so great was the housekeeping.  The staff was friendly enough, but there was a piece of hairy scotch tape up high on the wall by the bed. It was high--but low enough to catch  my eye.   Could have been there for years for all I know.  Pretty gross and hence subtracting a star.   Aside from that--even at full capacity the hotel was fairly quiet and the shower was good. The beds were comfortable.  It was a positive experience!Upon check-in I was given a suite upgrade, which was nice.The internet did not work during business hours on the only business day of my stay.  I placed a call to the front desk, and I got what I would expect at the Fairfield, "Sir, it is working fine down here.  You will have to call the vendor."Ugg, so I called the vendor who was confused for five minutes, then mentioned they were conducting maintenance.  Call #2 to the front desk, who was not aware of the maintenance, but was now going to allow the engineer to grace me with his over the phone presence.Call #3 and engineer informs me that the maintenance was actually conducted the night before, and probably the access points just needed to be reset.An hour later, and I placed call #4 to the front desk to ask for an ETA.  I was told in an exhausted voice that she had no idea, and I was to be called upon completion.Call never came.  After I attended another business event for three hours, it was finally running.To some this is probably a very whimsical concern.  For a businessman who paid $250 a night, please keep the fancy room and give me the same basic service I can now obtain at almost every McDonalds on the planet.Clean rooms, ok concierge lounge (Gold Elite and higher), and connected to the skywalks that will take you through most of the convention center areas in town.Parking is a tad expensive but you can use the garage and walk down. There is practically no view to be had due to the location of the property, but hey, you're here to sleep as a business traveler, not as a vacationer.Otherwise, it's in a prime location next to a lot of stuff so you can keep yourself well entertained when you're not conferencing or working.I stayed here a few months ago for a work conference, and this place did not disappoint. Everyone was super friendly, and even though the place was packed due to the huge convention across the street, they were always cheerful and willing to help with anything you would need. Several times I asked for directions, and the staff at the front desk were happy to help me. My room had a wall light that made a loud buzzing sound, and when I called to ask for maintenance, they sent someone right away to fix it. I noticed someone else said this place had very thin walls, but I have to disagree. I'm a very light sleeper and thin walls really bother me, but I heard nothing from my neighbors during my stay.The room itself was incredibly comfortable and spacious. My nights here were probably the most restful I've ever had in a hotel - that is one awesome bed. But one downside is that my allergies started going haywire, and after my second night I realized it was because the bedding was made of down feathers. I hadn't seen anywhere anything that said they used down comforters and pillows - if I had, I would have requested an allergy-free room. I had booked the room through the convention people, so I don't know if that was why I hadn't been warned about it. Perhaps if I had booked through Marriott itself, I would've been told. By the time I did realize it, I couldn't move rooms since the place was full, but the front desk staff immediately sent someone up with feather-free pillows and a regular blanket.Only other downside to my stay here was the elevator situation. They had six elevators for 19 floors, which you'd think would be sufficient, except I only ever saw two functioning at any one time. It was always a really long wait for the elevator, no matter when I needed to use it. It was especially bad after the gala, when everyone decided to go back upstairs at the same time. The gala was on the 2nd floor, but the wait was so long that people went down to the first floor so they could hop on the elevator, and by the time it got to the 2nd floor, the elevator was packed and none of us could get on. I waited no less than 20 minutes before getting on one that was going down, just so I could stay in there for when it went back up.Overall I really did enjoy my stay here. It has a fantastic location in downtown Indianapolis - and the connection to the skywalk was a LIFESAVER for this constantly freezing Floridian visiting in January. I loved how I could go across to the convention center (my second home during my trip), and from there go down to the mall, all without ever having to step foot outside. I don't know if I'll ever have a need to come back to Indy, but if I do I will absolutely stay here again (and make sure to request a hypoallergenic room).This was my preferred Indianapolis hotel prior to the JW Marriott's arrival across the street.  This hotel offers excellent rooms/suites, a great concierge lounge, and my favorite Indy hotel pool.  On occasion, I stay at this hotel especially if I need to print documents at their business center.  The JW Marriott does not have a "free" business center.  The JW Marriott has a FedEx office.  I'd rather have complimentary printing service.We stayed here for a recent long weekend (Fri-Sun nights). We arrived on Valentine's Day and my husband had arranged for flowers to be in the room when we arrived. That didn't happen, but the flowers were found and delivered while we were in the bar, along with complimentary wine and chocolate, which was nice.The staff was very helpful and friendly wherever we went. We had a family package which included a free breakfast buffet for 2 adults and one child each morning, and a free pizza dinner one of the nights. They very considerately allowed our teen to eat the breakfast for free also. The beds were very comfortable, as were the pillows (a rare thing in a hotel, IMO!). We were in room 329, which was great for access to the pool and gym, but had a view of a wall, which wasn't very picturesque. The room was fairly quiet, except for the idiots knocking on our door at 1am on Friday, but that could happen anywhere. (We did bring our white noise machine and I'm sure that helped).The only drawbacks were:no free wifi in the rooms (only in the lobby area). Seriously? Even the cheapest motels we've stayed in have had free wifino fan in the bathroomRidiculous daily cost to park (which I suppose is standard in any large city downtown hotel, but still *ouch!*)The pool and hot tub area need major updating. The pool and hot tub looked rusty and worn.The location was good. We were able to walk to most of what we wanted to see (capitol, war memorial, several museums, NCAA Hall). There must have been a couple of big events on Saturday, because the lobby on Sunday morning looked like a convention floor, the line at Starbucks was about 50 people long, and the wait for an elevator was so long we gave up and sought out the stairs. The gym was fine, and not crowded any of the three mornings I used it.We'd defnintely stay here again.Hotel is in a great location. Stayed for a conference, the best part is the sky walk. In the rain and cold weather you don't have to go outside which is a plus. The staff is impressive and extremely helpful. Check was smooth and the hotel made they took care of the marriott rewards members.There was nothing great and nothing terrible about my stay. I got a decent price on priceline and stayed only one night for a wedding at the Columbia Club. They are fairly aggressive about trying to valet your car and giving your luggage to a bell hop. Valet is $35/day, self park is $30/day and on the weekend you can park across the street for $15/day and walk across the skywalk to the hotel. (that garage only takes cash, btw) The skywalk connecting the convention center and many of the hotels makes this hotel convenient for getting around downtown in cold weather. Please note that the skywalk is essentially closed by 10 pm.Check in at this hotel is 4 pm and check-out is 11 am. Because of this we didn't have any chance to use any of the amenities like the pool during our one night stay.Overall nothing here was great and there were a number of negative things. There is no free WiFi in the rooms. The bed was ok with an average collection of pillows. The hairdryer was under powered. They had dispensers of bath products in the shower and the shower had mediocre pressure and temperature. Our closet was large, the bathroom adequate as was the room.I would not go out of my way to stay here again.My experience is limited to an evening social  reception in one of the conference rooms. The staff was AWESOME! The room was nice and spacious, but somewhat what you would expect in a hotel conference room. The food was good; I remembered we had lamb. The salad left a little to be desired, but still good. Overall, good experience here for any conference or reception needs in downtown Indy.As a Marriott Platinum member I can say I have spent many a night in their mainline properties. This is a very solid property in their portfolio. It's centrally located, has a nice underground parking garage, and the rooms are clean and updated. The concierge lounge is very nice, and the fitness center is good. Overall it's a safe bet for the business or casual traveler. The JW is certainly nicer, but for the money this is likely a wiser selection for those on a budget.Rooms are fine, but Thursday night band (crappy cover band) rocked until 10:45 in the cheesy sports bar on the first floor. Wouldn't be so bad except it shook the entire hotel. I was on the 4th floor. Hotel should have more control over that.... It's a hotel first.Awesome place to stay and hangout after a long day!Stayed here for a conference and thought the entire staff is extremely friendly.  Overall the hotel is very nice, has lots of amenities, and extremely convenient to shops, restaurants and activities.The beds are comfortable and the rooms are spacious!  I was a bit dissappointed in the number & location of wall-plugs.  I mean, who doesn't have an available plug next to the bed?  Weird.Also the air conditioner wasn't cooling properly.  I had the temp set to 60, but the room still felt warm. Last, the light in the bathroom was lacking.I would also expect hotels to offer free guest wifi, but this hotel required their guests to buy it.Other than the above mentioned disappointments, I thought the hotel was nice.I stayed at this Marriott for a work related conference. Our conference was hosted in the same hotel too.The rooms are nice and clean and they offer toiletries from Bath and Body works - that I love!The staff is nice and friendly and the location is right in the middle of downtown Indianapolis!During a three-day stay, I had issues with a broken tub stopper, a stopped up toilet, electrical issues with the lighting, and a faulty card reader so half the time, I could not get into my own room.Also, during a three-day stay, housekeeping only came once to clean the room. Front desk personnel seemed very uninterested in the issues mentioned. One female even yawned while I was telling her about being locked out of my room because my key did not work and asking for new keys.As a bonafide Marriott girl due to all the work travel I would say I'm definitely a somewhat expert on Marriott properties overall, so let me cut to the chase.  This is not the brand new Marriott but the "older" one if you want to call it that.  The location cannot be beat.  Is in walking distance to all the shops & restaurants in downtown.  We parked our call via the valet (holy freakin $32/night) and walked the entire stay.  The lobby is very expansive and very nice.  Probably one of the larger Marriott lobbies I have been in.  They have a really nice Starbucks in the lobby too which sure beats that mediocre stuff they provide in the rooms.The rooms are of the more updated Marriotts.  Nice, clean & modern.  Comes with the typical Bath & Body Works Orange Ginger lotion, shampoo and conditioner.I would definitely stay here again but the only 2 "eh" things about me for this location were:A).  The steep valet/overnight parkingB).  The hotel lobby had a somewhat moldy smell.  Kinda like when you accidentally leave a load of laundry in the washer & oh snap 2 days later you remember them........You know you've done that at least once in your life.  Now in all fairness to the hotel the rooms did not have the "funk" AND we caught the whiff of the same "funk" several times while walking downtown.  It's like they're having sewer issues.  We deemed it the smelliest city in the US - however we LOVED Indy and really liked this Marriott.  Next time I come I think I'll try the newer location which is almost literally across the street/highway to this one on Maryland.Stayed here on 02/15/14, got treated like the Priceline customer that I was. Was given a room on the 18th floor. The room was right next to some sort of closet or storage area used by employees. All we heard all night was cabinets being shut and music. Maybe this is their  secret hide away. Parking is outrageous at 35 a night for valet. Was told by valet, that their garage was full, and I had no choice but to valet park. Was told at check in, that we were lucky to still have our room. That the were overbook . I wish I would have looked at some of the reviews, before I picked it.    I see now the area manager does a lot of apologizing....Hello,  fix your problems.This place has razor thin walls and absolutely zero sound insulation from outside.Stayed here for a weekend with the GF for her Indianapolis reunion. We heard our next door neighbors roll in at 3AM and throw an after hours party. It sounded as though they were in the same room as us as we could clearly hear everyone's conversation.Then the next morning a booming rock concert was outside at 7AM for the opening of the Indy Marathon. We couldn't sleep late at night nor early in the morning because the sound insulation of this hotel is absolutely terrible.The pool area and workout room are really nice for an urban hotel though.Beautiful place, outstanding service, great food.  Been here for several meetings and receptions and they have all been top notch. I highly recommend if looking for accommodations in downtown Indy.
review_content_40: Lovely, lovely, lovely.  I've been to three parties and banquets at the Marriott in the past 4 months, and all were very well done.  Service was timely and the food almost hot.  How do you do that with 1400 seated guests?  All events had a warmth and comfortable setting even with large numbers of people.  No complaints.Plus comments:+conveniently located to convention center where conference was held and close to restaurant and shopping opportunities-starbucks in lobby and they did a good job keeping up with the breakfast crowd.Negative comments:-did not appreciate having to pay for Wi-Fi; thought it was pretty cheap in this day and age.-toilet handle broke!  but was fixed the next day.-housekeeping missed one day of service....not usually a big deal but my wastebasket was full!In here for several nights stay via MillionAir fbo. Nice hotel. Good food items in bar. Got in late last night. Great service from all. Valet park was easy....well yeah!! Room on 15th floor and views west to JWMarriott where my pax are staying for convention. My room is nice but lacks elec outlets for all the stuff we pack around which needs charged. Also, no fan-only on the temp control. Had not seen that, and I like the fan-only. Not sure I would stay here again, though there certainly are lesser places to stay. Overall, this is ok.What a sad hotel. As a platinum elite, I always choose a Marriott to stay in when traveling. This hotel, while busy, is extremely tired. First, the shower is completely outdated, and you can hear everything going on around you while in your room.  Last night, I could hear the entire conversation of the person in the room next to me, and every morning someone in my hall left the room at 5:30 AM, and each time the door slammed it woke me up. Room service is an extreme joke. Now, as of January 1, the delivery guy told me, they charge a $10 delivery fee on top of a service fee for each order. So, my nine dollar pizza quickly turned into over $20. Absolutely not worth it. I also ordered buffalo wings, yes I said buffalo wings, but when my food showed up they were actually barbecue wings, and not cooked all the way through. Seriously disappointing, especially when you're hungry. Now, as a traveler, I always use the gym. this gym, while it does have equipment, is also very tired. The treadmill I was on was lopsided, and it has very limited free weights. It is on the inside of the building, so there's no natural light coming in. The check in Clerk, was very pleasant, but sent me to the concierge to get a question answered about a shuttle. It took the clerk 10 minutes to get off the phone to address me, so I went out front to ask. The only redeeming quality of my week, was the doorman. He was very pleasant every morning and very helpful. There is also a Starbucks on site, which is a perk. If I have the chance, I will always stay at the JW Marriott in Indianapolis. This hotel loses my vote after my experience this week.After a three year absence from this particular Marriott, I once again found myself staying here for Gen Con. Unfortunately, the same problems I had before are still here, but made even worse due to the incredibly high price of our stay.I'm still blown away by the "no fans in the bathroom" oversight, and the Double/Double rooms are really tight if you've got four adults with luggage splitting (especially with tiny trash cans). That being said, the room was very clean, but many things in the bathroom need repair (a piece of the shower head had detached from the wall, some of the paneling on the bathroom door had been chipped off or damaged, and both the toilet seat and tub's faucet were on the brink of falling off their respective attachments). To make matters worse, neither the tub nor the sink had cold water the entire stay, and even after notifying the front desk, and supposedly having someone from engineering "fix" the problem, still only hot water remained.Additionally, while I appreciate a thorough cleaning, we had to specially call housekeeping to service our room on one day of our stay as it was almost 3:00 and it hadn't been serviced. Am I nitpicking? Yes, yes I am. Why? I paid $188 plus 17% tax a *night*. As a note to future travelers: Wi-Fi is not included in that rate, and is $12.99 extra a day.That all being said, the staff is still incredibly nice and accommodating, and of course the location is ideal. When it comes to future Gen Cons, would I stay here again? Likely, but outside of a con situation, where I wasn't limited on the number of rooms available in the entirety of Indianapolis, I'd skip it.The location is fantastic among a few other ones in downtown Indianapolis. Friendly staff and clean rooms are all very nice. I didn't mind the $30 parking fee, as it's conveniently located at the heart of downtown. But I am not too sure about the $15/day internet.Was here for business meetings and really enjoyed the facilities.A little dated, but close to events you have a walk way between the hotel and convention center which makes it very nice. Guest services is very helpful and nice. Room was clean, comfy beds.Horrible customer service. I have stayed at cheaper places with better service. Don't dare ask the desk clerk by the name of Prince for any assistant ,He will just make you fell stupid for asking where anything is. For the price internet should be includedStandard Marriott experience.  Great location near Circle Center.Stayed here for 4 days and 3 nights because of a wedding that was there and I would say my stay was pleasant, especially during Fourth of July weekend. There were so many events going on like weddings, pageants, and even a Kappa Alpha Psi 100th year celebration. Right across the street from the convention center downtown it was next to a lot of things.  We were able to go out, find places to eat all within walking distance.The only thing that was disappointing was that there wasn't really many options of food choices within the hotel.  There was Champs Sports Bar that didn't look too exciting so we tried things elsewhere. Since it was such humid weather out there I had such a craving to go swimming and I find out they have an indoor pool! Great! Only problem was it was closed :/ c'mon during the summer?? I did get to use their 24 hour gym which was good- no one was ever in there. The room was nice with a view of the state building and close some museums. More convenient than anything.Great hotel. Well positioned downtown, close to shops, restaurants, & convention center. Very attentive & helpful people. Well appointed rooms. Good view fro 12th floor.  Very nice lobby restaurant. I especially liked the art work. Early Van Gogh sketches of hardworking miners; just beautiful. The conference facilities and service is excellent and very efficient. As always, the wifi is complicated but it worked well. Good string signal even in high floors. I did a webinar from my hotel room with no problems. Excellent.I stayed here with friends the evening of the DCI World Championships this August. We got the room for $150 on Sidestep -- but ended up being closer to $200 after all the taxes/fees/parking for one car at $27/night. It was kind of weird because they wouldn't guarantee us 2 double beds, but ultimately we ended up in a room with 2 double beds, they just wouldn't guarantee it??? Interesting. We tried to check in around 3pm and were told the room hadn't been cleaned yet. The hotel was pretty busy that day and the front desk promised to call when our room was ready for us to check in. So we went to dinner and tooled around Indy for 2 hours...still no phone call. We wandered back to the hotel and inquired about the room. It was ready, but no one had ever called me. Luckily the guy working the front desk was AWESOME and gave us free parking for 1 of our cars in exchange for the slight inconvenience. Awesome service, and the room was great. Perfect for 5 weary travelers after a night of watching drum corps.What room I had was fine for the price but the extra costs and other issues would make me look elsewhere. Problems that lend to star removal for me: Bait and switch on the phantom King Size bed - not even queens? doubles? $10 Internet in the room, $5.35 Internet in the business center - even to print out a boarding pass? Well no... if you are in the know you realize that they will print your boarding passes for you in the lobby for free in the morning... huh? Starbucks in the lobby closes at 8 & the next nearest coffee house is.... the Circle Mall? Especially on my first night the time difference snuck up on me and this seems really shortsighted. The staff was friendly as they told me there were no King or Queen size beds, all of the staff smile and greet you as you pass them in the hall... the door men and bell people were great. BUT.. for what I need from a hotel on a business trip this isn't bliss.This place was a really nice place close to where I was visiting and a preferred hotel by my company.  Being a Hilton man, I reluctantly stayed here; however, I had an excellent stay and would return if I had the chance.Positive: Good customer service, multiple restaurants and bars in the area and a Starbucks that does specials every so often and takes Starbucks cards.  Not mean much to some but try waking up three hours earlier than usual (I'm from Cali) and getting to a client meeting at 9:00 AM trying to look awake.Negatives: Can't think of any,,,I stay at tons of Marriott's for work.This is your typical marriott in every city.Nothing special but will do the job when your in Indy!So the rooms were nice, and the staff we pleasant, and it wasn't too loud at night.And that's where the good parts end... We were there this past weekend when at least 3 events were going on between the stadium and the convention center that weekend. Understandable. But this place is like 20 floors, and are connected to the convention center via a sky-walk. You would think they'd be on top of things. Maybe it was our fault. We called and told them earlier that morning that we would need a late check in, and we'd be there by 6 at the latest. We got there pretty much right at 6 after fighting traffic. When we went to check in, they told us they'd need 15 minutes as they had to check if the room was ready, since there were 4 of us we booked 2 beds and they were going to give us a king with a roll away cot... ummm... no. We booked a room with 2 beds and told you there would be 4. It's not like we were hiding people on the billing.Half an hour went by, and its not like we could leave as we unloaded our car and the valet took it, as he said the self park was all full. Great... *end sarcasm*. So we went back up and a different person told us she'd have to call up and see if it was ready, and that they had our phone number and would call us.15-20 minutes later one of the guys with us went up and told them what was up as our event was supposed to start at 7-7:30 and it was 10 til 7 at this point. I believe he got the first gentleman we talked to and he offered us 2 Starbucks coupons for our trouble... nice gesture, but again, there were 4 of us....Once we finally got to the room, everything was fine (the beds were doubles not queen). We had a fridge, the bathroom was nice and roomy with great counter space. TV was nice, and it was spacious for a room with everything in it. The only other downside is the place price gouges. We looked to book a room 4 days before we actually did, and in that 4 days that we waited the price went up $100!!! not cool Marriott... but it is a nice hotel, there's bars and restaurants within walking distance. If you're a smoker, there's a gas station on block to your right and then make a left and go another block or 2. They do sell cigarettes for $10 a pack at the front desk.I was here for a short stay of one night.  The hotel is attached to the convention center and is very welcome place to hold an event.  The rooms were spacious and clean.  Furniture is well maintained along with a large television and a refrigerator.  The heat didn't work when I first arrived.  A call to front desk and the repair was made by the hotel dude within 15 min.  Bathroom is big with good water pressure and old fashion shaving mirrors that extend from the wall.  Main room is long and closets are plentiful.  The room service is not bad, selection is limited and they charge a lot for a service fee to bring the food.  The staff was helpful on all levels.The sound system in the conference center is weak way below standards.  Something to consider if you want to plan a big event here.  The meeting rooms are nice and big decorated with some class. Overall my stay was enjoyable parking was easy and the price was right.  Impressive lobby and plenty of places to eat nearby.For nearly every downtown wedding I have either attended or been in, bachelorette party, etc. when I don't want to drive home, I stay at the Marriott Downtown.  I have never had a bad experience from the staff at the front desk to the bellboys to the valet, everything is always wonderful.I also had the privilege of being a wedding where the whole thing was done between two banquet rooms.  The food was RIDICULOUSLY wonderful.  The catering manager attended the event and made sure everything was absolutely perfect.  I was blown away by everything in the wedding.  The staff was incredible, polite, and helpful at every turn.  The wedding was wonderful!! I highly recommend if you would like to do a downtown Indy wedding to consider this as an option.  The appetizers during cocktail hour still make my mouth water!!As for the rooms, they are spacious, well laid out and the beds are comfortable.  I have never had a sleepless night in this hotel!  I also love Champions Restaurant located inside the Marriott.  It is one of my favorite pre-Colts game hangouts.  It is also a great place to watch the games if you don't have tickets. They have a huge TV in one of the back rooms and when I've gone there is always plenty of seating.  It does get crowded on occasion, when big conventions are in town, but otherwise, we can usually get seats.  I also know the manager here and he is a great guy!  Tell Greg I said hi if you see him. :)  For my 24th birthday, we used my father in law's Marriott points and were upgraded to the Honeymoon Suite on the 18th floor, overlooking the entire city.  They gave us a welcome package with Starbucks coffee coupons, cookies and other fun treats and upon arriving home from the bars, we were treated to chocolate covered strawberries and a bottle of champagne.  Though I don't remember a LOT of this, I know it happened, b/c I had chocolate stains all over my robe in the morning!  The view from our room was incredible, the suite was fantastic and the staff was so gracious whenever we called for room service. Overall, the best hotel experience in the city.  If you are going to spend $250 a night on a hotel in downtown Indy, spend it here.Rooms:  super comfortable bed, spacious room and their suites make a lovely home away from home for the business traveler on an extended trip.   Food:  both their catering and their room service is top notch.  Fitness Center:  plenty of treadmills and ellipticals.  There are also free weights and some machines, but the free weight area is a bit small - there's little personal space between you and the stranger doing curls next to you.The biggest downside to this hotel is that there is no wifi in the rooms.  Now, I may be spoiled because I live in a wireless house, but there's nothing more stifiling than being chained to a desk via an internet cord.  Sometimes a girl just wants to surf the web sitting on her bed while watching TV.  :-)
review_content_60: I definitely try to get in at this FS Marriott when I come to indianapolis.  I'm definitely not disappointed with my stays here.  Nice big rooms, good concierge lounge, comfy beds...nice gym facilities.Everything is nice and clean - no complaints at all.I stayed here in August 2009 for DCI -- and it proved to be an excellent hotel choice! Its location is hard to beat, right on Maryland for proximity to restaurants, bars and the mall, and about a 15 minute walk to Lucas Oil Stadium for the main event along Capitol.Add unfailingly friendly and polite staff, and comfortable, quiet guest rooms, this was an excellent combination!The only slight let-down is some of the issues relating to their food service in the main restaurant (Circle City), particularly at breakfast. Being made to wait 20 minutes for breakfast on a Saturday morning, then having to remind the host that I was on the waitlist, then getting into the restaurant and finding a *ton* of tables empty is not a good customer experience. Also, on a different morning, multiple servers tried to claim my table, and one of said servers became slightly snippy with me over it -- not my problem if you can't organize yourselves properly, I'm afraid.For food at other times, Champions (the in-house sports bar) is a much stronger bet (and will receive its own review).Pricewise: It's a Marriott, it's going to be slightly spendy. The $12 for 24hrs Internet is good and reliable, and also includes free local and national calls -- so that strikes me as a fair extra. For the location and (general) standard of service, paying $180/night for a dual occupancy room is not unreasonable, so it's a straight 4* review. Does what it claims to do, and does it well -- but no real spark to get that last star.The location is fantastic, it is located very close to shopping center and nice restaurants. The lobby is very impressive, we stayed during Christmas holidays and everything looked festive and beautiful. The rooms are nice and clean, good size. So why 3* you ask? Well, for me the hotel must provide everything that's needed to get a good night sleep and at this Marriott I did not, it was very noisy. Not only because there was a party in one of the rooms on our floor, with people being very loud well past midnight but even later in the night I kept waking up due to various noises...I may give this place another chance in the future, not sure yet.Great service and friendly staff! You can easily access many attractions with in walking distance including the conference center.  Easily able to access other Marriott hotels.I stayed at the Marriott for one night when my college group was having a formal function there.  I have a friend who works there and she hooked us up with a great rate, $100 a night!  The room was clean and updated, the abthroom was very roomy and nice,  the location is GREAT if you are going to be downtown, and the service is friendly and helpful.  There was a bit of confusion about my room rate at check in but the staff was quick to assure me they would straighten it out without any inconveinece on my part, and so it was done.  The event I attended there was also ran smoothly by the Mariott event coordinators, the food was really good for banquet food.  Secondhand, my friends who planned the event said they were easy to get a hold of, flexible, and worked within our budget.We stayed here for New Years Eve, not bad, great location, got a good deal on Priceline, was a nice room, I think they recently remodeled them, it was $128 with tax for 1 night but parking is WAY overpriced $28 overnight parking. Also take your own pillow, theirs are the kind that flatten out when you lay your head on them, hardly slept cause of the terrible pillows.Great property!  If you are in town for business a few days, you are in walking distance to just about anything you would need food, entertainment, shopping and more. The concierge lounge is one of the best I have encountered in a very long timeSelected this hotel for its great location in downtown Indianapolis. It is right across the street from the IN Government Center and also attached to the Convention Center and the downtown Skywalk system. I visited in January and it was freezing cold and snowing outside so it was perfect to take the skywalk to the mall for meals and to take the skywalk to meetings across the street. I was on the 19th floor and had a great view of the Capitol building. My room was updated and very clean. I enjoyed the hospitality in the Concierge Lounge for both breakfast and appetizers in the evening. Would definitely stay here again.Excellent staff and very clean. Walls are just too thin...just saying.Stayed here in January for 3 nights and was quite impressed. We had a Management Institute and basically had the entire hotel booked for our organization, got an awesome rate of about $100/night. The people behind the front desk were extremely patient, courteous, and helpful in checking everyone in and out. The waitstaff = superb. Can't say I enjoy eating rubber chicken, but food was not too bad for one of these events. There is only wi-fi in the lobby, otherwise you have to pay for internet. If you are thirsty, there is iced, flavored water in the lobby (strawberry or lemon) that's quite refreshing, but it's not refilled as often as people would like. I was sick during this trip and was constantly drinking water..didn't buy water at the airport and thought I'd be able to get it at a convenient store by the hotel but there wasn't one! So I gave in and bought Smartwater @ $3/bottle in the place by the front desk. This hotel is in a convenient location - close to the mall, restaurants, and places to sight-see! Also loved the skywalk that connects to the mall, and being able to avoid the cold as much as possible.It's a pretty standard Marriott, nothing special.  There's a Starbucks in the lobby but they close super early.  The best thing it has going for it is that it's around the corner from Cafe Patachou!This was a very nice Marriott with a great location in the heart of downtown Indy. All of the great restaurants are just a few minutes walking distance and the staff were all very polite.  My kids and I enjoyed the indoor pool.  We ate at the restaurant downstairs for breakfast and it was pleasant although we seemed to wait forever for my son's pancakes.  I would stay here again without a doubt.The sky bridge to the Convention Center is a huge bonus. Friendly staff.  Gym and pool are clean and well mantained. Comfortable beds. Cheaper than the JW. Was a little loud on the street and could hear it from my 7th floor street facing room but it was Labor Day Weekend.Very nice hotel and great location. The price was excellent with the government discount.If you are having a convention in Indianapolis, this is the place. Let's be honest, you don't expect much from the food or service at these kind of events. Not when they are trying to feed and take care of 400+ people. The service was AMAZING. The staff was friendly and very accommodating. You don't like Italian dressing? No problem. Let me get you something else.You  have a gluten allergy? No problem. Let me see what the chef can put together for you.Truly the best service I have had in this type of setting.  The food was just okay, but the desert was fantastic. I can only imagine what they would be like when not being cranked out.The guys working the lobby are fast and attentive. When we were getting ready to leave, we had someone to help us right away. He grabbed our bags, flew out the door, and had a cab for us before we even finished getting our coats on. Everything else was good. The bar has a decent selection of wine, but closes kind of early for being a weekend. We were there at midnight and got told it was last call. Unfortunate, because we probably would have spent a fair amount. The starbucks in the lobby is nice, but expensive. Room service is fine, but super expensive and you don't get much for your money. $13 for a sandwich and they don't even give you mustard? Not cool.The lobby has free wi-fi, but the internet in the room is expensive and wired. Not good for college age women away at a convention who need to get homework done.The room itself was fine. Plenty of counter space in the bathroom for two women, but the shower head is far too short for my 6 foot self. But this is something I deal with most places I go. The bed was comfy and warm. The walls our paper thin. I first realized this getting ready in the bathroom in the morning when I could hear my neighbors getting ready in theirs. And it was reaffirmed at 2:30am when my roommate and I were laughing hysterically and they were banging on the wall. Oops.Overall excellent and I would definitely go back again. Next time, for leisure so I can see the city and enjoy something beside the lobby. I could see the football stadium from my window, and it was really making me want to come back for a game.As a regular Marriott person this one was very nice. The rooms were a good size and the bed, tv, etc..all top shelf. Had breakfast at the Circle City Grille every morning food was very good and staff friendly. Champions Bar and Grille was excellent for watching the NCAA basketball games. Excellent down town location.hmmmmm. I stayed here last weekend for a conference and pretty much got ripped off. between the hotel and the association trying to make money, the conference rate was 192 a night! ridiculous when another friend booked a room not at the conference rate and got it for 160. i did appreciate that everyone working there was really friendly and helpful. but things i didn't like include the starbucks closing at 4, paying for internet (which i didn't do), the mediocre food at the resto that wasn't open very often...Real nice Marriott in downtown Indy...close to the convention center, state house, eateries and venues.Valet guys are very attentive- they look like they are trying out for the Olympic track team. However, the $30 per night to park my rental car is a tad too steep. There are plenty of concierge guys floating around when you enter the hotel and the front desk staff is very professional. I am a Platinum Elite Marriott member and they could not get me onto the concierge level (bummer- considering I spent 140 nights with Marriott in 2010). I did get the usual access to the concierge lounge, which is on the 18th floor, plenty big, attentively staffed and with the usual food/ drink.The room is typical Marriott fare- comfy bed, screen TV, desk and clean bathroom...although the walls are a little thin and you can hear those around you. Good selection of TV channels.Room service was expensive....8oz. filet, slice of pie and 2 diet cokes= $58. Assume the position and smile while enjoying your steak. There are 2 restaurants in the lobby area, 1 of which is a sports bar. The cajun pasta in the sports bar is a good choice. If the NHL is your gig, this sports bar is no good- they do not have the NHL package, nor do they have a dish to reach the local broadcasts of games. Boo. there is a Starbucks in the lobby, which I know many folks need like crack.Overall, pretty good Marriott property. Probably a little pricey for most folks. When visiting Indy next time around, I will be back...maybe self park, steer clear of the room service and find a local watering hole with the NHL package.I've stayed here twice. Both times I was in town for GenCon.Staff is very helpful and easy to deal with. Not once in dealing with any employee in any area of the hotel did I hear any attitude. Staff presented themselves as courteous and willing to do what it took to help you.Baggage service is great. I've tipped them, but even so, they didn't hang around after handling bags expecting to be tipped.The breakfast buffet, while pricey, is quite good. I'm a big fan of the omelettes made to order. For those in a bit of a hurry, the Starbucks in the main lobby is another good place to stop for a quick caffeine & sugar fix.Location to the convention center was key for me. Having it attached via hamster tube was quite nice.Room was clean, spacious, well taken care of when I was out during the day. In-room fridge was great for storing leftovers and for keeping my growler-o'-beer cold. Bed was relatively comfy.I'd stay there again.STAY AWAY.I ordered room service breakfast here and it was super-late, super-soggy and super-salty. And when I brought it up to the front desk, they didn't offer to provide a remedy. This on a room that costs $300+ a night! Save your money and go to an economy hotel instead.
review_content_80: I stayed here while on a business trip.  Because I didn't actually pay for it..I'll try to be as fair as possible.I know this happens all the time, but I booked a King room, and was given 2 double beds.  I stayed here for 5 nights and that was pretty much the only thing I wanted..a big bed.  No go on that one.  Internet.  $10 a DAY???  Come on, really?  I'm pretty sure my boss payed upwards of $150 a night for me to stay here..and we're charged for internet access? (It's free in the lobby)  To make matters worse, it was OUT (being "upgraded") for the entire time I was there.  When I went downstairs to check-out, I was surprised that the charge was on my room bill.  I told the lady "Uh-uh..no internets were had in my room"  I tried all three restaurant options in this hotel:1) Champions - Sports bar with tons of flat screens.  Good beer selection, bar food menu..kinda like a Friday's on crack.2) Circle City Bar & Grill - No.  Overpriced, and the food there just sucked.  I mean it sucked bad.  Good thing I got to expense everything.3) Starbucks - Nice lady made my coffee every morning.  There isn't really much else to say..it was average.  If the price was right, I would stay here again, but definitely don't expect anything extravagant.Stayed here a couple of weekends ago for a Bachelorette party. Staff was friendly, room was nice and comfortable. Not sure about the price since I didn't pay, but I'd definitely recommend this joint.Overall, I was very happy with my stay.  Both the room and the lobby were very nice.  The bed was super comfortable with fluffy feather pillows.My only complaints were that the hotel charged $10/day for internet (yet it was free for wireless in the lobby) and there was no fridge/mini-bar.Nice hotel. Can be a bit spendy. But, the rooms are great, there are multiple good restaurants on site, and a Starbucks.

review_content: I highly recommend this hotel to anyone staying in Indy. My stay at the Alexander was for one night while interviewing with a company in Indy. Great hotel in all respects. Location, snacks, ambiance, cleanliness, noise level, amenities, professionalism of the staff. I was offered a complimentary free breakfast (normally ~$17-$18) but had to skip it. The snacks in my room were awesome. There were Indiana-made pretzels, potato chips, and a couple types of chocolate candy. Non-Indiana (as far as I know) snacks were Jelly Belly jelly beans, a few types of trail mix, pistachios, and maybe something I'm not remembering. There was a Keurig and k-cups in the room also. The bed was very comfortable. There were reading lights built into the headboard! The only complaint I can think of is that one of the lightbulbs in my room was burnt out.**Great** check in experience with Drew (Andrew) who went over & above to help out with something I'd forgotten). It's those moments that make for great customer service with me. I stay often in Indy, and this hotel is conveniently located for me. That said, there are clearly issues with housekeeping. Randomly, no soap or some such other supply not being restocked. Other than that, a downside could be a lack of a gym, but there's a brand new YMCA across the street. Overall, I'm satisfied and the interactions I have with staff in general keep me coming back. Breakfast is served by cheerful, genuinely nice people.Confession: I am obsessed with cool hotels. And The Alexander definitely falls in that "hip and cool" category.This boutique hotel is chic, contemporary, and art-centric with a European flair in the heart of the Wholesale District. It's just a few blocks from Lucas Oil Stadium, the Convention Center, and Monument Circle. The Alexander occupies a spot on the CityWay complex, which will soon be home to the largest and finest YMCA in the country. The beloved Cerulean and Platt 99 can be found here, and let me tell you, it is worth a trip just to see Jorge Pardo's incredible handmade lamps. Fun facts:-11,000 square feet of meeting space -209 rooms-six floors-the only hotel in North America curated by an accredited museum of art, the Indianapolis Museum of Art-unique artwork: take note of "Anthem," with birds made of local vinyl records; the Madame CJ Walker work made out of combs, paying homage to her success in the hair care business; the word structure located by the elevators (you'll know what I mean when you see it)-outdoor plaza and lawn space for weddings and other events-Market Table exhibition-style kitchen serves breakfast and lunch-no two rooms have the same set of paintings above the beds-complimentary wi-fi throughout property-your room awakens/sleeps with your key -- eco-friendly! Hence, why it's silver LEED certified.-there's a small health club, but no pool...but really, do you need that when a state-of-the-art YMCA is across the street?As a full disclaimer, I merely toured the hotel and did not stay here. However, I can tell it would be an exquisite experience.Beautiful art everywhere you look, friendly staff, an environmentally friendly building and (most important) clean rooms with comfy beds -- The Alexander was outstanding.  I had heard wonderful things about The Alexander, and those expectations lived up to reality. So to start with: Parking.
