There is a public parking garage right next to the hotel if you don't want to splurge for valet. Parking overnight cost me $20, and if you park on third floor, you can take the pedway directly into the hotel. One more tip: Even though the spaces are numbered, you can park anywhere, per the hotel staff. Speaking of, the hotel staff seemed friendly and eager to help any time I encountered a staff person, whether it was at the front desk or at the front door. The front desk clerk also told me that Platt 99 in the hotel serves complimentary truffle popcorn, which I'll have to try on my next visit. I also spied the infused water bar near the front desk. And then once I got to my room, I found it to be beautifully decorated with art hung above the bed and a modern bathroom.Considering the hotel puts a focus on sustainability, it was great to see how you have to use a room key to turn on the lights in the room -- meaning that you will likely not leave the room with the lights still on. The wifi is free and easily accessible. My TV worked great, and it was easy to navigate through the channels.And as I mentioned, the bed was heavenly. It was one of the most comfortable hotel beds I've slept in. I sometimes have trouble going to sleep in hotels, and I had no problem with that here. The Alexander is a short five-minute or so Uber ride from downtown Indy. Really, this hotel replaced the generic that is often found in hotels and put something unique, sometimes avant-garde and always worth a peek in its place.I can't wait to go back!So im pretty pissed, my first time here and within two hours I was down $500 due to a mishap in the kitchen and someone swipe crazy with my debit card number. The superviser offered me free breakfast for the two nights i was gonna be here, i told her that was hardly any kind of courtesy for my $500 wait for my bank to release my funds. Boo!I came to Indiana for an incentive trip through my work, and we were booked to stay here at this hotel. As we pulled up to the hotel in our limo, we were greeted by two younger lads, and directed to the front desk to check in. Our check in was quick and painless. The gentleman at the desk was also really friendly and welcoming. He gave us our room keys and directed us promptly. Once we got into our room, we were amazed at how nice it was! The room was decorated tastefully with modern art, and had a nice king sized bed. The shower was clean and tidy ready for use, and we had a nice view of the bar in the hotel and some of Indianapolis. It was all very nice. We were never bothered by room service, and when we would go out on or adventures throughtout Indiana, the room service left our rooms clean again, and none of our stuff went missing. The front hall of the hotel was also very well decorated with awesome modern art. Some of which I posted pictures of.Overall; my experience here was comfortable and fun! The location was also near the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, downtown Indianapolis, and other fine dining. It is also not too far from the airport! A very nice place to stay!They turned me away.  I had a room booked and they bumped me out to accommodate a Taylor Swift fan.But everyone knows that Taylor Swift fans are more important than educators.The best hotel I've ever stayed at! I love the Alexander hotel, they take an unconventional approach to hospitality. From their intense focus on art and upscale decor to the individualized attention provided to each guest. Reasonably priced and in the heart of downtown, what's not to love? Their bar, Plat 99 is modern and inventive with unique drinks you won't find anywhere else with bartenders who are knowledgable and engaging. My recommendation? Order the Indy love drink with basil and cucumber, a refreshing drink no matter the season. Now, onto the actual rooms. The rooms have a laminate flooring that resembles dark hardwood floors with minimal carpeting that is up to date and pairs well with the art theme you will see throughout the hotel. The rooms have clean lines with dark wood finishes and large floor to ceiling windows with view of the city skyline. The linens feel luxurious and have some weight to them. Nothing about the hotel feels cheap or tired, it is extremely clean and transparent. It is connected to Cerulean, a highly recommended restaurant who takes a creative and cultivated approach to cooking. Overall, if you find yourself traveling in Indy and are in search for an experience rather than just a place to sleep, give The Alexander a try, you won't be disappointed.I should start this out by saying i've been here 3-4 times to work, but it has always been extremely nice!  Always very clean and updated, even in the "behind the scenes" areas that people normally don't see.  I've been able to sample the food they serve for parties and it is awesome.  I love the hotel decor!I stayed here for a business trip recently.  I absolutely loved the art installations throughout the lobby/elevators. My room was spacious, bright and seemed like it recently updated. The bathrooms were well lit so I didn't have to struggle to do my makeup (always a plus). One of the blonde front desk agents had a pissy attitude, but otherwise staff members were nice and accommodating. Would definitely stay again next time I'm in Indy.I was in town for the weekend.  The Alexander was at the top of my list of places to stay since it was the newest property in downtown Indy and its price was comparable, if not cheaper, than the other downtown hotels during the time of my intended visit.  With its boutique feel and bright, airy, quirky interior replete with modern artwork displayed all around the common areas, everything about the Alexander screams hip, modern, and someplace other than Indianapolis.  Adding to the Alexander's appeal is its outstanding cocktail lounge, Plat 99, which is just off the front desk and easily in the discussion as Indianapolis' best place for craft cocktails and Cerulean, an excellent restaurant on street-level.  Having driven to Indianapolis, I left my car with valet ($29/day), which while not cheap was less expensive than other's self-park prices and seemingly more convenient than self-parking since the garage was adjacent to the hotel, not underground and  accessible by elevator.  Friendly valet and front desk staff greeted me immediately and were efficient in their duties during both my arrival and departure.  My room was clean with a modern, yet minimalist design.  The bed was comfortable giving good back support.  The shower was unique to most hotels I've stayed with its overhead showerhead. Although my stay was a brief one, the Alexander impressed me greatly.  It may not be for everyone, since its location isn't as convenient to Lucas Oil Stadium and the Convention Center as other downtown hotels, but it's still within walking distance.  For Indianapolis, it's definitely a 5-star hotel.  The Alexander is definitely a place I'd stay again.Very clean, modern, beautiful artsy space. Garage next door was convenient. Walls were thin though as I could hear my neighbors and woke up every time they flushed their toilet...I stayed at the Alexander hotel for my wedding night this past weekend. My husband and I were completely floored by the installed art throughout the space and the impeccable service. The hotel itself is a modern work of art, with feng-shui placed glass walls and views of the city. We also got a chance to peek into the Plat 99 bar during the daytime when it was not open for business and took a look through their extensive bourbon and Indiana draft pull selection. It looks like they put on interactive "pour and play" cocktail competitions for guests periodically so it's worth checking out for guests and locals. We had a king suite with a HUGE bathroom, complete with a glass door shower, 2 sinks, and a large bathtub. And get this, they have a TV built into the mirror! Crazy fancy. They also carry Gilchrist & Soames bath products in the bathroom stock. All rooms appear to come handy with a Keurig (free coffee and tea) and local snack foods (for a fee). The bed was luxurious and came with ample bed side lighting dimmers. We also made use of the mini-fridge to keep our celebratory sparkling wine chilled. We also received a 2-fer free breakfast the following morning at their in-house restaurant, Market Table. Beautiful warm space with modern, almost molecule-featured light art. They also offered a gelato bar with their breakfast (need I say more).This place appears to appeal to a slightly younger demographic but I saw all ages staying at the property checking in and out the following morning. Central location to the fieldhouse and stadium for games and to downtown spots. Highly recommend to my style savvy traveling buddies out there in Yelpland.This was a wonderful experience. The hotel screams modern, chic, sleek and comfortable in every single way. From the auto-shut down of heat and electrical when you leave the room (which reboots once you put your key in as you walk in) to the living and breathing art museum (is this a hotel or an art museum?) and the cute little hipster touches on even the "do not disturb signs," there are little surprises in every corner.The bed was super comfortable. I can just melt into a nice slumber thinking about it. Shower pressure was fantastic and the stay was pretty much perfect. Check out is 11am which is kind of early, but the staff extended is to 12pm when I called which was nice.It's a bit of a pricey stay and I think there could be more value delivered for the per night price paid (thus the 4 stars), but if you're comfortable with it; it's definitely one of the better hotels I've stayed in.What can if can i find nice to say about this hotel...... hmmmm well... the artwork is cool.  other than that.  I have to be honest, it was probably the worst hotel experience from a customer service perspective I have had in many years.  I travel frequently  as many as 150 nights a year in the past, and have stayed in all kinds of hotels from 1 start to 5 star in my travels.  This hotel rates at the bottom.  There are zero amenities for a business traveler.    MY stay started with a poor check in experience, with a front desk person who was snarky at best and at worst sarcastic.  our room was not ready, and we were told that they would call when it was, ..... they never called.        My breakfast experience was horrible as the wait staff totally forgot I was there, the food was cold, and I never did get a bill, finally tossing 20 dollar bill to the bus boy after a 15 minute wait for a server that never came back to my table.    The bar only sells bottles of soda?  yet they can make a mixed drink with soda,  but have no coke or diet coke.    The onsite mini store was the smallest I have ever seen with little to nothing that the business traveler would want or need.   Every thing else was overpriced, from the $4.00 pretzels in the room to the $19  double vodka I had in the bar.       I passed by the front desk multiple times, as it is right by the elevators, often the staff were leaning on the glass  or looking at their phones and seldom acknowledged me as I walked by.  If you are looking for a decently priced hotel that seems to care little if anything about you as a customer, then this is the place for you.The Alexander is a newly constructed hotel in downtown Indy. The building was originally designed to be a residential, and this reflects in the cozy structure of the hotel. Within days, you'll start referring to The Alexander as "Home" :)The quirks that make The Alexander a unique, lush, and indulgent experience:- modern and cheerful art in the lobby, hallways, and rooms- spend some time relaxing in the common area by the lobby-- it reminds me of a spacious modern ski log cabin... something about the wood decor and homey living room vibe, against the glass fixtures and roomy interior- each room's mini-bar comes stocked with local Indy popcorns and snack mixes. Irresistible.- relaxed complementary breakfasts at The Market Table, where you get the full restaurant dining experience with skilled chefs who can custom-make any egg dish your heart desires- the Platt 99 bar has a mean cocktail menu with complementary and addictive truffle popcorn- gumdrops, spa water, and coffee in the lobbyHighly recommend this swamky hotel for a pleasure tripNote that they do sell out.... so make friends with the receptionist, and book in advance!This place is absolutely gorgeous, on Pennsylvania street by bankers life field house. I went here for my 21st birthday. I really enjoyed the vibe of this place ! The lantern lights really brings a uniqueness to this bar, that no others bars have. I have to admit the drink selection is not the best. I would rather them have some more girly drinks rather than manly drinks. The bartender did their best & came up with wonderful drinks for me. I appreciated the service very much ! Definitely would go back (:Was really excited to stay here for a wedding in September, but unfortunately the staff was less than helpful or friendly the entire time. We were carrying bags and a wedding gown that was heavy and awkward as we were looking for our room. We had never been there before and it's easy to get turned around. Not only did the front desk employee laugh when we went to the elevator (apparently it was the wrong elevator but instead of showing us where the right elevator was he decided to laugh at us), but he also simply pointed a general direction for us to go. Would have been wonderful to have someone walk us to the correct elevator as we were weighed down with belongings and unfamiliar with the hotel. The room was great! Very clean and spacious. The balcony view was beautiful, looking out to Lucas Oil. Everything seemed to be going well after the first mishap, but the night of the wedding a guest had the brides wedding gift delivered to her room. It was never delivered there and they still haven't given her the gift. She has called numerous times and tried to track down the package, but it's been a month and no one has been able to send it to her. A little guest service goes a long way. The hotel was immaculate but that can all go down hill if you don't treat guests correctly or if you are dishonest.Our stay was short and sweet. We needed one night as a stopover to Louisville. I was traveling with my kids (8 and 10). The kids liked the Modern esthetics, the rooms were a generous size as well as the bathrooms. My husband wished for more "hooks" in the bathroom. It's really the simple things, robes and slippers, safe was in a drawer. I appreciate that the creamer fir the coffee was liquid and not powder. We'll definitely be back to take more advantage of other amenities, like the lobby bar.I'm writing this as I sit in the reading chair in our room. I loved our stay at this hotel! The art installations throughout the hotel are beautiful, the staff is extremely friendly and accommodating and the rooms were modern, clean and definitely cozy. I came here with my two kids and as soon as they saw us at check in they offered a crib right away and had it sent within minutes of us entering the room. I also asked about using a microwave to warm up my daughter's milk and they actually brought a microwave to my room. With Yolk being just downstairs, I really don't know what else to ask for.I definitely appreciated the hospitality and the courtesy we received during our stay. It was my first impression and stay in Indianapolis and it was certainly a good one.
review_content_20: This is the most solid five star review I have ever written. In fact, if it were a percentage it would be 110% out of 100. After a long hard six months working for the Reds, and throwing a gigantic Halloween event, the hunny and I finally had a break at the same time and decided to take a long weekend to celebrate our nine year anniversary. Totally last minute, we jumped on Yelp, and booked through expedia to get an almost 50% discount! I had no idea which hotel to pick, and we were SO over the top ecstatic that The Alexander was the one we landed on. If you know me, you know my style is uber modern. I am not a Bed and Breakfast kind of gal. I like luxury, clean lines, and stay away from knick nacks galore (creepy and they stress me out). This hotel was everything I hoped it would be. My favorite part was the fact that the hotel is filled with tons of incredible, thought provoking art installations. They spent $2 million and commissioned the Indianapolis Museum of Art to turn this hotel into something much more than that. Every time we turned a corner we were in awe! Now onto the room. Oh. my. gawd. THE ROOM! Our bed was giant and plush. Originally we had planned to do an afternoon bar crawl, we were so thrilled with the space, we got in our pjs, and just hung out for a while. It was probably the most relaxed I have been in years. The shower was giant and had a waterfall shower head. The space in general was just soothing, clean and comfortable, just the way a hotel room should be. One other plus? The had some best of Indy mags in the room that was used with Yelp to bookmark some brunch and dinner spots. Loved that! And almost everything was within walking distance, this hotel could not be in a better location.We took naps, we watched tv, we relaxed, and had an incredible anniversary! Thank you so much for your hospitality, and for providing an oasis for those who want to escape the everyday stresses. If you are reading this and needing to make a decision on where to stay, stop looking, this is your place! Worth every penny, and we will most certainly be back!Want to love this place, but they're challenging me. Checked into an upper floor room yesterday to discover that someone else's key card was laying in the room, along with some of their trash. Glasses in the bathroom were dirty, some of the mini-bar snacks were missing, and used soap and shampoo were in the shower.Housekeeping responded promptly and made things right, but misses like this are tiresome and make you wonder how well anything is being cleaned.Pretty pretty! Indy has a fair number of solid hotels, many of which seem to book up quickly (and for a pretty penny) when conventions come to town. Thus, I'm always game to try out a new nightly abode in the circle city. The Alexander is definitely one of my faves! The Good:-Art abound! Amazing modern art installations and features throughout the hotel. -Modern rooms with extra comfy beds with reading lights-Large glass showers and nicely sized bathrooms-Lots of closet and dresser space, especially int he extended stay rooms-Kitchenette with coffee maker and bottled water (extended stay wing)-Solid, free Wi-Fi throughout-Friendly employees-Decent workout area with a handful of machines, weights and space to get your sweat on (even TVs on the cardio machines!) -Infused ice water and coffee near check in (melon water FTW)The Meh:-I found the entrance confusing (have to walk up or take the elevator up to check-in) - they could probably use more signage-No mini bar for snacking (FYI - the workout room has fresh fruit) -I called for a taxi the day prior and the front desk agent said it was taken care of, no problem. When I arrived downstairs at the entrance, the bell lady/host called upstairs to confirm and I had to wait for a bit for my taxi. She ended up hailing me one to the airport. Not sure if that was a hotel issues or a taxi issue...I hope next time I'll have a bit more time to enjoy the beautiful art and amenities at The Alexander.Beautiful hotel.  Interesting and inspiring art surrounds the visitor. Clean modern decor. Curteous and professional staff. Rooms are spaceous and offer scenic views of downtown Indy. Extreamly clean with very comfortable pillow top matresses and down pillows.This is a relatively new hotel in Indianapolis. I stayed there about a week ago for a conference and the hotel was simply wonderful. The hotel is clean and orderly. The staff was super friendly during the entire visit. There's a lot of great artwork throughout the hotel and even in the parking garage. I ate several meals at the hotel and each one was delicious. If you're looking for a very nice hotel to enjoy while you're staying in Indianapolis The Alexander is definitely at the top of my list.Ate and drank on the patio bar. Edamame, SMORES! shrimp wraps, cheese boards. All were delicious. Service was great. Waitress forgot a food order and gave it complimentary. Margaritas were perfectHubs and I stayed at The Alexander while in Indy for a conference. I had read a great deal about how artsy it was, and how it was just beautiful, but I don't think I really 'got it" until I arrived. We were greeted by some pleasant fellas who were genuine in their hospitality. We were led up the stairs to check-in to the hotel. The front desk staff were pleasant, and the process for check-in was easy. Our room was awesome, very posh and modern. The a/c worked, which is always a plus, and the bed was amazingly comfortable. Our time spent in the conference area was also nice, the hotel put on a great nosh spread for us, and were always very friendly. The staff also helped recommend places of interest, and called a taxi when we needed one. Mentioned most in the reviews, and should not be overlooked, is the art. The place could double as a modern art gallery. Everywhere you turn is another great piece, worthy of a stop just to admire it. I really loved that part of the hotel more than anything!Me, my boyfriend, and two our our friends stayed here for a night while visiting Indy for the Kenny Chesney concert.  First of all, the customer service at the front desk is wonderful.  We arrived at 3:10 and our room wasn't quite ready.  Since they guarantee that your room will be ready by 3:00, all 4 of us were given a comped drink and appetizer at Plat 99 (check out my review for that place!) to use while we waited.  Once we got into our room, we were elated with the set up!  We had a 2 bedroom/2 bath suite for the night and it was absolutely gorgeous!  It was modern and sleek with a TV in both bedrooms as well as the common area and the balcony provided beautiful views of the city and the stadium.  The beds were the most comfortable I've ever slept in at a hotel and the robes provided in the closet were lovely and soft.  All in all, I will absolutely be back and honestly, I'm not sure I'll stay anywhere else in the city!Love this hotel.  It is beautiful and clean and the staff is incredibly nice.  They are truly pet friendly and even have goody bags for your dogs.  Can't wait till we are back in Indianapolis again so we can stay here again.We love the Alexander and have stayed here 2 times in the last few months.  It's a very hip and comfortable hotel with great facilities and a nice staff.Stayed here before. The staff is still very nice and professional. However, some decisions seem to be made based on profit instead of customer satisfaction and common sense. Some requests seemed to take forever to be completed. Maid service was a little inconsistent. New softer towels should be ordered soon. Would I stay here again, yes.An excellent hotel, certainly stylish. Not cheap yet a good value for the money. Love the art everywhere, from lobby to halls to rooms. Staff is helpful and friendly. Best hotel shower I've taken with water faucet on ceiling and well lit shower (something most hotel showers/baths don't have is good lighting). Good bed and pillows. Convenient plug-ins around room. Plenty of outdoor space in restaurant and bar. Free and good wi-fi signal everywhere. I'd stay here again and will look for other Dolce brand hotels when traveling. Their slogan matches the experience: "Hotel Reinterpreted."Nice hotel with a very modern and urban feel to it.  Definitely a different feel than other downtown Indianapolis hotels. The location is great if you are attending a downtown event and the staff is helpful and friendly.There are 60 works of art on display in the hotel, the ones that I saw were interesting.  They are spread out literally all over the hotel so you'd have to spend quite some time here to see them all.Room rates were very reasonable and valet parking was $29 per night.I stayed at the Alexander for a interview I had in town. Honestly this establishment deserves five stars if it were not for the poor housekeeping. I am very lenient and understanding, but there were many mistakes. Upon entering my room, I found a broken off ladle to the fridge cabinet in the drawer next to it with it's respective screws. No one bothered to put it back on, making it difficult to access the fridge. My second day in town, I was gone between the hours of 9am-1pm and put the please clean room placard on the door. I returned to find my room not attended to, with the placard still on the door. I was very surprised by this since I saw three different housekeeping attendants throughout the hall when I left. The following day I requested a afternoon housekeeping with the housekeeping attendant since my interview was from 12-5pm. I returned to find my room in a "cleaned" condition worse than a holiday inn express. My bed was made, yet the covers appeared as if someone had laid in them, with the decorative cover in a diagonal position when it should clearly be horizontal. Additionally I left a wine glass next to visibly full wine bottles. Upon returning the wine glass was gone, yet the coffee carafe from the morning was sitting next to it without any coffee cups. The cups for the bathroom sink area were visibly dirty, not replaced, and not even aligned together. Shower caps and shampoo were missing, as well as the coffee creamers and coffee itself. Honestly I usually don't expect a lot, but this was a very lacking scenario. I expected mush better from this establishment.Looking for a change of scenery, the husband and I used the Indiana resident rate to book a night at the Alexander. For about $180, we got a room, 2 free breakfasts at Market Table and it seems like there was something else. We stopped by the hotel around 12:30, hoping to drop our bags off before lunch but, to our surprise, we were able to get into our room. I was pretty impressed. Big comfy king size bed, a nice array of Indiana-related snacks (for a fee), a Keurig, a mini fridge, and art all over the place. One neat feature is that in order to operate the lights in the room, you need to insert a key card into a slot; that way, lights aren't used when you're not in the room.The decor is phenomenal -- tons of cool installations in the lobbies, the bar and the hallways. Lots of lounge-y feeling seating areas, too.One quirk -- you enter on the first floor (ground level) but the elevator only takes you to the lobby (level 2). Then you take a separate elevator to the guest room area. Could be a safety consideration, but it was a bit strange. The only quibble is that there really isn't all that much right there. So far, Qdoba seemed to be the only retail establishment open in the CityWay development. It is convenient if you are going to an event at the Fieldhouse, however.I was at a business networking event the second day it was open - apparently the first such event after opening - and everything went without a hitch. The staff was professional, courteous, and, if you didn't know it, you would have no idea that the hotel had only been open for two days.The decoration, layout, and art at this boutique hotel is what makes it unique. Some of the art displays would stand out even at the IMA.The staff gave a tour of the hotel and it's fairly impressive. If you get a chance, definitely check out the Boardroom, which is on the 6th floor and has a 270 degree view of just south of downtown Indianapolis. There's also an outdoor terrace that surrounds it, which should be awesome when it's not 10F.Hotels like this will help Indianapolis improve its profile and image to travelers - business and pleasure alike. I wish it success.The Alexander is a gorgeous art hotel. The amount of effort and time spent on the selection of pieces in the lobbies, restaurants, public spaces, and hotel rooms' shows. The collection is unique and each time you look around, you spot something different.The pros:- Striking art- The shower is awesome and made for tall people- Location- This hotel is located within a minutes' walk of Bankers Life, Lucas Oil Stadium, and many of the downtown Indy restaurants- Free Wifi- Hotel Garage Parking- It is cheaper than some of the other downtown hotels. With in/out privileges, it is $24/day. Without in/out privileges, it is $20/day- The bedding- The comforter was thick and warm - Eco-Conscious lighting- Like European hotels, you are required to place a room card in a slot to make the lights work.  The cons:- The rooms have high ceiling and can echo. Depending on how drunk your neighbors are, you can hear them.- The bed- This is one of the biggest issues that I had with the hotel. This is one of the most uncomfortable beds I have ever slept on, and this is coming from a person who tends to stay in a hotel 200+ nights a year.- The chairs- Like the bed, the chairs were just not comfortable to sit in. While I understand that they went with the themes, you should also consider the functionality and comfort as well.- The price- I was lucky to score a good rack rate, if it wasn't for that fact, I cannot justify spending that much money on a room , even if I was on business and that I find uncomfortable to sleep and work in. - The restaurants on site- Plat 99 interesting take on cocktails and nice space to hang out in, but I've had iffy service on several occasions; Cerulean Restaurant- great decor, but I am just not a fan of the restaurant.I'm rating the Alexander purely on a tour of their facilities, the bar and their public art.  I've not actually stayed at the hotel, but I certainly plan to on a future staycation.I love that Indy finally has a boutique hotel.  It's a bit off the beaten path, but I think this makes for a great connection from the Lily campus to downtown proper.  The building is beautiful -- tons of art pieces in the lobby and open spaces.  And it's great to read up on the artists.The piece de resistance for The Alexander is their bar, Plat 99.  See my separate review for the bar, because it is fab-u-lous.The Market Bar is downstairs and I've enjoyed a couple of meetings in this space and the food I've enjoyed here (via catering or the Market Bar) has been excellent and far superior to most hotel dining options.All in all, this is quite a gem in our city and I think it's got some modern swank.  It's a place to go to for a cocktail or fun parties that they host (Merry and Bright for the holidays).Friendly staff, large rooms, quiet, maybe the best hotel bed I've ever slept in. Efficient check in, valet and check out. Couldn't be better. I'd go back in a minute.Absolutely loved the atmosphere!! Spent the day visiting the Indianapolis Museum of Art so to stay at the hotel that expresses art (and has IMA souvenirs in a little gift shop) it was def finishing touches for a fantasic day. Upon arrival the staff was super friendly and informative. After dinner and such a busy day we just wanted to stay in and enjoy the game (Go Irish!) So wine from room service was ordered which came with surprise chocolate strawberries. (Just because, he said) service was professional, friendly and prompt. Will def stay again!!
review_content_40: I have stayed in hotels around the world but this was without a doubt my best "hotel experience" yet. Great helpful staff, amazing bar, awesome contemporary art. Totally recommend it.The Alexander is an impressive hotel and loved the private tour offered for the event we were at. From the $2m art collection and pieces exclusively made for the hotel or the view at night from the Board Room patio will be a conversion starter for some time.  This is a hotel I can recommend with confidence and will do so often.  The entire event was phenomenal and brilliantly organized.  Be sure to visit Platt 99 where the atmosphere is inviting, relaxing and beautiful from the moment you enter. The view of the city from daytime to nighttime mesmerized us while having wonderful cocktails and never ending appetizers.  Plats outdid themselves with the food and drinks tonight. I even smiled when I received my small, glass bottle of Diet Coke...to cute. We tried everything from the pork belly sandwiches, mini lox puffs, YUM, homemade donuts puffs with 3 varieties of fillings, and my favorites, the Beef Carpaccio. Unfortunately, I  didn't get an opportunity to sample the Adult Grilled Cheese that everyone was raving about but then again just another reason to return.  My husband munched on the edamam with pinot noir salt and popcorn delivered to each table throughout the evening.  Our servers were awesome; friendly and managed our crowd very well. We're looking forward to bringing friends back for cocktails on the deck or have a weekend downtown at the Alexander.  Can't wait till the next trip to Platt 99.The Alexander is a very lovely hotel with lots of great amenities. From breakfast at the Marketplace to drinks at Plat 99, from the gym facility to the art tours, there's a lot to enjoy whether you are a business or pleasure traveler.The rooms are nice, fairly spacious with a Mad Men mod feel. My bed was super comfy and the amenities were simple, but good. There isn't a mini-bar in the room, but there is a coffee machine, bottles of water and a couple of local snacks.The rooms are really green and none of the lights will work unless you put your key card in a holder on the wall. Really interesting idea, but it takes a bit of getting used to.The staff is top notch, very friendly and I'd definitely recommend this place if you are looking for a hotel in Indy.Beautiful hotel! As soon as you walk in you feel like you're in an art gallery, and i was eating it up!As you walk up the stairs into the lobby, there's a super swanky bar that made me want to drop all my bags and run into. Too bad I was on a busy schedule. But I wasn't too busy to enjoy the amenities! I love the modern accents. The shades that block out the outside light, the make-up mirror and most importantly... these cool little pop out bedside lights. Seriously, how can I install those in my bedroom? And, the bed, extremely comfy. Five stars for that alone!The only thing I was not into was the shower. Specifically the fact that there was no door. I get it. We're being modern with our shower. But it made it cold, I was spraying water everywhere and, if I had someone with me, I'd want a little privacy. The staff was super friendly and the best part is they called me a "cab," which ended up being a town car that cost the same amount of money as a regular cab. I'm down with that! I would stay here again and again. Heck, I'd be okay living here...My wife and I got married on Leap day, 2012, so we dont know exactly when to celebrate our anniversary. This year we decided to take a little staycation night in downtown Indy to overlap Feb. 28-Mar. 1. We've been wanting to check out The Alexander for some time, and this was the perfect opportunity. Having called ahead to let them know we were celebrating a special night, I was cheerfully told, "Great, I'll make a note of it, and we'll take care of it for you". Not knowing what that meant exactly, we just went downtown and settled in.From the moment we arrived to the moment we left, we felt special. From the valet gentlemen to the front desk staff to the Plat 99 waitress, we were congratulated on our anniversary and warmly treated. The front desk upgraded our stateroom to a corner room overlooking Lucas Oil, and shortly after we got to it and unpacked, came a knock at the door. Two very pleasant staff members came in with a bottle of champagne and chocolate covered strawberries, and a handwritten note welcoming us and wishing us a happy anniversary. What an impression that left!The room itself was whimsical, with unique chairs (a highlight for us when we travel), spacious bathroom and shower, floor to ceiling windows with electric shades, interesting lighting units, and a bathrobe for each of us in the wardrobe. The bed was comfortable, and we fully appreciated out stay.The hotel itself is beautiful, with both specially commissioned art and purchased art decorating everything from the entrances, to the common areas, and even the parking garage (which we drove through after we left since we used the valet service). Plat 99 was a fun place to meet friends for drinks and a killer grilled cheese sandwich. Market Table was a full weekend brunch, complete with a bloody mary bar, build your own mac n cheese, a carving station, and even a gelato bar! We did not try Cerulean, but will in the future. All in all, it was a fantastic weekend in downtown in Indy, highlighted by the hospitality at The Alexander. Thank you for making our 2nd (1/2?) anniversary special!If you are visiting Indianapolis, I highly suggest this hotel. My boyfriend and I went just for one night and used his AAA discount which saved us a lot. They have a parking structure attached to the hotel for $20 a night. Starting at the garage they had such cool urban art that continue throughout our stay. The check in was an easy process and the service was amazing. Everywhere you turn there is another interesting piece of art work to look at. Our room was very nice, keurig coffee machine,large luxurious shower, comfy robes, and comfortable california king. We had tickets to the Pacers game which worked out perfectly. We had drinks and dinner before the game at Plat 99 which is in the hotel- again more great decor. They had a whole timeline of cocktails and complementary truffle popcorn. (they also had a really cool outdoor rooftop seating area for the bar, but was too cold and snowy to go out on) Bankers Field house was maybe 1 minute away walking. After the game we came back and got some drinks at Plat 99 again, it was pretty crowded, fun environment. For breakfast we ate at the Market Place downstairs, it was one set price for a buffet and had a lot of good food.We checked out at 11am- very easy and the concierge was friendly and helpful. Before we left we spent about 30 minutes just walking around the hotel looking at all the art work, it is like a modern art museum. Overall we loved this hotel, for a quick getaway to Indianapolis, especially if you are going to a Pacers or Colts game, is was fantastic. Next time I go back to Indianapolis I will be staying here again.Wow!  I am super impressed with this hotel.  I love that it is almost like a mini art museum! We booked a California king room.  The room was lovely!  The view isn't that amazing (currently there is construction across the street). The bed was crazy comfortable! However the pillows were not as great as the bed!A warm welcome to a New neighbor on Indy's southside. A breath of fresh air has blown in filled with enchanting, inspiring, and rejuvinating urban modern art that graces every corner of the lobby. The Alexander is a fantastic addition to this neighborhood with many throw backs in it's design and name to the history of Indianapolis. We attended a hospitality industry function here and it was truly wonderful to see such great service and such a great facility! The art and design truly is top notch!Way to kick it up a notch, Indy. Alexander Ralston himself would have undoubtedly been proud! From the name, to the restaurant and bar to the lobby to the rooms, this place is top notch! I heard a few people criticize The Alexander for not being as good as 21C in Louisville and I presume that is only due to the public restrooms.Love the artwork in the public spaces--especially the Madame CJ portrait made out of combs: bloody clever, that. As is the record soaring out of the turntable. I could go on.The rooms are modern, tidy, with awesome local touches: a different local photo in every room and a mini bar stocked with snacks from local businesses. Very cool.Love the custom wallpaper in the halls.Plat 99: Unlike any space in the city and the one of the best hotel bars I've seen. Can't wait to hang there in the summer on the patios.Cerulean: In a word. Fab.Only downside-- room without a view. I visited a friend with a south facing scene: a parking lot and Eli Lilly HQ? Might want to look into dropping a theatre scrim outside the window or continue with the art theme and add some shapes or colors to the windows.This review is only based on my impression of the lobby while visiting the hotel bar, Plat 99.This is the hotel that could give the Conrad a run for its A-lister money.   I can really see this being the place where visiting football and basketball teams stay on their road trip.   It's super-modern and luxurious.   They've spend millions on the art alone.The house bar is a worth of visit on its own merits (see my review for Plat 99).The best hotel in Indianapolis! I love this hotel! It's the perfect blend of comfortable modern elegance. The staff was extremely friendly. Everything was impeccably clean. The room even had enough space for me to do yoga in!The lounge had live music with excellent food and was the perfect atmosphere for a relaxed business meeting.Not one detail was missed with this hotel! My favorite part about my stay was learning about all the art through out the hotel.  It's one thing to look at the art, but it's a whole different experience watching the artist's progression of each piece on a flat screen next to it. LOVE! LOVE! LOVE!I too have had issues with staying in a room paid for by someone else. My room, as well as my son's room, was already paid for when we arrived. At the desk we were both asked for credit cards for incidentals. BOTH of our cards were CHARGED for each of our rooms IN ADDITION to the card that had already paid for it in full. Time consuming inconvenience that I wouldn't expect from such a fine hotel. Upon arrival I showed all of the paper work printed out so the young lady could hold it and read it. She was uninterested and in attentive when I tried to explain. Her condescending smile said it all. After our stay- Of course we had to discuss it with the front desk, the bank, and the hotel again. Plus my son is 19, has his own banking, and is away at college so dealing with that was frustrating as well. I'd give more stars if the people working at the front desk had better critical thinking skills or training. Or if anyone there even acknowledged the situation with any empathy. The front desk is the face if your business. A condescending smile instead of listening to your guest explain something isn't the way to run an expensive hotel.Beautiful hotel. Great guest service. When we arrived they had us in the wrong room. But talked to Michelle in Guest Services she fixed the problem and even received an upgrade. Nice job Michelle. Thanks again. Would stay here again!OK, It's not the Ritz-Carlton Hong Kong, but The Alexander is a damned fine hotel.  And when you compare the cost per night of the Alexander to the swindlery that was being perpetrated by the big chains, such as The Marriot at $340/night, during this week of big events (NTEA show, Big 10 Basketball Conference) in Indianapolis, the Alexander is even more appealing.It's close to all of the essentials-downtown, the convention center, the Lilly Complex, Lucas Stadium, Banker's Life Stadium, etc, but the aspect most appealing to me was the impeccable appointments that you'll find everywhere in the hotel.The rooms are stunning, with excellent mid century furnishings and decor. From the Eames designed aluminum management chairs and walnut stools (painted in this case) to the Hans-Grohe faucets and shower heads, the Dolce Group eschewed the "what's the cheapest furnishing we can find?" mentality that is so prevalent in the hotel industry today, and instead furnished this property with a steady focus on design and quality.Comfortable beds, although I can certainly do without the 30 lbs duvet that seem to be de rigueur these days, and a very efficient work area are also standard accoutrement.Finally, The Night Light Bar has an excellent selection of local craft beer and the complimentary truffle popcorn is delicious.Book here with total confidence!My stay at The Alexander was a lovely one. The decor was tasteful, the amenities were many and the staff was friendly and eager to help. Would recommend.Had a meeting here last week, wow! The rooms are very nice with a modern theme. The food was awesome in the market! Enjoyed the bar as well. Comfy couches suit a large group nicely. In the summer they gave heated outdoor seating. The only problem with this hotel us that it isn't part of the rewards origami I have built up at another hotel! Parking us easy and it us right across the street from Lilly. The entrance is weird, as when you walk in, you gave to go upstairs. Price is right, and I really like this hotel!I stayed here while relocating a family to Indy, the staff did what they could accommodate my parking situation(Large deisel truck) so that we could have a comfortable stay and not worry about having to move that mama-jamma. Staff was really nice and told us all the fun things to do downtown. Hotel is clean and really decked out.Amazing business, art hotel!  One of the only hotels that has been fully curated by an art museum in the country.  Very modern decor throughout, with comfy beds in the rooms and a posh mixology lounge, Plat 99.  Located perfectly downtown with walking distance of a Pacers or Colts game.  7 minute walk to Monument Circle and 15 minute walk to Mass Ave.Stayed here for a conference. The check-in girl, Luan, was a little rude, like helping me check-in was inconvenient. Also, she didn't think to tell me about being able to charge the garage to the room (which costs less than if you pay and leave and return), and gave me a hard time when I asked her to confirm the room was being paid for by the conference (which it was supposed to be since I was a speaker attending for that purpose and they had made all the arrangements.)I followed up that day with my contact at the conference and it was confirmed again that they had made the reservation and were paying for the room. So I went back to check-out to let them know that the conference person would stop by and remind them, which she the head of the conference did and let the desk know to please send them the charges. Then the next day I went back and it was the same girl, Luan. When I asked about the garage, first she said that she couldn't refund the extra charges on the garage. Then when I pressed to have the double parking cost removed (as I had added the daily parking rate to my room and was charged when I tried to exit the garage earlier) then she did the return - very begrudgingly! I never would have had the extra charge if she had told me about the parking garage in the first place!She also told me that yes the person from the conference had stopped by the front desk,to confirm the conference was covering the room. But, she said that I would still need to stop by the front desk AGAIN in the morning to check with the hotel's conference person who would come in and I needed to take it up with her. seriously?It's really frustrating - for a hotel this nice they ought to check that all front desk people are well trained.Just stayed here for a conference for three days and nights. What a lovely hotel. Very clean and sleek and the staff was friendly, knowledgable and professional. Everyone had a smile and was willing to help. The food was amazing and the Market Place buffet had great choices, all fresh and delicious. I would definitely stay here again and recommend it to anyone looking for comfort and class in downtown Indiana.
review_content_60: Came the hotel for an after hours social event. The space was really nice. The staff seemed cool and parking was good.This hotel has a lot of potential and great customer service. The problem I had with this hotel is the room. First of all we came in and the toilet seat was dirty. It didn't seem like feces but still gross. Let's write that off as isolated. The rug in the room overall looked dirty, and had a large stain on it. Probably hadn't been cleaned in a while.  The floor underneath seamed nice, if only they had just removed the rug. The wallpaper in the bathroom was peeling, and the shower head was in some serious need of CLR. To be honest the thing that annoyed me the most was they have no movie rental service. Just basic cable plus HBO. The wife and I were away from the baby for a night it would have been nice to enjoy a movie. What hotel doesn't have movie rental. What the heck?  I am not even looking for adult movies. Just something I can pick when it starts and not have any commercials. So in the end. Not worth your money. It seems really cool when you walk in but the don't pay enough attention to their rooms to make it worth it.Beautiful, modern, and reasonably priced! The decor is modern and their gym is amazing. The service is as good as it gets. I definitely recommend this hotel with high praise.Great hotel, the art creates an amazing atmosphere. Up to date, clean, modern rooms that look great. Plenty of shower room, and the overhead shower heads should be mandatory in every other hotel! Who knew this little gem existed in Indianapolis!Staff was nice, check in was easy.Only thing is I wish there was a little more walking distance around the hotel, but I'm sure in a few years the development will catch up.Would deserve a 5 star... But the lady a check out was unorganized and not helpful with the package I had coming in UPS red early AM.  Short of that the other 4 days of my stay were 5/5 stars.Everything at The Alexander is first class. If you're a guest in the hotel, you're really treated like royalty by the staff. When we checked in, the front desk asked our group (four women) if we were staying for any special reason. We explained we weren't out of towners, but we would be going out that night to celebrate a 30th birthday and wanted to stay somewhere nice downtown. They immediately upgraded our room to a gorgeous suite (full kitchen, two bedrooms, two bathrooms, a corner view with a wrap-around balcony) gave us four free drink tickets, breakfast tickets, and, later, sent up a bottle of champagne with four glasses. This is not the first high end hotel I've stayed in, but I've never had so many extra perks thrown in! The women at the front desk were enthusiastic, and excited to help us celebrate. They were wonderful and helpful with all of our questions. The room was, in short, awesome. Luxurious bed linens, gorgeous furniture and design elements, wonderful lighting (no overhead!) The bathroom lighting was fantastic. We were able to crowd into one bathroom while we got ready; the mirror was big enough to accommodate everyone. There were even magnifying mirrors in each room. The kitchen was stocked with cooking utensils and glasses and a dishwasher. I think it was an extended stay room that they let us use just for the night. It even had a full size refrigerator. Each bedroom had an iHome clock radio/stereo, which we used to listen to music from our iPhones. It sounds cliche, but it really seems they've "thought of everything."I don't think I'll be able to stay anywhere else downtown. The Alexander has spoiled me, completely. With a AAA discount, and all of the perks they threw in, I felt like we didn't even come close to paying what our stay was worth. Even without all that, I'd still choose The Alexander over other high end establishments downtown, just thanks to the wonderful staff. They left a lasting impression. I'd give it six stars, if I could. Now go. Book a room. Who cares if you don't have a reason?The people are amazing! The place wasn't even open yet and they let us poke around. The art and atmosphere is top notch!Beautiful hotel, feels crisp and new.  Rooms are clean and bedding is SO comfortable.  Nice bath products and proper soap in the shower.  Surprised there was no tub, only shower.  Loved the fruit infused water in the lobby, very refreshing.  Breakfast was fresh (made to order eggs, oatmeal, pancakes, fruit, etc).  Plat 99 bar had cool ambiance.  Gym was a bit difficult to find, small but sufficient.  Had a billing error - was charged for minibar food I did not take.  Staff reversed the charges quickly and easily when I brought this to their attention.  Would definitely consider staying here again.Attended a one day conference here. The snack service for meetings is awesome! The meeting rooms were very nice and comfortable. This is obviously a very upscale hotel. Would love to stay here some time.Great hotel. very clean and modern. The staff at the front desk was not that knowledgeable about places to eat.There's a lot of good things to say about The Alexander. Free wifi, an in-room Keurig with several free K-cups, interactive touchscreen directories and art galore. The best thing though was the thoughtfulness of the staff. I forgot to bring batteries for some headphones I recently bought, no problem, they just gave me some for free. My girlfriend casually mentioned that it was her birthday... Free champagne and chocolate covered strawberries with a well thought out card from Steve at the front desk. It's this kind of thing, particularly in contrast to some other downtown hotels, that will have us coming back to The Alexander for weekend getaways. The only downside to this place is the lack of a pool and hot tub, but seeing as they don't advertise them, I couldn't really count it against them. In all, given the price I paid, this was one of the best overall hotel experiences I've had. I certainly plan to stay again.loved this hotel. i want to stay here anytime we are in indy. the architecture and interior design is really cool. i felt like i was staying in a contemporary art museum. we spent part of an evening just roaming the floors and garage to look at all the art. very cool. i love all the lights in the bar. i felt like it was out of "lost in translation."the room was super nice and comfortable. it was also surprisingly quiet. it might have been that we were there on a sunday night but normally all night in hotels you can here doors slamming and elevators and random noises but it was silent. the hotel staff accommodated us getting a late start and helped us move our checkout time to noon with no extra cost. great place, great staff!What an amazing hotel!  Fabulous service, cool art, and well designed functional rooms.  One of the few times I was sad to leave a hotel.  Everything hotel wise was perfect... except for the food.  There's no where to get drinks/snacks in the hotel and all the food available is pricey.  The lunch buffet restaurant was ok...unfortunately, there wasn't enough customers to keep the food fresh and hot.  Service was again great.  Finally...the reason why I'm taking one star away...I ordered crab cakes and shrimp and grits one night for room service.  Dinner was tasty...however, i ended up sick and throwing up in the middle of the night!  Disappointing blemish on an otherwise fabulous stay.Had a morning meeting at Market Table yesterday and breakfast was fantastic. Made to order eggs, great coffee and a few items from the open kitchen was all I needed, thankfully, it came with outstanding service! Great way to start the day.The second week in April 2013  I stayed there in a corporate room. What a delightful surprise. I loved the eclectic art, the desk staff, and the food in the restaurant. The breakfast was oh so healthy and quality food in my opinion. The sleek modern room decor is fun and fresh. I especially liked the lighted magnifier mirror in the bathroom.Went on a tour of this facility through Visit Indy and oh my goodness it was so nice. Loved the implementation of art and local. Cerulean was top notch. Plat 99 food was meh, but those are different reviews.Sleek contemporary style hotel with an exclusive art collection make this place one of a kind especially in Indianapolis.  Clean minimalist rooms with a lot of light. Free wifi is always a benefit I enjoy.Nice addition to the downtown area.  I can't wait for the weather to warm up to get back down there and be out and about.one of the best hotels I have ever stayed at, aesthetically. i was there during the hurricanes that swept through IN in November, and the staff was so attentive, especially when the power went out. brought guests into the basement, gave us water bottles, and played music for us until the storm had passed. i ended up leaving a scarf and a sweater in the room and when i called to see if they found the items, they shipped it back to me and took care of the shipping even when i tried to give them my CC number. seriously, wow. cannot wait to go back, such a beautiful hotel.At first, I thought "Ick. A hipster hotel that's trying way too hard." But when I left, I was completely convinced. Truly, a wonderful place. A little off the beaten path, but you'll get a one-of-a-kind customer experience. Their biggest draw should be their amazing (IMA curated) art collection. This would be a wonderful spot for a wedding-you could rent the entire place. Their dining areas was really nice, home to some excellent food. Plat 99 is awesome too. They have yoga on the lawn, bikes to rent, and soon they'll have a partnership with the giant YMCA going in across the street. And their prices are fantastic! I encourage you to check out this hotel.
review_content_80: Though this was limited-service, I had a good experience and hit up every service staff employee I could to inquire about their own experiences. I had a good vibe, despite any turnover which may exist. The limited food I had, the sliders, were very good, and I was extremely excited to know they carried Prohibition liquor. I don't know how much of the stock they have, but it's a fantastic start - recommend!!! Platt 99 was nice and the desk staff on the outskirts of the bar was fantastic. There was a female staff agent tonight who was extremely helpful, however her name escapes me. She was pleasant, friendly, and knowledgable. I will re-visit to learn her name, because she was great in my experience of The AlexanderBeware.   We stayed at the Alexander in order to be close to basketball games at Bankers Life.  Coming down for breakfast, we were told that they couldn't seat us for a buffet breakfast for 2 + hours, despite many empty tables throughout the restaurant.  It would probably not have been too bad, except there was not apology or regret at this.  Furthermore, we were told that the next closest restaurant that was open for breakfast was a substantial walk (in the frigid cold) or a taxi ride.  Beware if you would like a meal or employees that were empathetic.My wife and I decided not to go back out to the west side after a night of revelry at the Columbia Club, and happened upon the Alexander in a web search. Although I did not think the place was any great shakes (except that it is new, clean,  and very metropolitan), I will say the service was absolutely fantastic. Now, to be fair, I am an old fart and not easily impressed, nor am I easily deterred. The beds were comfortable, to be sure, the showers were big, fancy-schmancy all around. I don't think it deserved a 5 star rating just because it's new, but it is a solid, SOLID four star, and I think a younger customer might think it was all the dogs and then some.Very interesting layout and decor, including a few multiple dimensional pieces of art. Platt 99 is a very modern looking bar with a collection of art glass lighting fixtures. The room was clean and sparsely furnished with a poster on the wall in place of art - which was disappointing given their self designated "art hotel" moniker. Their web site as well as the info guide in the room stated that they have a museum store in their gift shop - when they don't even have any gift shop according to the employees. That is on their yet to come list, so is misrepresented in their marketing. The coffee maker in the room didn't work, even though new. The biggest issue was the lack of service available. A room service order for breakfast was still undelivered 1 hour and 2 calls later. Since the order was for yogurt, bagel, etc., I couldn't find any excuse - and none was offered by the staff. While I am sure they will get control of these issues soon, I certainly wouldn't go out of my way to return.

review_content: This place was amazing. Great bar in the lobby area. I was there just for the night so just needed a place to rest my weary bones and relax before a long day driving the next day. I had such fun just chatting with the very friendly bartender on duty. It felt like chatting with an old friend.The room was immaculate and the bed was ohhh so comfy. I had one of the best nights sleep in a long time. I really loved this place and the view was AMAZING!The hotel's structure, rooms, amenities, and the location is great. The front desk staff is not approachable and they do not represent the hospitable standard upheld by the Sheraton brand. The location of this hotel is wonderful. It's in close proximity to lots of shopping, restaurants, and entertainment. The hotel is in great condition. This review is based mainly on how I was treated by the front desk.It was Valentines weekend. Of course this hotel would be booked to 100% capacity if not oversold however, that is not my problem. My flight was cancelled so we had to extend our stay at this hotel. Now, usually most hotels would be able to smile and say "Sorry we don't have rooms available for tonight blah blah blah" however, my company has a contract with this hotel and if such thing were to happen, they would have to extend it no matter the circumstance. The front desk then started complaining to me how this was an inconvenience to me and how they didn't have rooms for us and we should have checked out hours ago. I don't remember filling out an application to the Sheraton can somebody please remind me when I started working here again? I'm sorry about your issues but I'm your guest, you don't complain to me about your problems. Unprofessional.I am not a fan of this hotel and it is a last resort when all the other hotel options (The Conrad and Hilton) are sold out. On a recent trip, room service failed to answer their phone for breakfast, forcing me to go down and order and wait in the restaurant for a to go order. Similarly for dinner the server gave me the apps menu and then disappeared for more than 10 mins - I left! The hotel was also ridiculously hot, with no way to turn on any air to cool down the rooms. And don't get me started on the ridiculous bathroom layout with the toilet arranged under the bathroom counter. It is just weird! I am sure I will have to stay here again for work at some point and can only hope they fix these issues.Could Indianapolis be where Starwood is trialing their new "use fitted sheets like a normal human" policy? Both this and the Sheraton Keystone Crossing are acting like we all do at home, and using bed linens that don't just end up in a crumpled mess after 10 minutes. You hear me Starwood? This is awesome. Do this everywhere.That aside, this place is fine. The lobby itself is a little dated, but the rooms look to have been recently refreshed and they're pretty comfortable. I notice coworker Frank L.'s review from 2010, and would comment that while the TV has been replaced with a more modern edition, I must agree with the room temperature settings - the room was always warmer than the set point, and this during early December, something I wouldn't expect to have to struggle with. Beds were comfy (what with those fitted sheets) and the bathrooms were fine. I do want to comment that my suite (I think I got upgraded because I certainly didn't book that) featured some mood lighting built in to some bookcases, and idiot me was about to unscrew the light bulbs before I figured out that the switch to turn off said lights was a black switch built in to the black bookcase...almost impossible to see, at least for this moron. Just an odd design decision, I wonder if anyone else has had this problem, or if i'm just stupid.The lounge had a little better breakfast spread than Keystone Crossing did, but not as nice of a coffee machine. I found myself missing the cappuccino from Keystone, but this is actually a pretty nice club lounge with more fruit and juice options, as well as one or two hot items each day. Interesting to me the difference between two Sheraton lounges just about 20 miles apart (or closer).We bailed out and booked here rather than our standard Keystone Crossing when Keystone was completely booked out one week, and for whatever reason, these rooms at retail were cheaper than the negotiated rate my project team has at the Keystone Crossing. Unfortunately, the client's office is really inconveniently located from this place (no highway option, all busy surface streets and stoplight parades), and parking isn't free, rapidly eating up any savings on the room rate. But it's certainly a serviceable option, and in a good area with tons of walkable restaurants. If the rates are always as low as they were for me, this would be a solid option in downtown Indianapolis.Perfectly little lounge spot comfortable break spot with a in house Starbucks and bar and grillI'd like to give this place 3.5 stars overall, though you see it as a 4 here. There's a lot of old-meets-new all over this place. The parking garage, for example, very old. I initially exited through some stairs with creaking doors into an old hallway with leaky pipes and maybe mold, then into the street. From there, walked down a quarter block to the Sheraton main entrance. By the way parking is $25 a night. After checking in, you'll notice the elevators inside actually take you to the different floors in the parking structure. That's good.Lobby is nice, and it was cool to see the bar was open even at 12:30am when I got here. Receptionist was very nice, answered my questions, and since I am a platinum guest, he let me know about the 10th floor club lounge and gave me a room upgrade to a suite. Elevators up and hallway are old, but the suite was totally new and modern. New everything, beautiful dark furniture, granite counters, flat TVs, refrigerator, and microwave. Kinda like a one bedroom condo I have back home. I like to keep the curtains open, but here can't do it because of the office building right across. Water in the room warmed up quickly, and I put the placard up to get the $5 green choice vouchers daily. Everything runs well here. If only they fixed that initial hallway and warmed up the hotel hallways a bit.Junior Suite walk-around: youtube.com/watch?v=v39r...Parlor Suite walk-around: youtube.com/watch?v=V2r9...It gets the job done! Good location in downtown Indy. Comfortable, clean beds. Staff was friendly - not amazinggg, but they did their job. My room was located on the 17th floor and had a gorgeoussss view. I uploaded pictures, so take a look! :) Especially at night when the lights lit up on the Soldiers & Sailors Monument. Parking was $25/night for self-park. Wifi was only free up to a certain GB. I got a room with 2 double beds - pretty standard. It's not superrrr close to the stadium...I think about a 20 minute walk? Or maybe I'm just a slow walker...Otherwise, it was close to lots of bars/restaurants!Mixed bag of experiences across two stays here.Here in May, for both work and the Indy 500, I booked a suite and enjoyed the 2-room (living and bedroom) space. Large and comfortable couch, with a dark wood finish in the living room and a decent selection of interesting books on the bookshelves. One of the main highlights of my stay was the excellent help and advice given by Judy, the rockstar behind the smooth operation of the Front Desk at night. My second stay in November was a bit more aggravating. I was initially excited to see that the hotel had upgraded my standard-room booking to the "Presidential Suite". I'd booked on Starwood's Birthday rate, meaning I paid the regular room rate for the first night and the last 2 digits of my birth year for each additional night. Unfortunately, as I arrived after midnight, the hotel's booking system made a mess of the billing, which took nearly a month after my stay to finally sort out fully. Furthermore, the room itself was a bit distressing, as I was horrified to discover that the entry door did not close properly unless one slammed it brutally, which I didn't do at first, only to discover my room open to the world after coming back from dinner. The room facelifts the hotel has undertaken are nice, but I do have to regret that the bathroom in the suite still looks old, tired, and I had issues with my running water one morning as I went in for a shower. On a more positive note, I left behind a set of cufflinks, and Samantha from Housekeeping was quick to find them and package them up wonderfully for a next-day FedEx back to me.Probably the worst part of my November stay was trying to receive a package. I'd had an urgent package (couldn't depart without it) sent to my attention for 8AM delivery, and at 8AM, the hotel turned away the FedEx driver. FedEx came back and successfully the package at 10:45, but despite my numerous conversations with the Front Desk Manager and all staff on duty at the time, nobody notified me of the delivery until after noon (Front Desk Manager's excuse - "Oh - I'm short, and the package was placed a little too high for me to see it easily"). That delay ended up costing me my flight, and over $100 in car transfer charges to make an international connection. As an SPG Platinum member with over 100 nights in 2014, that takes the cake as the absolute worst customer service fail of the year.All in all, two stays, and two very different customer service experiences. I'm not entirely sure if I'd come back now that there is a Le Meridien in Indianapolis, but if I do it is only because I know that there are great staff like Judy and Samantha here who care.7226 Woodland Drive, Indianapolis, IN 46278, United StatesAwesome staff, comfortable beds, amazing view.... And to top it all off, the soap smells really good. :P The check out time wasn't until NOON!!! Our parking was FREE. The guy below who said the internet wasn't free was wrong.... He just needed to get the access code. The only thing keeping me from a 5 star is.... Where's the breakfast?OK, but not great, especially for the posted price. The posted room rate was $500 per day. PLASTIC CUPS, not glass. Cheap. No mention of breakfast provided. I discovered this a few moments ago. The bar served HORRIBLE flavored stale popcorn. AVOID IT. YUK!!! The bed was not so good, morning backache! BUT, the parking was included. The restaurant Alexander's served a very nice Ruben sandwich. Great service there. Nice rooms. Lovely view. Nicely decorated with pictures of Indianapolis. A very nice location, steps from Monument Circle, and near lots of restaurants. Very nice staff.OK, but not for $500 a night.$350, nope. $275, maybe.$25 for parking. That's all you need to know. It's a nice hotel, in a great part of town, and great value for my Starwood Points...but $25 for parking! This isn't NYC, it's Indianapolis. I've stayed at dozens of Sheraton's over the years, and parking is usually cheaper for those staying at the hotel, especially when I'm a Gold Starwood Member. I get it, I'm a spoiled hotel traveler who doesn't want to pay for parking. But seriously, if you're considering staying here budget for the ridiculous the $25/daily parking rate.Possibly the most convenient location ever for access to downtown Indy, as it's right on Monument Circle with swarms of taxi fleets downstairs. But overall, not too happy with my experience at this Sheraton.Pros:- Great location for downtown, with pretty much a taxi hub downstairs.- Not much else.Cons:- Really old building, and it shows in the rooms and hallways.- Impossibly slow elevators. Since most guests are business guests, getting out of the hotel between 7-9 AM involves budgeting ~15min to wait for the elevator.- The Club Room was a disappointment... you need to be SPG Silver/Gold, or pay $30, or get a room on the 14th floor, for access. And even then the selection isn't too great.- The connected Starbucks has a line nearly out the door for the morning cuppa Joe.do not eat at alexanders bar and grill, horrible nasty food plenty good places close by. In addition three other of my travel companions also on separate times had the worst experience and food ever.A nice room, but some issues.First, I'd like to acknowledge that the bed was great. And the hotel's location in the center of the city makes it attractive for tourists and business travelers. That counts for a something.My recent stay at the Sheraton coincided with the 99th running of the Indianapolis 500. While on the surface the hotel seemed nice, ultimately a series of small issues accumulated to make the stay less than pleasant.One of my primary gripes regarding the hotel concerns billing. Simply put, I was charged for the whole stay when the room was supposed to be billed to a corporate account. That would be an understandable error had I not pointed it out repeatedly while I was there, and assured by staff (repeatedly) that it would be taken care of.Instead, it's one week after my stay and the charge for the whole stay went through on my debit card, which was supposed to be for incidentals. Not cool. I finally contacted the accounting department directly, and the hotel is issuing a refund, but it's worth noting that this Sheraton held on to over a thousand bucks it was not entitled to for over a week. During my fourth (and hopefully final) interaction with customer service, I was told it was my fault for providing a debit card instead of a credit card. Ummm... no.Another issue pertained to noise. The guests in the next room over were clearly interested in late night partying and arguments. At 2 am I was woken up by someone shouting "come on in and join the party" which was followed by the thump of a subwoofer. I called the front desk, which sent security--it took seven minutes before I heard the knock on their door, and the noise subsided. But not too much later I heard a female voice scream "You are such an ***hole" through the (apparently thin) walls. The arguments and yelling continued and I had to call security again. I wound up getting only four hours of sleep that night.Given that I was awake at 3 am, I went to the mini-fridge to grab a bottled water--you know, the one that costs $4.00 if you open it. I opened it but could not get a single sip out of it because it was frozen solid. Oops.The elevators in the hotel were a low-light of the trip. Sometimes the cars had a mind of their own, reversing direction or refusing to stop in the lobby. And during the morning rush, the wait for an elevator seemed interminable. Another issue was breakfast. When I pay $25 for a classic two eggs and bacon breakfast, I like it when the potatoes are edible and the eggs cooked as I requested. I strongly dislike it when I am served eggs with broken yolks, as I was at the Indianapolis Sheraton. I was also baffled that the servers did not ask if I wanted OJ, I had to ask for it.One more gripe... as nice as the location is, there is a homeless presence that made stepping outside the door in the morning a bit nerve-wracking. It's not the hotel's fault, but basically if you take a left turn out of the entrance instead of a right, you might have an encounter. On the last day I was there, within seconds of stepping outside, I was approached by a vagrant who asked if I would help buy him a beverage. When I declined, I was lectured. Sorry, bud.Also, I was annoyed by the limo drivers trying to hustle for passengers when I already told him I had arranged and paid for transport. How many times do I have to say "no?"The hotel should make an effort to maintain a nicer environment at its doorstep.OK, so on the plus side the bed was nice, the room was clean, and the shower had hot water. But I've stayed at enough hotels to know that customers should expect a bit more at the Sheraton's price point.Stayed here for 1 night with my husband. Room was fine. Bathroom was set up awkwardly. You could hear the toilet flush in the room next to us. Parking was easy. We did receive a coupon for a free appetizer at a local restaurant, so that was nice. Overall, would probably stay here again if it was cheaper then some other options.I had a very pleasant stay at this hotel!I am new to staying at Sheraton hotels, but I think it is genius for them to provide guests with a $5 voucher in place of room cleaning service for the next day. There was a Starbucks in the hotel, so it was nice to use the voucher there for Breakfast. I was happy to see that they provided a refrigerator for my use (it wasn't stocked full of expensive drinks like other hotels), they provided free bottled water, and even a loofah to shower with! Their exercise room had everything I wanted, their internet was free and fast enough for me, the bed was comfy, the room was clean, the staff was friendly, I didn't hear other guests while staying in my room, the electrical outlets were easy to access for a phone charger, and they provided free Starbucks coffee and tea products in the room. The location was also perfect for me - near my work and lots of restaurants, and I had the beautiful City Centre as a view from my room.The only things that would make this a 5-star hotel is:1. Better elevators. The doors opened at random times, the numbers didn't always light up after you pressed them, I had to wait 3 minutes to get an elevator one morning, and they didn't indicate which floor the gym was on.2. Better TV reception. I don't watch too much TV, so it didn't bother me enough to say anything about it until the end of my stay, but the TV wasn't getting reception for channels like: the History channel, HGTV, Hallmark, Animal Planet, Discovery, etc. I told the front desk at the end of my stay so they could maybe fix it for a future guest and they were very nice and offered me a free $5 voucher to Starbucks for the inconvenience.Before I start, I will say that the front desk is friendly, as is one of the managers, but the General Manager (Bill) is inattentive, dismissive, and rude.I was worried about this hotel as I had heard about many bad experiences from my colleagues. My own experience was a nightmare. I did not even continue to stay there despite a stay 5 nights get 1 night free SPG promotion, which I could have gained more nights for. There were so many issues that I've made them into bullet points here:1. The bathroom water (soiled water) overflowed on the 9th and 10th floors 2. The faucets started emitting brown water (which some people accidentally were already mid-showered b/c no one told them) before the hotel temporarily shut the water down. 3. Gross spots on the bed mattress4. I grabbed a granola bar in the Club Lounge, only to later open it - take a few bites- and realize it was moldy. I was horrified, that is a serious health issue. I called the hotel very upset so that they could remove the granola bars from the Lounge, and I was furious and demanded to be called by the GM. I informed them at that time I would contact FDA/ Health Department for health violation. They promised to call him. I heard nothing for about a week. Only when I returned (because I had booked it already through work) and complained again at the front desk and to a manager did I finally get a call from the GM.
