He seemed apologetic initially, but skeptical of my complaint. He promised to compensate with points and inspect the food. He called again later that day, accused me of lying (I couldn't remember the exact time I called nor the date on the granola bar... BECAUSE IT HAD BEEN A WEEK!!), and said that they get complaints like mine 10 times a week. I was infuriated and insulted, but most importantly worried. What kind of a hotel doesn't care about food complaints?! Further, I brought up my concern of prior issues in the hotel, and he claimed that he knew exactly who it was who complained b/c he knew where I worked...he then proceeded to name a company I do not work at. I acknowledge that the above 3 situations were resolved. But at the expense of my faith in this hotel. The GM was incredibly defensive, rude and accusatory in his emails and phone conversations with me. He also was highly aggressive by placing multiple calls to my hotel room when i was staying at the hotel to interrogate me regarding the food situation. I became so uncomfortable I vowed to never stay at this hotel again unless every other hotel in the area was booked out.I'm driven to write this now as AGAIN an issue has arisen. When I initially checked into this hotel I asked the front desk if I was all set for the SPG promotion of staying 5 nights and get 1 free night at any Sheraton. I was told "You're all set," I didn't need to take any further action to register. I just called SPG (I am a platinum member) to use this promotion and was informed this was not the case. I asked SPG to resolve the issue. I then received an unsolicited email from Bill Seitl first asking me whom the staff member was (it is not my job to record which staff members tell me information), then again to deny the request which SPG put in for me (they were trying to determine how to best meet the promotion). He was rude, dismissive, and callous in his emails and phone conversations. The worst experience I have EVER had with a hotel.I travel a lot for work, but I've never had such an awful experience where I've felt the need to post online. THERE ARE MANY HOTELS IN INDIANAPOLIS - CHOOSE SOMEWHERE ELSE!Really beautiful hotel but you definitely are paying for what you get. Their garage parking is $20 a night which is kind of steep but worth it considering the location. Since it was my SO's birthday we booked for the executive view which was definitely worth the extra splurge, super great view of the buildings and monuments. The room setup however was pretty small which isn't a huge problem since there were only two of us. The only downside is that the walls are VERY THIN. We heard the "activities" of our neighbors all night long which wasn't only awkward but disruptive in terms of sleep. something to keep in mind. Really nice place for a weekend getaway, and if you're interested they have a Starbucks and a full restaurant in the lobby. Staff was welcoming but not overwhelming worth noting. Clean, decent decor, but nothing too special. The lobby is a lot prettier than any of the rooms.This hotel was really nice. Great location, very quiet insulated rooms, comfortable beds, great view, clean bathrooms, refrigerator, nice decor, multiple elevators. If you travel and need a QUIET room that you can get great sleep in, this is the place. I have a hard time sleeping and I slept like a rock in this place.Gave us the wrong room
review_content_20: Pleasantly impressed as I didn't expect much with a last minute reservation so we had somewhere to stay after the Florida Georgia Line Concert.  I was able to get my corporate rate a few days in advance.  We wound up on the 20th floor (only 21 floors) for which the desk lady said had been recently remodeled.  It was newer but nothing amazing, however it was clean and had everything we wanted.  I much rather have had one king bed, but we wound up with doubles.  We had a nice view of the circle and the snow (I'm a sucker for a view).  The staff was friendly and got us checked in quickly.  We had a late night snack at the restaurant.  They had a limited late night menu, but it worked (chicken quesadilla, $12 i believe?)  There is some construction happening on the building across the road it looks like.  We didn't hear anything as we were on the other side of the building, but it may be heard on the weekday when they are working? Overall, it was a good experience, well worth our corporate leisure rate for a nice in-town get away.  (PS First Watch just around the corner had good food for breakfast)The location is great the the staff is extra friendly. I was recently in town for work and the Sheraton is situated in the middle of downtown. It was a quick walk to the Fieldhouse, convention center, shopping and nightlife. It was my first time in downtown Indy and the staff assisted me in getting around the area.Pros-great location -nice staffCons-we had to wait 30 minutes for a luggage rack when we first checked in-elevators are slow and don't seem to open the doors at the right time. At one point I saw a guy step up off the elevator at his floor. -our A/C didn't seem to be working (but we didn't say anything so this didn't factor into the review)-no ice machines. You must call down to the front desk and have them deliver it to the room, which took 30-40 minutes at leastI was flown in to Indy for a meeting at the world HQ of a pharma company, and they put me up here. The room was very comfortable, the bed was TERRIFIC, and I slept very well.I gotta wonder at the lack of HBO on the in-house TV service. I also question the fact that, if you're eating in the restaurant or bending elbows in the bar (both are adjacent to the lobby) you must ask at the desk for a key to get into the restroom. According to the desk jockeys, it's "because of homeless people." I'm sorry, but I didn't notice a large cohort of homeless folks in downtown Indy. And all my years in NYC gave me a "never, not even once" experience of having to ask permission to use a lobby restroom, particularly if I was eating dinner in the hotel restaurant.So ... only 3 stars.I read a lot of different reviews of this hotel, this is my experience:Easy to get to from the Airport, and there is a garage attached to the hotel. I fit a Durango in there no problem. The check in was easy, very courteous staff, and the room was clean. There is a Starbucks right off the lobby and they take the hotel vouchers for coffee. They have a club level which had good enough food every morning and evening... The showers were clean, hot, and good water pressure.. WiFi worked and was free for me anyway, I mean I really can't complain.I was in town for work and we ended up here because of its close proximity. I was pleased with the location, the rate and the comfort of the bed. The elevators are a bit slow, but it is an older hotel. The walls are a little thin, but thankfully, the only noises coming thru were the flushing toilet, not anything "else". The workout room on the top floor was open 24 hours and was very nice for my needs.  Only gripe, the bathroom was a bit small!I chose Sheraton's Indianapolis City Centre Hotel as the base of operations for New Year's Eve for a group of 4. The staff at the Sheraton made our group feel very welcome. From accommodating our room requests to assisting with food orders, each individual with whom we interacted was friendly and sincere. I had some difficulty/confusion about my online reservation and I was amazed by how quickly and effectively the staff helped me create the perfect evening for my group. The hotel has private parking which was a huge relief as downtown parking can be difficult and pricey. The lobby was very classy and I was greeted immediately. The view from our suite has to be the best the city has to offer. While some of the facilities and decor were a bit dated, it seemed as though improvements and updates were underway. The size of the suite was impressive. I wish we would have had more time to relax there and enjoy the accommodations but New Year's plans wouldn't wait. We did not have time to enjoy the Alexander restaurant in the hotel but I have read wonderful reviews. I will be staying at this classy downtown hotel again! P.S. The Sheraton has an exceptional snack room with a huge variety of munchies should you find yourself hungry after all restaurants have closed.We have stayed at 2 hotels in Indianapolis - Sheraton, Hyatt Regency. The Sheraton is definitely the better choice of the 2. We stayed here APR 2014 and a couple of years ago as well. LOCATION: Excellent. Convenient location right in the middle of the action on Monument Circle. You can walk to attractions like the park, Mass Ave, Circle Center Mall, the football stadium and basketball arena and a ton of restaurants. Downtown Indy is quite small. ROOMS: It has recently been renovated so the rooms are beautiful and modern. We had a suite on the 10th floor, which was huge! There was the bedroom with a tv and living room with a couch and tv with a small library, kitchenette with a sink, microwave and fridge. The bathroom area had 2 sinks and plenty of room. AMENITIES: The gym on the top floor (21st floor) is great! I can tell this is new. Nice equipment and great variety - elliptical, treadmill, bike and free weights and a weight machine, floor mats, medicine balls, foam rollers, etc. Definitely a very nice gym! There is a Starbucks as well as a restaurant and bar on the 1st floor. The only complaint I have from our whole stay is the old creaky elevators which seem like an anachronism in the newly renovated rooms and common areas. PERKS: Complimentary Starbucks coffee in your room to make with the provided coffee maker. Even still to this day, this is the best Sheraton Club I've been to. It's on the 10th floor with 24/7 access to the most variety of juices, coffee, tea, fruit, snacks.  Hot breakfast and nightly hot appetizers complimentary with club access. I was impressed with the hot appetizers being grilled vegetables (red and green peppers, eggplants, squash), chicken tenders, sweet and sour meatballs, and an impressive cheese and cracker plate among other selections. You could definitely make a dinner out of this! It is such a nice place to read the paper or watch TV.  TIPS: Upgrades are easier to get when you are an SPG (Starwood Preferred Guest) member and you earn points for free hotel stays in the future. SERVICE: Also excellent. Our check-in was no problem and MJ at the front desk was extra helpful to us. CONCLUSION: Our experience was top notch - great location, upgraded to a suite, getting club access, and great amenities. I would definitely recommend this hotel!They have recently renovated and it really does look great. We have stayed here for our wedding, got ready in a nice parlor room attached to our suite. They accommodated our needs and Brian Ward the evening manager was great. This stay was for our anniversary and same great service. The pool area is a nice roof top view  and has plenty of chairs and tables even if you're not swimming. They could tend to the cleanness the pool and area. Several cigarettes, band aids and trash about. Great stay if you're downtown and on the circleGreat hotel, recently renovated and in a great location. Upgraded to a suite on the 14th floor and couldn't be happier with the size of the room and amenities. Club Lounge is open 24/7, and had some very nice snacks waiting for us at 2am. Parking is a bit pricey, but that's to be expected in any major city.Decent hotel, but I have to knock down one star because they don't have free Internet in the rooms. The work out facility in the lobby is also very small with limited machines. However, they do have complimentary bottled water in the gym. The rooms are also stocked with Starbucks coffee and Tazo teas. The hotel is in a great location and it's behind the Monument Circle where the Soldiers' and Sailors' neoclassical structure is located. I even got a room facing it! (See my picture) Lots of restaurants and shopping in the area, but I didn't really venture out too far. It was raining, so I just went to ABP and went back to my room. I'm a Starwood Member and read that they offer free happy hour and breakfast on the 10th floor, but I woke up so late so I didn't get to try it. Maybe next time.Great room, freshly remodeled(we were first in it), great GREAT service, fast exercise room with a good view on 21st floor.  Great location in the heart of the action.  View out our window of the monument.  Easy parking.  No indoor pool was the only negative, but the exercise room was equipped well enough we didn't really miss it.The wife stayed there three days for a conference. She said the conference facilities were good but the food served through the conference was not very good. The room was a little on the small size with two queens (she shared a room). She noted the room had an "odd smell" that went away when she turned on the heat. Likely either a room that had not been used recently. She noted, while her room had a hot shower, a lot of her co-workers complained about cold showers. I asked if she would stay there again, if it was one her dime. "oh hell no" was her reply.Front Desk assured us of no construction noise, that's all we heard all day. Called down to front desk and the noise never stopped. Elevator noise also, so request a room far away from them.  Better yet if you want a place to get some sleep and rest. Go elsewhere.Horrible!!! Its after 11pm. We are staying in a suite at the hotel. And it seems there is a wedding reception venue somewhere in the general vicinity (Regions Bank tower). They knew our 17month old daughter was staying with us. But now no one can sleep because its like the horrible cover band is right in our room the music is so loud! Don't stay here or make sure you are as far from that venue as possible.Staying for a weekend trip in Indianapolis and booked directly through the hotel( did not use a travel site). The hotel failed to inform my wife and I that they were sponsoring an event that started at 7 am on Saturday and featured incredibly loud music and a loudspeaker. On the 11th floor and could hear every word like it was being broadcast directly into my room. Worse than staying at a hotel with construction.We were in town for the MEQ volleyball tournament. This was a great place to stay! I'm actually glad we didn't stay somewhere closer to the convention center since we've been exploring Indy on our walks to and from the convention center. This hotel had about everything we needed on site. And so much of downtown Indy was within easy walking distance in all directions. We parked the car on Friday night and haven't started it up since. Yes, they do charge for Internet in the rooms, the shower head was low flow, there is no free breakfast, and no mini fridge, but it was a great place to stay for our three nights in town. This is a beautiful hotel in a beautiful city with a very friendly staff!Stayed here during the convention time.  The hotel is located right next to the monument, which is a very short (about 3 blocks) to the skywalk, which connects to the mall and the convention center.  Odd number rooms have better view facing the monument while the suites are on the even number rooms.The hotel rooms are very clean, although it is a bit older style.  Typical Sheraton (pre renovation) decoration.  The lobby staffs were friendly and relax.  Its much more relax feeling than other Sheraton hotels in other metropolitan city.  However, the problem with this hotels are the lift.  One of the lift have that "Tower of Terror" feeling.  It pull up, then stop, then pull up again.  Its quite scary (one of the four).The A/C is a bit problematic too.  Since its centralized system, if it failed, entire building gets hot and humid or other way around.If the price is right, I will not be hesitate to stay here.I stayed here for a bachelorette party downtown and it was the perfect location! We were within walking distance to plenty of bars and the hotel is really nice. Our room had an incredible view of the fountain, however we had three rooms, none of which were on the same floor, so that was a little annoying. Overall, this place was clean and in the perfect location. Will definitely book this place if we ever need to stay downtown again!The location is great, and the hotel is what to expect for a 3 star hotel.  The reason I gave it a two star is how they nickle and dime their guest.  There are a lot of random charges that you might receive at this place.  Even the internet, which they give free to the public, charge you if you try and use it in the room.  For the cost per night of the room the internet should be included.  They also charge you 25 for parking (which is normal at all places dtown) and a random amount for breakfast.   This place is on par with other hotels in looks and niceness, but the way they try to continue and charge you once you are here really lowers the value.  When this is done it makes me feel as if I am in a one star hotel (cheap room) instead of a place that is suppose to be three stars.  They need to just charge one price and be done with it.
review_content_40: My husband booked a room here for my birthday.  We had a view of the circle.  We had dinner and saw a movie downtown before walkign back to our room.  We didn't take advantage of any of the hotel amenities - just enjoyed relazing in our room and sleeping in the next day.  The bed was comfortable, our room was nice, and we loved the view of the circle.Front desk staff was very friendly at check-in, however when I got up to take a shower to get ready there was no water.  I called downstairs and she told me that they were working on the hot water and the water would not be on until later in the day.  Her solution was to bring up room temp bottles of water.  She said she had called every room and left a message, I had no message I even double checked in case the blinking light on my phone wasn't working.  Not a way to start your day when you have to go to work and not shower.  Very poor planning.We arrived on Friday evening by a $40 cab ride from the airport. It was either a cab ride or renting a car at the airport and parking it here $20-30 per night. Had no issues checking in, was quite a breeze. The receptionist's name which starts with a R... with the Aussie accent of some sort was very friendly, cute, and all smiles.They put us up on the 16th floor. The room was clean and it did not entirely feel brand new but it definitely didn't feel like a poor college kid's dorm. I've stayed at much worse places and this one was pretty decent. We had an awesome view of The Soldier's & Sailor's monument. At night it would light up like a huge Xmas tree. Couldn't ask for a better view from my room. If you want this same view, try asking the receptionist when you check in. We didn't, we just got lucky.My only gripe with this establishment was the continuing sound of either the plumbing or the elevator noise throughout my stay in their room. I was able to deal with it but I'm sure it would drive some people up the wall. Speaking of walls, they are quite thin so you can easily hear those annoying kids running up and down the hallway playing tag at 0745am. If you plan on making noise in the room, you may want to heed this warning not unless you're an apathetic person.What's nice is that if you opt to not get your room made, they will give you a $5 credit that goes to any food establishment that is connected with the hotel. I'm not sure if it will work with the Starbucks (conveniently connected to the lobby downstairs) though. If you don't use it, you can add it to your SPG points when you check out. Bring that voucher!As for the location of the hotel, it's about a mile or so walk to Lucas Oil Stadium which was the whole point of my visit to Indy. If it's not raining or snowing, the walk isn't bad (it was about 30 degrees out). We didn't have a car, so we basically walked everywhere; to eat, shop, and do some sight seeing. Bust out them Nike Shox and just explore.For the right deal, I may consider this hotel again. If I come back for another Colts home game, I may want a hotel a bit closer to the stadium.My two nights came out to about $230ish through Expedia.No hot water this morning. You pay extra for basic wifi. Good location. Most staff are helpful. Mediocre food. Reasonable fitness center (but it doesn't provide sanitizing wipes to wipe down machines after use--ewww).LOVE the beds... THE room.. THE area... however.. after a day and a half there.. NO joke..I was ready to come undone.. I had a 310am wake up call.. about 11pm.. comes screaming children down the hall where I was already hearing the elevator all nite.. and I was not across from it.. I like the gym...but its stuffy.. I finally turned the old school ac down to 64 so i didnt have a heat stroke! haha.. bring ur water bottle and refill with cold fresh water in gym.. they have a cool bar.. decent room service.. and Starbucks on property.. as well as in the room. Lots to do within the radius of hotel.. wifi.. is not free.. but wink at the guy.. he'll give u the pass code.. I do like that I could call for housekeeping at 2pm..and they came ..after I slept my morning away.. Im a fan.. mostly...Everyone I knew who was staying at the Sheraton was in awe.  They were all staying in suites, and they probably were hypnotized by that grandeur.  It is a fine hotel, sure, but it is not nearly as nice as the Sheraton in Chicago.  If I were writing the AAA hotel book, this would be a 3 star hotel.The hallways are dark, with dated carpeting.  The room had a strange smell, which might have been Time.  The view of the circle and monument was lovely.  And the beds, well, they are immaculate.  There is free wireless, which is always wonderful.  The flat screen TVs are nice, but they have those in motels now...Service was friendly, but I requested a different room and it took 20 minutes for them to get me new keys.  My key card didn't work in the Club Lounge (as it should have).  I did appreciate the dried fruit and granola bars at breakfast in the Club Lounge.  If you can get a good deal (I did), I'd recommend the Sheraton, but I hope there are better "4" star hotels in Indianapolis!Seriously, Sheraton Indianapolis in City Centre?? Seriously? I'll just share what was awful about our stay here in July 2012:- $25 to self-park (or $30 to valet)- Old breakfast food sitting on a tray outside our door when we checked in. Gross.- Dance moms and their daughters running around loudly (while we had a baby sleeping at midnight)- Random pieces of plywood covering parts of the hallway- 15 minute wait for an elevator- Unattended workout/fitness area with kids playing on all the machines- Smelly room- The Starbucks wasn't open during key times on the weekend- The pool photos advertised on the site look NOTHING like the real pool. The real (small) pool had a few random chairs surrounding the murky water. A million kids playing in it.With that being said...we paid way too much for 2 nights  for such a crappy place. I understand that the location is great but really?DO NOT STAY AT THIS HOTEL!!!! My fiance and I had thousands of dollars worth of stuff stolen from this hotel. Management never apologized or acted concerned at all. When the police were taking the police report he said this happens all the time at this hotel. He said that people from the streets walk up and down the halls checking for doors that haven't fully shut. It feels horrible to have your space violated by a stranger and have your stuff stolen. It is worse to have the people that were suppose to have taken care of your things act so poorly and never apologize or seem surprised.DO NOT STAY AT THIS HOTEL!Stayed here with my cousin on St. Patrick's Day weekend.  He is a frequent business traveler and has access to the Club Lounge.  I am really sorry I did not get her name, but the woman taking care of the Club Lounge on Sunday March 16,2014 is an exceptional employee.We arrived about 30-45 minutes before happy hour ended, and sometimes you might expect someone to start cleaning up, the woman here went out of her way to make sure we had whatever we could have wanted, and was especially nice to my cousin's son, making sure he felt special and taken care of.Sometimes it's seemingly little gestures that mean a lot, and the employees here seem to understand that.Wife booked a room here. We had not seen each other for several months so looking really forward to this stay. Booked King bed 7 weeks in advance. Upon checking in (30 minute process) was informed there were only twin beds available. Lobby was congested of teenage kids that were loud and obnoxious. Housekeeping was poor. Parking garage meter would not read our ticket. Staff didn't really seem to care rather you stayed with them or not. LOOK ELSEWHERE. You can do much better than this place.Location is excellent. Parking garage is easy to navigate. Price wasn't outrageous. Housekeeping was so-so...they didn't restock all of our towels and coffee items.  Reserved 7 weeks ahead of our trip - requested a king got two full size beds. 7 weeks in advance seems enough time to guarantee a bed preference.  Bathtub didn't drain.  Parking garage exit kept malfunctioning.  Front desk staff was unorganized and didn't seem to care about our preferences.  We stay at Sheraton hotels when we travel...this is the worst Sheraton we've stayed at.Great location and $25 a day parking w a Starbucks thrown in for good measure! We were in 1602 for a week and could view the parade prep for the Memorial Day celebrants. Large tv generous bedding, good temp control made this a comfy place to sleep. The two stars were unfortunately due to a lack of service in a couple areas. The room wasn't cleaned each day and the trash piled up. You can opt not to have your room cleaned for points....we just wanted towel and basic soap needs, we reported it twice to room services to no improvement. No ice is avail unless you call front desk. No room service either. Valet is fairly energetic...kudos!bartender couldn't make a basic bourbon n soda did sub ginger ale?. Front desk didn't key our card correctly and we really got a bit overwhelmed w the poor cleaning and service. Can't recommend this location. Note that we did not opt for the Green program. We had room cleaned partially one night , room cleaned very well one time, the third day we had privacy sign n didn't expect room service, next day no service, next day after that, no service. Each time the room should have been cleaned, I called and was offered points to make up for it. The one day I visited front desk n asked if they could clean the room they sent towels n soap, no surfaces were cleaned. That was the day after we had a note saying the head of housekeeping would personally see the room cleaned. At one time the desk said it looked like we had opted out of cleaning. We said no we hadn't. N if that WAS the case, where were the five dollar reward vouchers?. To this moment the hotel denies that they have a problem n it must be the misguided customers' fault!As far as hotels/lodging are concerned, I have very specific tastes and preferences. This particular establishment was EXACTLY what I try to find. when I speak of quality lodging. The low priced budget places along with the high end luxury places are both really not my bag. This place had the following going for it:1) Very clean2) Staff was very friendly and helpful3) Our room was in very good condition4) Our bed was very comfortable5) It was VERY close in proximity to all of the things we wanted to see6) Good value for the moneyThis place had the following things wrong with my visit:1) NothingGreat job folks! Looking forward to my next visit to Indy!Stayed here in the "club" lever and it was horrible. The room was small and had stains on the curtains and chair. Only 2 of the 4 elevators worked and one of them didn't have a working light. As far as the "club" part it wasn't anything to advertise.  Will never stay here againI was here 2 times now and the staff has been excellent. We got upgraded to club status and we had a gorgeous view of the monument circle. The hallways and doors you can tell are old, but the room with a king size bed, with beautiful, comfortable sheets and pillows were the best. Bathroom upgraded as well with granite and with a new flat screen TV. But the best is their fitness room at the top of the building and there are 4 elevators with easy access to their parking from there. This Sheraton is great but we had discount from the IU med center, so we paid 96 dollars for 1 night stay, complimentary breakfast, and upgrade to club status, with free paring. I don't know how much it is without a discounted rate, but it must be expensive.We have stayed here three or four times over the last couple of years.  Though we live in Indianapolis, we've done a few date nights and stayed here so we could be right downtown, and more recently stayed here for a wedding so we wouldn't have to worry about driving home afterwards.  The service here has always lived up to the standards I expect from Sheraton, and the rooms are always clean and nice.  As always, the Sheraton beds are pretty much the best ever.  In the summer, the rooftop pool is absolutely awesome, and as this hotel sits right on the circle, I don't think there is a bad view possible.  Even if you aren't using the pool, I suggest going out on the pool deck just to check out the sweet view.  During this stay I visited the hotel bar briefly and the bartender was awesome.  She made it so that I would drop by for a drink even if not staying here.  It was a bummer that there was no room service after 11pm, but it worked out as they have a convenience store in the lobby that is open 24hrs.  Potato chips to the rescue!As is a problem with all Sheraton's, you do you have to pay for internet, though I believe they have a business center where you can use a computer with internet for no charge.  Regardless, I feel that with the money spent for a room at a Sheraton, included wifi would be a nice touch.  Parking is also more than a bit spendy at $25 a night to self-park in the garage.There are a couple of fancier hotels in downtown Indy but this hotel is nice and the people are very friendly. There's a Starbucks right in the hotel, an outdoor pool on the 9th floor, and the hotel allows dogs so we're able to bring our puppy to stay with us. You can access the parking garage from the hotel elevators, making for an easier pack in/pack out.This was a good place to stay in the heart of Indy.  The staff made us feel special by getting us a great view of the Monument, the best feature of the hotel, and gave good advice on area restaurants.  The rooftop pool overlooking the city was a nice feature, though it's a bit spartan.  On the downside the wifi and parking were both expensive, $12.50 and $25 a day respectively.  If you take that into account before booking then this hotel is good value for its location and view.This was definitely an OK hotel for business or leisure travelers. As far as I could tell, this place is pretty much as close to "everything" Indy has to offer... whatever that may be. Comfortable bed, big TV, speedy room service even though the food isn't that good. I particularly enjoyed the convenience of Starbuck's in the lobby. The shuttle ride from the airport was $16 dollars - a steal in my book! Mind you, this is not a hotel shuttle, this was a private shuttle. I was extremely disappointed that the INDOOR pool was closed. I'm from California so that thought of closing a pool for any reason other than an illness outbreak seems completely irrational to me, the woman in guest services said that the pool was "not yet open for the summer." I was puzzled. Because it is May afterall. Regardless, my stay was comfortable and the staff was friendly. I'm not an SPG member, but they put me on the SPG floor and treated me very well. I'd definitely stay here again if I ever had to come back to Indy.I've stayed here a handful of times. The most recent time I have a complaint.Stupid United Airlines delayed my flight from Denver by 4 hours (oh, there was no weather, they just wanted to demonstrate how incompetent an airline they are) and I didn't get to the hotel until a little after 3 a.m. The next morning when breakfast comes the maids are already coming down the hall at 9:30 a.m. so I put the "please do not disturb" sign on my door while I eat and shower. I carefully and very deliberately took the sign off when I left a little after 10.It was a Friday, I'd been on the road all week, I was exhausted. I'm not a diva, or whatever, but I'd flown 8,000 miles in a week through six cities and was really looking forward to... just a shower  and a made bed at the end of a brutal week.I opened the door and... the room had not been cleaned. I'd had the "do not disturb" sign on the door for all of maybe 30 minutes that morning. I called the front desk and they said "you had the sign on your door."  If I take a shower in the morning and don't want the maid to hang out with me naked then you refuse to clean my room? You had 14 hours for someone to clean it. It smelled like... food. The meal, which I'd not finished because I was too exhausted to really eat, was emitting odors. No fresh towels. No water. No made bed.When you're paying over $200 a night, having your room cleaned is not some outrageous indulgence. After I called they sent someone up to take the food away and bring me a towel, but the room smelled gross all night.The location is fine for Indy, I guess, but Indy's City Center is not really that great. I've never been here when the pool was open. If it ever is open it looks like fun. I'm going to ding the hotel for charging me for a $500 stay that didn't come with a clean room.  It was a smelly reminder that Sheraton is really a second-class or third-class chain of hotels.
review_content_60: This hotel definitely gets the nod as being Indianapolis' most unwanted bald-headed step child, given the number of name changes this old dusty clunker has had in the past 40 years--The Hilton, Hotel Marriott, The Radisson, Sheraton....  It's not a bad hotel, but you get what you pay for here...and that may either be a good thing or a bad thing.The first thing you notice is the old parking garage--the dark, damp garage that the hotel rests on.  I love being pampered while on a getaway trip and wouldn't mind spending a few dollars more to enjoy indulgence.  Take it from me: self-park and don't do the valet parking.  The valet and self-park use the same garage.  Valet is so expensive, too.  Well, so is self-park, but it's noticeably cheaper than valet charge and tip every time you want your car.The rooms are pretty nice.  No, this is not the Conrad or the Canterbury Hotel.  You do not get Molton & Brown, L'Occitane beauty products or Egyptian cotton towels.  But my room was wonderful, clean and stocked with all the crunchy starched cheap white towels I could use.  For $89/night (versus $200+ for rooms at Conrad!), the quality, location and pleasant personalities of the hotel staff far surpassed my expectations.  A special shout to the weekend hotel operator, Mark--thanks, man for being so friendly.Of course this being a hotel and not my mother's guest bedroom, you have to have a level of acceptance that yes, your comforter may have a tiny icky pink spot on it; yes, one of the bath towels may have a very faint yellow stain on it; yes, the hotel restaurant is only a couple notches above a Denny's in food quality.  But those are things I am willing to overlook for an affordable room with a spectacular Monument Circle view.Stayed here in Nov 08 during a B.O. canvassing roadtrip to Indianapolis. This is a very nice Sheraton - we're SPG members and always stay in their properties no matter what city and Sheratons don't always tend to do very well in terms of service and customer satisfaction.. but this one does a very good job. Great location, to start with. The staff is friendly and helpful. The rooms are nice (we had an upgraded suite though) and the room was clean and everything else was also in well-working condition!I was recently at the Sheraton for a conference. Thankfully, I didn't stay there but I was disappointed still. The parking garage is a claustrophobia inducing, semi run down cluster...well, you get the idea. :) One of the parking ticket receipt machines you use to leave the garage was broken the entire three days I was there and you had to use the intercom & wait on someone to let you out. Also, the bathroom near the meeting rooms was a tad janky. Broken, hanging toilet paper holders and soap less soap dispensers all three days of the conference made me wonder if any employees had even stepped foot in there. :( So, what made me give the hotel 3 stars, you ask? The staff! I had to pay for parking at the desk to get the special conference parking rate and the staff was friendly, efficient, and happy! Verdict: Wonderful staff, but I held them to higher standards and wouldn't stay there.The Indianapolis Sheraton is pretty much on par with other Sheraton's across the land.Great beds, nice sized and clean rooms. There is a roof top pool that overlooks the skyline and the circle. The only real thing I dislike about this particular Sheraton is the parking. It's a standard downtown parking garage with a $25 over night fee. A lot of others have similar parking, but I feel like this might be the most expensive overnight Sheraton parking I've had. If you're looking for a nice place to stay in downtown Indy within walking distance of pretty much all of downtown Indy, look no further.I will say this hotel is very clean. However, the wi fi in the room is very expensive. They do have a business center, but it is in the bar. Which is very unusual.   They put my friend and i both in rooms by the elevators. She on the 19th floor and me on the 14th. All night long you hear everything with the elevators, it gives you a headache after too long. My friend went down to have her room changed because, it was driving her mad. So instead they shut off the  elevators till 6:00am!      Which at that time it woke me up when it started up again. No hotel should have  rooms by the elevators, they know how loud it is.  Also on Sunday nothing is open inside the hotel even Starbucks was closed at 3 in the afternoon. It could be worse though ,right.Wasn't terrible, but I would probably try a different hotel next time.First, the positives: As others have mentioned, the staff is very nice and accommodating. I didn't have a *ton* of interaction with staff, but enough to know that they take pride in customer service. The concierge helped me out with my parking issue (see below), which I greatly appreciated. We stayed in a corner king room, which was pretty spacious and well-decorated. The bed was comfortable & I slept OK. I did use the room's iron and was pleased that it was a newer hotel iron and worked just the way it should---not a given in other hotels that I've stayed in!Negatives: Paper-thin walls and doors. I felt like I could hear every movement of the people in the room next door and had to keep the TV on to drown out the noise. They weren't being loud or anything, just getting dressed, I guess? I kept waking up because it sounded like someone was in *our* hotel room rifling through our stuff. I feel like most of the sound came through the door that allowed us to turn the hotel room into an adjoining room. Parking --- I drive a 4Runner with a Yakima roof rack installed. So, okay, it *is* a big vehicle but I would absolutely not call it over-sized. I don't normally have issues parking in parking garages, but my vehicle could not fit into the Sheraton's garage. Luckily it was a weekend and street (meter) parking was free and allowed overnight. Otherwise I would have been pretty screwed.This is minor. I probably should have called the front desk and I'm sure they would have taken care of this. But I guess I'll mention that our TV seemed to not be programmed properly. The remote control did not work at all, and the channel numbers did not match what was printed on the guide. So we had a tough time flipping channels to find the one we wanted. But, we found this out when we got in around 11 PM and I wasn't about to call anyone to fix it.Also, the TV set was a "standard definition" 27 inch-ish tube TV and not anything big or fancy. Wasn't a deal breaker for me, but others might care about this.Again, this is probably something I could've & should've called the front desk about, but I'll also mention that our room's air conditioner seemed unable to reach the set temperature on the thermostat. Our room stayed at a solid 75 degrees-ish during our stay and never dropped to the more-comfortable set temperature of 71. Wasn't a huge deal, but I wasn't quite as comfortable as I otherwise would've been.Finally, the bathroom: didn't affect me because I am short, but the shower head was only about 5 feet 9 inches off the ground. I'd imagine that this would be a problem for a tall individual. Also, the bathroom had no exhaust fan. This meant showers made the room even more hot & humid. Also, if anyone decided to make any stinkys, the other occupant(s) in the room got to enjoy it.Very nice hotel with a friendly and helpful staff.  The only drawback, as stated in some of the other posts is that it is not connected to the convention center through covered walkways, but a brisk morning walk is a good way to wake up!I get called out by name in boutique hotels, never at a Sheraton but it was "Mr. G-" from the front desk staff for the few days I stayed here in August. And not only are they friendly but accomodating: they managed a few fussy room requests without blinking.Hotel location is great - right near the circle - and the view of the courthouse and monuments from my corner room was terrific. A taxi was always available out front and the embedded Starbucks means you don't need to wander Indy's squeaky clean streets for a FrappuccinoBut then there's the club room. It's cozy and a good place to work in the afternoon but charging $9 for a glass of wine? And from a server who didn't speak English (that's not some xenophobia, she didn't speak or seem to understand English at all). And she didn't know how to open the wine bottle. And wasn't comfortable actually pouring wine. Kinda bizarre. Don't get me wrong - you know I'm no cheapskate - but if you're going to turn the club room into a bar you might as well bring in better wine (what was that? Mirrasou?). In all though: a good business hotel experience with decent rates and the ability to rack up more Starwood points.First, I need to point out that this review has nothing to do with an overnight stay and everything to do with dealing with the catering/events department. Oy.So to start, my first time here was for an event through my work was in a fantastic space, the panorama room overlooking Monument Circle. Great space. Most things went well except it was the hottest day of the summer in July 2011 and they could not get the temperature below 82 degrees in the room which was confusing and disappointing since it was just an appetizer event and just so uncomfortable... especially for the cost. Then there's the food. Not horrible for catering appetizers, but not the best. Most annoying part was running out, never getting it refilled and still being charged for the refills. The second attempt here, also work-related, was for a dinner buffet event. Same room, but in January so it wasn't hot at least. This time I did 100% of the planning and figured that it should be much smoother this time, then I learned where the problem lies, the catering people. I literally sent 4 emails and discussed on the phone 3 times about requiring a cash bar for our event, no cash bar. Ironically, the food was much better and more organized and for a much better price since they do negotiate, but the fact that every single beverage other than water and iced tea had to be brought up from the bar on the lobby level 20 some floors below was just tacky. Then you have dealing with the bill. The food part worked out fine, but the A/V was another issue. We were quoted $125 for everything we needed, but somehow ended up paying nearly $600 for the dumbest things that I did not see coming and were not notified about in advance, like $15 to use an easel. Then with the billing, the receipts provided didn't exactly match the charges, each was off by $100 which broke even, but not easy to deal with when having to submit on a company credit card. Which I called to get it corrected 3 times and 2 emails and finally asked for the general manager just to get his voicemail. Then I learn that the person who was avoiding me actually thought that everything was fine and admitted to just not looking at my emails. I work a lot with event planning, but when I practically have to do the job for you, I should be getting credit for that.So my loooong moral of the story is that please read other reviews about overnight stays, but when it comes to hosting an event here, proceed with caution. I would have had an easier time working with a 1/2 star hotel with no meeting space compared to this disorganized insanity. Our events downtown are now being held elsewhere.We stayed at the down town Sheraton this past weekend. The room was smelly. The elevator old and a little scary. The AC was total crap. The pool is over sold. But the hotel is right there near City Center and all that there is to offer.Stinks out front but that's a municipal problem not specifically the hotel's issues (it stinks everywhere in this city). Very centrally located on the circle - lots of food options, entertainment, and local attractions within walking distance. Downsides were the Starbucks AC was not working (and hasn't been working for weeks), the pool is on floor 9 but the club floor is on 10 and the gym is in the basement (not convenient). There is a little convenience market in the lobby and lots of seating with free wifi downstairs. I didn't get put on the club floor since they were full so I can't comment on those amenities, but it looked nice from what I saw. The rooms were typical Sheraton rooms, but the view of the circle was great. The only real problem was that the wifi was shite, the housekeeping didn't bother to check my extended checkout time (kept trying to enter my room multiple times without knocking! - Hate it when they do that). The gym was crappy too (no AC, TVs didn't work, small space/not a lot of variety), but I guess a lot of people don't use the gym too much on travel. Front desk agents are very pleasant and were very helpful in recommending atypical things to do and places to eat.My mom always said if you have nothing good to say don't say anything. I am not following that advice. First the bed - it was about as comfortable as a roll away cot. It would squeak every time my wife or I rolled over. It was a lumpy pos. The room - small and musty. It did have a nice view of the circle though. The bathroom - smaller than my closet at home. If you are over 5'7" or so the shower head will be too low for you. Club room - this was ok. Musty smell but the staff here was nice. 21st floor party - we were here for a wedding reception. They could not get the room cool. It was HOT. The food was good, but when you are so hot it is hard to eat.Service - the staff was great. If it was just about staff this would be a 4 star review. Sadly the property is run down so we only give 2 stars.A-OK is right. Bummed that the pool wasnt working.. in 90degree+ weather in September! Rooms were pretty nice, conference rooms were large. The staff wasn't incredibly helpful or professional- get them trained!It's obvious that this used to be a pretty good hotel. The location is good and the lobby is nicely appointed. The staff were friendly and helpful. The rooms were ok but the air conditioning rattled badly and the entire floor (10th) smelled faintly of mildew and mold. There were also odd holes in the walls that were covered by huge sheets of painted plywood. Very strange for a "nice" hotel. The pool area was abysmal. Huge pool area but the poor itself was no bigger than your standard backyard pool. Not nearly enough chairs or chaise lounges around the pool either. Seems like for the price you are paying for a nice lobby and the location.It honestly pains me to lower my rating of this particular hotel. I've stayed here probably about a half dozen times, and have always been pleased. This last visit may prevent me from ever considering a future stay at this particular Sheraton.We checked in this past Saturday for a two night stay. We were here for the Colts game, and used our AMEX Starwood points, and were given one of the old, non remodeled rooms with two double beds. I normally would not have a problem with this, seeing as though we were technically not paying customers as we used our points; BUT, we were promised a King when we reserved over two months ago...A little upset, but not overly concerned, and not contemplating a complaint, we started to get ready for dinner. After about a half hour in the room, we realized that the heat was not working. The room was frigid, and there was a healthy draft coming in through the window. I figured the hotel was booked, seeing as though we were placed in a crappy room, on an outdated floor.I called the Front Desk, and was greeted by the rude, condescending jerk of an employee, "Adrian." Adrienne was a real jewel. I informed him / her that our room had no heat. He didn't seem to care, offered no apology, and said  the hotel was at "capacity." But, the Customer Service pro that he / she is, Adrienne offered to have a space heater brought up to our room! A "space heater" I responded. He said "yes, a space heater." ME: Okay, leave it outside the room as we're getting ready for dinner.ADRIENNE: No, I can't do that as it may end up in someone else's room.ME: {Laughs} Seriously? Okay, can you please bring it up soon, before we leave for dinner, as I don't want anyone in our room when we're gone?ADRIENNE: Yep. {Hangs up phone}Dear Adrienne: Starwood will be notifying you soon, my friend! I would place the odds on the used points from this past weekend being refunded to our account in the very near future.I rarely review anything other than food establishments, but I had to make a mention of this place. My friend and I stayed there over the Indy 500 weekend (for unconnected reasons) and were surprised at what a great hotel the Sheraton was.The building must have gone under some renovation since past reviews, because the carpets, comforters, towels, and even desks and dressers all felt new. The service was great. The front desk staff were very helpful and accommodating when we needed to stay longer than the check-out time (Especially impressive since this was the busiest weekend of the year in Indianapolis.).The difference between valet parking and self parking was only three bucks, and the valets were fantastically friendly and capable; so the extra couple of bucks is definitely worth it. I was a little annoyed that there was a fee for in-room wireless, but that was a minor trouble in a very comfortable stay.I travel to Indy quite often for work, the Sheraton isn't the 'newest/nicest' hotel downtown but the staff is amazing, friendly, and they go above and beyond. The Sheraton also has a great bar, let's face it when you are traveling on business the hotel bar becomes your second home!If you are a Sheraton member you'll get access to the 10th floor club room, happy hour (free) and a nice breakfast...oh, and chocolate chip cookies baked fresh every night...yummmy!Ask for a king corner room, nice and spacious with a great view of the circle.The outdoor pool is a great feature, especially on a nice evening - it's on the 9th floor and overlooks downtown.Wi-Fi is free in the lobby (and the bar) but you pay in your room and it's not wireless.I'm writing this review from a fairly different perspective. We not only stayed here for several nights, but also had our wedding reception here - on the 21st floor in the Panorama Room. Initially, we looked at a lot of hotels and other establishments for our downtown wedding and finally settled on the Sheraton b/c we felt the Panorama Room had the most character (floor to ceiling windows throughout the entire room, overlooking the city and monument circle, breathtaking views) and the price was the most reasonable. The wedding day, itself, was awesome. Smooth sailing. No problems on the Sheraton's end (that I know of anyway!) The planning process was quite different. We were shifted between 3 different catering mangers during the planning - which made me a little bit uncomfortable b/c once I would establish a relationship with one manager, that manager would leave. A LOT of information got lost b/t the 3 managers so I felt like I was starting from scratch with each new contact. And email communication was poor - they very rarely replied unless I sent follow-up emails. Very disorganized, frustrating, and not the most professional (especially considering that we were going to be bringing in thousands of dollars of revenue for them!) Also, there were a few instances when one of our catering managers lied to us. I could go into the long story of what she lied to us about, but not worth anybody's time. Not just white lies, bold face lies. Sort of ridiculous actually. As far as our stay, it was mediocre. The rooms were mediocre, clean and nicely kept, but just mediocre for a downtown hotel. The 'discounted' wedding rate for our guests was actually not so discounted either. Many of our guests made reservations a few weeks prior to our wedding for $30 - 40 cheaper than our wedding block rate. Also, on our wedding night, we stayed in one of their wedding "suites" which is really just a king size suite (nothing special), but the toliet flushed endlessly. It wouldn't stop. And this was not a quiet toliet. It was a commerical-type toliet, so it was loud. We kept thinking that it would stop. But after 25 minutes of listening to the toliet flush, we had to ask to be moved to a different room. Imagine how frustrating it would be to be moved (on your wedding night!) to a different room at 1am. Ugh. Okay, so a quick list of pros/cons Pros: -The Panorama Room was beautiful! One of the best views in town! Great room to have our wedding reception. Our wedding reception seemed be flawless - very organized and professional on our wedding day.-All my guests said they had a good stay at the Sheraton - they loved the easy access to the mall, bars, restaurants, starbucks, etc. Cons:-unprofessional, unorganized catering managers (during the planning process anyway)-broken toliet; flushed endlessly on our wedding night! frustrating. not to mention a BIG waste of water.- the "discounted wedding block rate" for our guests was really "discounted". More expensive actually.the most run down dumpiest Sheraton i have ever stayed inGreat hotel for short stay. My room had a wonderful view of the monument circle. The breakfast in the club lounge was also great. I had a very pleasant stay here. But a few things i didn't like: the light in the hallway is dim; the elevators look old and are kinda slow.
review_content_80: I have stayed here about 6 times over the last 2 years.  The staff is super friendly and the location is awesome.  They accept pets with no deposit which I think is great as I love to travel with my four legged buddy.  The rooms are pretty good - standard fare but nicely done.  They look to have been remodeled fairly recently.  Housekeeping is great and does a good job.Great location, very clean, comfy beds and pillows!  I would definitely stay again.I've stayed at this hotel a few times and my experience has been excellent.  Yes it's not as flashy as the Omni, but the prices are excellent, rooms well appointed and amenities are decent.  I stayed on the Club level which provicdes free snacks and beer from 4:30-7:30 M-F (its a business hotel).  The staff are attentive and friendly and it's close to the circle so you can walk pretty much anywhere.   You can grab a beer in the bar for $4, can't beat that for a bar in a hotel.Okay hotel downtown, just a little run downI'm a repeat customer to this one. Not really because of the great service or anything, but because of the really low rate I was able to snag here thru Hotwire. I've stayed here during GenCon. Usually, hotel rates for anything within half a mile of the convention center are around $150+ per night. I got the room at the Sheraton for much less.I'll agree with what others have said about the parking garage. Self park is extortion, and valet even moreso. Still, it's pretty much the going rate for hotel parking downtown. There are other parking options in the area. Check those out before parking at the Sheraton garage.The room itself seemed pretty clean. I do remember, though, one night I had a sheet with a small hole in it. I specifically left a card on the pillow indicating I wanted the sheets and towels changed. When I came back the next night, I found the same small hole on the sheet. Even though I left the card. Even though I left a tip for the cleaning service.I'll echo earlier reviews about noise problems. The air conditioning system is noisy. Apparently, one of my neighbors was having coughing/puking problems, and those woke me up a lot during the night. Thin walls. Note to self: bring earplugs.There is a Starbucks on the first floor. Came in handy when recovering from a hangover.The breakfast buffet is average. There's a fair spread of eggs, meats, pastries, bagels, cereal, fruits and such. I went to Le Peep most of the time for breakfast.Count me among those annoyed by the lack of free in-room wireless. It is available on the first floor, though, in the main lobby.For $70-$80 a night, the stay was worth it. I will be staying there again this August, but again, more for the cost savings than anything else.Wow. This is not your father's Sheraton. I stayed here last night for a business trip. NOT coming back. Why?Noisy AC/Heat Vent? Check (let's see, do I freeze to death or have a sleepless night cuz of that rattle from the fan?)Runny, oily hash browns with your $33 room service breakfast? CheckSoap scum in bathtub? Check.Smirking, wise-a** desk attendant? Check.$2.25 bottled water at the convenience store? Check.Thin doors/walls so you can hear your neighbors and passers-by every wink and nod? Check.All for the comfy rate of $245/night plus tons of taxes, fees, tips, etc.That said, the lobby and elevators are really nice. But there are plenty of other choices in downtown Indianapolis.This is my second stay. This time I was here 5 nights. I was in a king suite (1510) and did not suffer from any noise problems as reported by other travelers. However, there was tons of noise coming from busy Ohio Street including sirens, motorcycles, etc. The room is nice, bed is comfy and I enjoyed the little extras such as the micro & fridge. Location is handy to plenty of downtown shops and restaurants. There are computers and a printer for guest use in the bar area that were easily accessible.  My only complaints are the painful check-in/front desk staff and the slow elevators.  Check in time is 3pm and even though I'd made my reservations months in advance, I didn't get to check into my room until after 5pm and that was only because I was hovering in the lobby.  I'd been traveling for over 14 hours and just wanted a shower.  I did get a wifi password out of the deal, so I saved some $$.  The front desk area was always understaffed it seemed.  Despite 4 elevators, several times during the week there were lines for the elevators.  It never seemed like all 4 were in operation.  There's 1 express elevator that goes from the lobby to the 21st floor direct which is handy but still slow to arrive.When I visited INDY for the first time to celebrate my brother's last week in the US before shipping off for the military. We found this place by default. Meaning I picked him up from the base and did a 40 minute drive back to the city. We decided to go to the first hotel we found. This one if first class and not just because of it's looks. We went inside (LATE) and it was obvious my brother was military - you know the bag.. the hat. Anyway went inside after parking and the night manager was beyond classy, as was the desk man. They gave us a great rate for military soldiers, comped our car for the week- although it never really left the garage except to go to easley winery. This place is city center so we walked everywhere. Plus we had a higher floor, meant to visit the gym and pool but never did. Did the complimentary breakfast that place (the club room) is to die for.. I need one of those. The room, beautiful. Five stars in my book. Oh, and the last day we visited their bar. The last night I had to stay myself because my brother shipped the next day so I went to the bar and met a few new friends and the bartender was comporting, complimentary.. a million nice words.

review_content: In love with this property! It is a true star in the JW Marriott portfolio. Let's start from the beginning-Parking-valet or self park for a lesser charge in a garage beneath the hotel.  The greeters at the door are very welcoming and have a smile on their face. Check-in- Friendly and efficient, took about 5 minutes from walking in to getting to the room. There was water mixed with different fruit out in the lobby which was very refreshing, there is also a Starbucks on the 2nd floor! Room-Standard king room on a high floor that was perfectly clean/kept with updated amenities and in-room features with a beautiful view of the river/park. There was a small plumbing issue in the bathroom upon arrival but the FD sent someone immediately and it was fixed when I came back to the room. The manager also sent a breakfast voucher which was wonderful recovery!The Bar-Great atmosphere for a cozy conversation during the afternoon or watching a game on the big screen. Enjoyed a couple cocktails with a very helpful bartender! It was slow when it first opened for the night and I had trouble deciding on a drink so he asked what I liked and crafted one himself! Breakfast-So many options in their buffet! Eggs, waffles, meats, biscuits, fruits, you name it! If i ever go back I will go with a bigger appetite than I did. The server was nice in giving recommendations for nearby restaurants/attractions as well. Surroundings-so many things to do! Everything is in walking distance or you can even rent a bike/segway to make your way around downtown. The zoo is a beautiful walk over the bridge, there are paddle boat rentals across the street, a comedy show theater, there's a plethora of dining/bar options nearby along with boutique shopping. It is one of the nicest downtown scenes i've ever explored!I'll be staying here if I get to return to the city!While I was in Indy for work I stayed here. Overall the hotel was nice, easy to get to and from the airport. The location was great for the convention center and a little walk to the mall/downtown. The hotel itself had two restaurants on the main floor which was nice as you always felt like there was something happening. On the second floor there was a nice looking gym and a starbucks. The staff was always friendly and eager to assist. The room itself was very nice and spacious. I had a king size room on the 22nd floor. The view was pretty however you could hear a lot of street noise on the 22nd floor. The shower was one of those three head showers you could opt in to use if you wanted. One thing that I've been running into is the cleaning staff and the inconsistency. Some days the staff would come early and other days they would be much later. Some days they would double up on my lotion/shampoo/etc. Other days they wouldn't replenish my tea or water. Overall this is a nice Marriott and I would be happy to stay there again.My bride (now wife) surprised me on my wedding night with a hotel reservation at the JW Marriott.  We dipped out of the reception around 10:30pm arriving at the JW Marriott at 11:00pm.  We arrived in Tux and Wedding gown.  Everyone from around the lobby was yelling congrats as we walked up to the front desk.  The attendant at the desk was having trouble with the computer system and left for quite some time.  We began to get worried and for good reason.The manager came out with the other employee to inform us that our reservation had been sold to someone else.  They handed me a voucher for 2 breakfast buffets and offered to put us up in the Residence Inn.  A very cold "Sorry, but there is nothing I can do".  I was left speechless, my wife was in tears,My wife had booked this reservation months ago.  She was actually enticed to book our wedding night at the JW through a special they run for all newly wed couples.  Beware, booking a reservation may not mean you have a reservation as we found out.  The JW Marriott was 100% aware that it was our wedding night!We walked to the front door in embarrassment and people were now calling out to us "Where are you going?!".  The answer not here.The view! We stayed on the 33rd floor and could see victory field, the zoo, white river and the canal. Our room was amazing, it was a single king sized bed. The bathroom had only a shower but the shower had 3 shower heads, I could have stayed in there forever. We enjoyed dinner at Osteria Pronto and everything was delicious we had the steak and sea bass. I highly recommend eating there. Since I am 9 months pregnant, we ordered room service later and that would be my only complaint. The room service only deserves 2 stars. Our burger was cold, dry and over cooked. Our salad came with the wrong dressing and we had fruit stuck to the bottom of our plates. The breakfast buffet at Osteria Pronto the next morning was truly amazing, the best breakfast buffet I have ever enjoyed at a hotel.Stayed at the JW Marriott a few weeks back for a tradeshow in Indy. Very close to the convention center, large bar/lounge area, plus a restaurant and additional sports bar.I found the staff friendly, rooms nice/clean and the shower was hot - I don't really ask for a lot more :)Service was a bit slow in the hotel bar, but there was a lot going on that week/weekend, so understandable. Signature cocktails were awesome, though.Would definitely go back.The staff at JW Marriott is a well oiled machine of professionals who keep their cool and follow up to ensure all flows smoothly for those planning events and meetings. Each of the staff members I interacted with provided VIP service and made our 3 day stay flow seamlessly.  The views from the upper levels are breathtaking, whether overlooking Indianapolis Indians' Victory Field or The White River Canal.  The luxury bedding made me want to  hit snooze forever!  I must admit that getting around from conference rooms and levels can be somewhat confusing, but the signage provided by the event staff generally gets you where you need to go.  If there's one area that my guests commented on most, it was the catering menus, which were clearly prepared differently than our last meeting at the JW.  Perhaps there was a new chef, but they weren't at all impressed with the options provided, outside of the fresh seafood bar that I ordered for our reception.  After (several) long days in a conference room, I certainly appreciated the Concierge lounge at the end of the day for pick me up snacks and adult beverages.  A big thanks to the entire staff for always looking out and being ready to assist!Very nice hotel and a most attentive staff. We went on our honeymoon and were treated like royalty. Put us up on the 32nd floor, gave us the romance package with chocolate dipped strawberries and champagne. We also received two complimentary breakfast buffets in the restaurant on site. It was amazing, with a waffle bar and an omelette bar. The pool was nice, but small. Hot tub was great. I also liked the hi-rise elevators! Those scream all the way up!! It's like a thrill ride!  Also, valet is on top of things. We never waited more than 5 minutes for our vehicle, and on that note, we also had great room service. Anyways. Overall impression was it's a very nice hotel. Just too bad Indy is becoming a sort of gang neighborhood. 20 cops arresting gang members in Circle Centre and 2 cops arresting gang members 2 blocks from the hotel.Definitely a fancy hotel. And while I've not stayed here, I did take advantage of the restrooms, the meeting facilities and the lobby at various times during the conferences I was attending in Indianapolis. The conference rooms themselves are well appointed and there are a number of different configurations that can be used for different styles of events. The restrooms are large and well maintained. The lobby is crowded but otherwise useful.My one complaint is that the entrance to the hotel on ground level (the one not via pedway) is really oriented to car traffic rather than pedestrian traffic which is frustrating when one doesn't want to get here via the pedway from the convention center.New York in Indianapolis. Beautiful room with the nicest of linens, soft towels, high quality soaps and exceptional service. Walking distance to Lucas Oil Stadium and downtown if you like a short hike. Parking cost was also New York caliber. We grabbed a quick bite in the bar/restaurant. Was not impressed. I'm usually not a fussy eater but the bun was like cardboard and inedible. Meat was dry. I expected so much more for what it cost. Left without eating half of it. Recommend finding another place to catch a bite.Excellent location! Location location! The service was great! Their gym is also great valueHonestly probably one of the top hotels at which I've ever stayed.  I stayed here for a conference and received a King room on a high floor with a view of the city (the park is the other view option).  I LOVE the city view which overlooks downtown Indy and I even got to watch the sunrise from my window waking up the first day. Fanstastic!My cab driver told me this hotel was built only a few years ago for Indianapolis to host the superbowl which makes sense - it's huge and everything seems so new and modern (but still cozy)!My room is quite large and equipped with all the traveling essentials including plenty of outlets, lamps, a desk + chair, ample closet space, micro-safe, and even a mini-fridge that was pleasantly empty for the storage of beverages and any leftovers. Speaking to others in attendance at the same conference, I think the mini-fridge is somewhat of an anomaly, so perhaps make a request for one if you think you'd use it!Like the executive suite mentioned by a previous reviewer, the shower in my room also has 4-way shower heads which are just awesome and super relaxing after a long day of corporate presentations or enjoying the sights. A couple of museums are right around the corner with many fine restaurants and shopping options within blocks. This hotel is definitely pricey and I'm sure some other high-end options in the area may compare but I'd definitely recommend for the amenities, overall quality/cleanliness, and the friendly customer service.My second stay here. All I did was inform Kenny at the desk during check in that my fiancee and I were about to get married and we were in town for the weekend to celebrate her birthday. What followed was a commotion of niceties from the choc flavored strawberries and champagne brought up to our 32nd floor suite with wondrous view to the complimentary breakfast for our entire stay to unfettered access to the lounge. It was a very upscale and totally enjoyable weekend. I rarely give 5 stars but I will give this time because customer service was great and every employee seemed happy with their work and excited to help us. I would have fussed about parking but I got a very affordable $6 parking at the 'public' parking garage opposite the hotel. Thanks Kenny!!We stayed here for Thanksgiving. The rooms were excellent and the service was superb. We even enjoyed the hotel restaurants.For Indianapolis, this is about as swank as it gets.  It is very conveniently located by Lucas Oil Stadium and the Southwest corner of Downtown (also not too far from Ooey Pooey).   I have been to numerous conferences here.  Indiana Bar Association meetings, CLE's, private parties.  The place is always clean.  To be honest, in my humble opinion, nothing quite matches up with the classic hotels of yore.  This is no Palmer House, no Waldorf.  It lacks that degree of character.  It is somewhat ironic that is named similarly to the Marrott, an old hotel that did have such character and closed long ago.   As someone who is by no means a fan of modern architecture, this looks pretty cool.  I dig the blue glass.  But it is too sterile and disposable to be really classic.   So it gets for stars because there really isn't much else by way of hotels in Indy.  If you want class, convenience, service, and good food... this is probably your stop.   (The Canterbury is such an old hotel, but back in the day it was a flophouse.  It has been remade into a boutique hotel, but it lacks gravitas--it's a good option, too, though.)I'll preface my review by saying I really do not like traveling for business and so I am difficult to please when it comes to conference hotel accommodations. But here I was at the JW Marriott for a week-long conference, hoping for a good experience.The first thing you'll notice upon entering this hotel is that it is very beautifully decorated, modern, and clean. And then you'll notice how attentive the staff is, because someone will generally greet you within a few seconds of entering the lobby. They have a lot of "floaters", or people who are tasked with directing guests, answering questions, and providing a good customer experience. They are really on the ball--I was very impressed. They will direct you where to check in, where to get bell service, where to eat, and pretty much anything else you might need. Check in was a breeze. I actually arrived really early (like 5 hours before check in time) and was prepared to check my bags and go roaming around the city--but the desk clerk even offered to see if there was a room available. Turns out there wasn't, but I appreciated the gesture.The rooms are very nicely appointed and clean. The beds are on the firm side, which I don't mind, and the bathrooms are comfortable and modern. A complaint I do have is that the thermostats are very limited in their range of temperatures. The room was 70 when I got there, and it only goes down to 66. That is WAY to warm to sleep, so I was pretty uncomfortable every night. They probably do this to conserve energy and all that, but I don't care for it.The conference accommodations where very good. The wifi was strong and reliable. I gave presentations in two different rooms, and someone always came in before my session to make sure I was set and that there weren't any tech issues. Very nice touch. The food was pretty good, nothing out of this world but definitely good for any mass catering effort. They kept enough variety in the conference provided meals that it was a pleasure to eat each of the meals.I had limited experience with the staff in the other eating venues in the hotel (mostly just having a beer at the High Velocity bar) but they seemed like a great staff with interesting menus.I would recommend this hotel to anyone traveling to the downtown Indy area. If you have a conference here, you are in for a good experience!Wish my conference has been at the Conrad Hilton!  We were at the JW for five nights. What a disappointment!  1.  When I walked into my room there was a musty/moldy smell. 2.  Had a dust ball on the carpet when I got there. It was still there five days later. The carpet was never vacuumed. The maid carts don't even have vacuums on them. 3.  One day I had no bath mat nor soap4.  One day a coworker had no soap5.  Ice machines are all on the 2nd floor, I was on the 25th of 33. 6.  TV remote went missing one day. 7.   While looking for remote found about 1/8" of dirt/dust under the bed. Co workers rooms were the same. YUCK!!If this is Marriott's flagship, then the ship is sinking. Put on your life vest and swim to the Hilton!I cannot stress how wonderful my stay was here. The front desk crew were always quick to 'do' for you. The room was gloriously lovely with a view that was spectacular. I know, Indianapolis spectacular? What drugs am I on? None at the moment. I was so impressed with the city, the people, the restaurants and the walking around. Even the mall was nice, not full of derelicts like the one back home. I was hesitant to come here for a conference, I almost skipped it but staying here and visiting INDY was something that I'll never forget and believe me I've travelled quite a bit.My first experience in a JW Marriott and I was pleasantly surprised. Very nice hotel with great amenities and restaurants. The beds were very comfortable and the hotel shampoo and conditioner were better than most. I am traveling for work so not sure of the cost but I would definitely stay here again!Probably the nicest hotel in downtown Indianapolis. Great views of downtown and the surrounding areas. Conveniently located to several venues and restaurants. Beds are the most comfortable I have slept in. Hotel features two restaurants and a bar.Good things first: Mr. Miller and Mr. Nathan are two bar tender legends in the Marriott Velocity Bar. Bar is the best feature of the hotel as well as the gym. Concierge lounge is over average, too. Rooms are great, Italian restaurant is okay. The hotel lobby and the bar are extremely noisy and mostly filled with conference-attending groups. This would be a 4-5 star hotel but the major flaw is the lack of commitment to pricing. I booked my trips frequently (8 months) to Indy using my customer rate. The website spits out $125. But that price is changed upon your arrival and you may learn it or not. Depending on the person checking you in. If you figure at check-in the associate will tell you that since you did not book through the travel department of the customer they can't give you the price. I'm platinum premier and I don't like games especially not if adding that tiny portion of arrogance. ALTERNATIVE: stay at Courtyard or Springhill Suites. Less $$$ and more friendly. @JW: smart move... I spent about $20K on hotels in Indy in the last 8+ months. And you got a fraction of that budget.
review_content_20: We stayed at the JW Marriot for a wedding that I was in. The hotel also hosted the wedding. If you are looking for a hotel that has everything in it, the JW Marriot could be the choice for you.Location: The hotel is located centrally downtown Indianapolis. There are several restaurants and entertainment spots within walking distance of the hotel. There are also a lot of historical and cultural places in the area as well. There is a skywalk to the convention center as well as one to a mall. There is also a skywalk to two other Marriott hotels (courtyard and Springhill) that connect to the JW.Amenities: The JW holds two restaurants and a Starbucks inside the hotel. One restaurant is High Velocity, which has a sports pub feel to it. There are TVs located inside, a bar, and they serve American food. The other, is Osterio Pronto which is an Italian restaurant. Both are open for lunch and dinner. Osteria is open for breakfast as well. There is also a stand alone bar in the lobby with a large seating area for guests.
