On Sunday we also noticed the slow elevators other Yelpers mentioned. Really really slow. We decided to walk down 5 flights of steps to get to the game, since the elevators were so slow. And the stairwell was pretty creepy. The best thing about this hotel was it's proximity to Lucas Oil Stadium and the Skywalk. It's close to a lot of other downtown Indy attractions too, but the next time I'm there I will stay somewhere else.My wife and I live in the Indy area, but we spent a night downtown to celebrate our anniversary. After much searching we finally settled on the Hyatt Regency because of the price and proximity to the things we wanted to do downtown. We booked a single king bed room. When we arrived we parked in the PNC garage underneath and paid $24 for 24 hours of parking. We were planning on walking everywhere and didn't go back to the ca until we were ready to leave.The gentleman who checked us in was very helpful. I asked if we could request a room with a view, and he put us on the 19th floor. We had a great view from our window, looking out straight across at the Embassy Suites. You could see the old theater across the street. You could also look towards monument circle and see the Conrad, Chase Tower, and other tall buildings. I've seen a lot of complaints about the slow elevators here, but we never had to wait more than 30 seconds for one. The room itself was very nice. There was a mini fridge, which was very helpful because my wife is still nursing our baby and she had to do some pumping and store the milk. The bed was very comfortable. My biggest complaint is that there was no variety in pillow sizes. All of the pillows were huge, and I like to sleep with a very thin pillow, so I didn't sleep all that well. If we go here again I'll bring my own.The bathroom/shower were very nice. The shower was very roomy, and pressure was good. The water did take a minute or two to get hot, which I had seen mentioned here before. But once it got there we never had an issue of it running out on us. We did spend some time down in the pool area. The pool was somewhat small, and there were several kids playing around in it, but the hot tub was very spacious. I don't care what time of year it is, a hot tub is one of my favorite things. The fitness area seemed to have quite a bit of equipment, but we didn't do anything there. The location here is great. You're in walking distance of anything you could want to do in downtown Indy. I'd definitely recommend a stay here.This hotel is satisfactory is most regards. However, I am giving it one star based solely on the elevator situation. I have never been in a hotel, or any high rise for that matter, and had to wait 5-10 minutes for an elevator. There is a severe shortage of elevators for the size of this hotel. I am not sure how they passed building codes.We entrusted our wedding weekend and honeymoon to Hyatt brand hotels. Our wedding was in downtown Indy and the Hyatt Regency was where we blocked rooms for our guests. (We honeymooned the week after at the Hyatt Zilara Cancun).First, the Hyatt regency offered the only competitive /decent block rate and was the most accommodating overall. Gabrelle was our contact and was always available at a moments notice if we needed something. She even assisted with some items outside her normal day to day tasks which is huge.The hotel itself is decent as far as interior/rooms. Some could be updated but it did the job for us and our guests. I have found at this hotel the rooms to be a bit musty/dusty at times when staying here before. As the groom though, they put me in a high room with a great view and surprised my wife and I with treats on our wedding night. Very nice touch.When we started arriving Thursday and Friday, the computer systems were down, which meant only one key per room and a long line to check in. With no computers it rendered half the front desk staff helpless, and basically one person was checking people in from a printed list while others tried to help or get out of the way. I would not have been able to handle the situation with the amount of patience and class that the staff at the Hyatt did...so, kudos to them for making the best of a bad situation! My wife and I are platinum gold passport members and clearly are quite loyal to the Hyatt brands. This also means I don't hesitate to complain or bring up an issue if I have one. This stay and weekend at the Hyatt regency met expectations, made our wedding weekend run smoothly, and we will definitley stay here again!My room was clean, quiet and very comfortable. The service at check-in was prompt and attentive and anything anytime I asked, the staff greeted the request as if they were personally happy to be hosting me.My favorite thing though was to have one of the employees of this Hyatt proudly stating to me and my coworkers that she has been with this hotel for nearly 20 years this year and loved it and added that she had requested this location because it was the best. That certainly builds your faith in the company!First impression? When you walk into the lobby you are stunned by the beauty of the Hyatt. It has a huge open air atrium and the hotel floors rise up majesticaly over you. You can see the walkways that snake out to the mall, the adjacent hotels and the Convention Center. You can see the glass elevators as they rise majestically to their skyward destinations. It really is a striking sight to see.Check in was easy- and the desk attendant asked if I was a Hyatt member, and I wasn't. So she signed me up and an instant perk was free wifi for 5 miutes of questions- not a bad deal at all. While checking in, I saw a bank of computer terminals for customers to use - good for boarding pass printing.My hotel room was very spacious- most definitely one of the larger chain rooms I've seen. It had an interesting design too -with an angled wall for the flatscreen and work station. The bed was very comfortable. The alarm clock had an mp3 plug so you could fill the room with selections from your iPod.There is a small alcove in the middle of the room with a mini-fridge and a Starbucks coffee maker. I didn't see a mini-bar, but since I never use them it was no great loss for me.The bathroom was very comfortable- and this is a big deal because so many chain bathrooms are petite, i remember one where I could barely close the door without smacking it into the toilet. This room was plenty big. The shower had that Herculite glass construction, and the water temp and pressure were fine. One picky thing - the bottom of the shower door leaked a little onto the floor. Not once, but every time.I asked for a late checkout on Wednesday and that was no problem everyone I dealt with here was pleasant and professional.Great hotel.  Service was great.  Staff very attentive.  The maid came by and knocked on the door to bring  me a pen that had been neglected to be placed on the stationary.  Location is very convenient to all downtown venues and restaurants.  Skywalks connect it to convention center, shopping mall making it easy to access Lucas Oil Stadium or the Field House for basketball games.  Don't have to go outside in the rain or cold.  Lots of panhandlers and "street walkers" on the street corners outside.  Still this isn't the Hyatts fault.Great stay.5 star hotel?? I think not. 1) While relaxing in the lobby for the rest of our guests to arrive, we brought our own alcohol to start the weekend with a drink (Since the hotel bar was CLOSED at 1pm on a Saturday!)...We had asked the concierge for ice. It was going to cost $25 FOR A BUCKET OF ICE!?! The associate who informed us of this ridiculous policy was also no help. We had to take our cups and find an ice machine on one of the hotels floors. 2) We waited 18 minutes for an elevator from our room to our lobby. We spent A LOT of time waiting for the elevator.3) The hallway light did not work in our guest room.4) I stood in line at the Starbucks for 23 minutes for a coffee. 5) We had breakfast at the hotel restaurant, One South. First we waited for over an hour for our food (the restaurant was not crowded at this time)...finally when our food came, one of the guest in our party was told that they were out of what she had ordered. Had she known an hour prior, she would've ordered something else. 6) Staff is nice but not at all accommodating or helpful. Very disappointed.For a "4 star" hotel the service was garbage.First my "complimentary" wireless internet wasn't setup and I needed a phone call to have it "activated" and the code they gave me stopped working before check out.When we returned to our room for the second night our stay after 6pm the room was not made up. Not even looked at by the staff. I called the desk and they seemed not to care the offered to do it now, it's kind of late for that, I wanted to take a nap in the bed. I could talk to the housekeeping manager if I wanted. Neat. I had to ask them to send up fresh towels and made it know that I was unhappy.  They made no efforts to change make it right. So they clearly do not care about my money and they won't be getting it in the future. Which is a shame since I stay in Indianapolis 3+ times a year.We had a really wonderful one-night stay at the downtown Hyatt Regency. We originally planned on staying at a crappy 2 star place (we were only here to party.. high class wasn't really what we were going for!) When we went to book before leaving home, we realized that they jacked up the rates to an amount that seemed ridiculous for a non-fancy hotel. We had to start looking around for something else and were so lucky to get a fantastic rate for the Hyatt Regency on Priceline through the Express Deals.This place was really easy to find thanks to my BFF, Google maps. We arrived early in the AM with the thought that we'd probably have to just leave our bags and check in at a later time, but we were able to get a room right away on one of the top floors. Although we didn't have much of a view, we were still really impressed by the room overall. Since we were here on a Sunday evening, there wasn't a whole lot going on, but there was some kind of musical organ conference going on. All of the attendees were pretty friendly in the elevator, so much so that we wanted to go sneak in and see what an organ conference entails. Other pros:-They have an indoor pool! It's pretty small, but I was one of the only ones in it so I didn't mind.-Elevators were quick-Extremely close to City Centre mall, donut shop, coffee, fro-yo, etc.-Staff was friendly-Fridge in room - none of that weighted mini bar crap.-Spacious roomCons:-Not their fault, but a lot of businesses are closed on Sunday. We were in town for a concert, otherwise I probably wouldn't come back on a Sunday.-I love taking long baths at night especially after walking around all day! Our room didn't have a tub. (I think I read in reviews that you can request one -- not sure if that's true or not)This is one of the better hotels that I've ever stayed at, especially since nothing went wrong. I'm planning a trip back in the future and Hyatt will be my first choice!Best thing about this place is the location. The connection to the mall and proximity to Circle is great. Valet staff was hit and miss (some just outright rude) and parking was way too expensive. You know what though, Indy has a small downtown which makes almost all the hotels have a decent location. Maybe look around for other places to stay if you're in the area.A disappointment for all the money I spent. Lovely lobby and right downtown--it seemed perfect but the room was frustrating.I was here for four nights a few weekends ago for a convention. And wow, where to begin. This is supposedly a nice place? Weird. Because there were a lot of problems.1. Light by the window didn't work. Maybe it was connected to the lightswitch by the thermostat that didn't seem to connect to anything. Don't know if the bulb was just burned out or what. But, you know, basic maintenance.2. Internet: constant disconnects and crashes. Though, it was free.3.The shower curtain is a soft, absorbent fabric. It's not waterproof. That means that, as a shower curtain, it's USELESS. Be prepared to put down all your towels on the floor--cause when you step out, you will slip and die if you don't.4. Water never got better than lukewarm. Also, the "plug" was depressed--which I didn't realize because it still drains. So I thought it was just slow. 5. Tried to use the thermostat to warm up the room---but it would only blast cold air6. Minifridge was barely cold. Couldn't even freeze ice packs in it.7. There was an old pop can, trash and copious amounts of dust behind the work desk. 8. Water damage and stains on the bathroom ceiling9. Got short-changed at the Starbucks in the lobby. Gave the cashier a $20. She insisted I gave her a $10. I had no way to prove it--so I lost ten bucks. 10. I had the Privacy Please tag up--left my room for a little--came back and discovered that someone had been in there. Because they had decided that Saturday--which was very busy--was a good day to....trade out TVs for a slightly bigger one? So, that was a weird thing. 11. And then, at the end, having to pay $100 to park my car in their garage just seemed like a slap in the face---even though that's pretty much common practice in cities like this.Great location but this hotel needs work! Everything was unkept.  The hallways were dirty, wear and tear all over, just meh.  The room was a good size but walls were paper thin.  Could clearly hear a conversation next door.  The most annoying thing was the night lights built in to side tables that would go off whenever you moved.  Had to cover them with a pillow!Stayed here several years ago, when I accompanied the family to Indy for Bouchercon. Very solid hotel. Honestly, not overly amazing, not over-the-top fancy, but a solid hotel. Spent several very comfortable nights here.I stayed here last weekend.  I loved the bar in the lounge and the hotel is in a perfect location.  Walking distance to anything of importance and valet offers a flat fee of $35.00 for all day in and out use.The only reason I did not mark 5 stars is because there was a guy at the front desk who hastled me about my government ID to book my room at the discounted rate.  I had to get my colleague on the phone with him to argue my case.  It was sort of ridiculous.Besides that, the hotel was wonderfully clean and pleasant.  The gym is a bit small but functional none the less!The price is fair and the location is great.  Room was clean, but the staff was over zealous about wanting to clean. Started banging on doors at 9am. Everything is expensive. $17 for the buffet breakfast.  $8 well drinks at the bar. No wonder its always empty. Part of the idea here should be attracting people to mingle at the hotel bar.  I don't want to drop a Jackson every time my wife and I want a drink.  We paid less for mixed drinks at the area gentleman's club.  A guy ordered a bottle of corona. It was $6.The pool is tiny and the hot tub is not a hot tub.  It is a whirlpool. No bubbles.  Do not come here if you are planning the hotel as an inclusive facility.  It really has nothing more to offer than a room with good location.  Oh, if you want a view room, ask for it. We got a lovely view of the ac units. Bleh. We did get high up as requested.  Book through them and the internet is free. Book through a third party and you have to pay.  Parking is ridiculous.  It is part of the PNC building, so there are other people milling around in the daytime.  Don't expect or count on Starbucks being open when you want it either.
review_content_20: A colleague and I stayed at the Hyatt on a Wednesday and Thursday for a conference that took place at the hotel. Rooms: neat and clean.  Very modern decor, but visually busy.   Extremely comfortable beds.  We stayed in a two queen room that were each the size of a full size bed.  There was not a safe in the room to lock up your wallet and jewelry.   Exercise facility: state of the art equipment.  Cool towels for after working out.   Sauna.  Pool.  Hot tub.  (And not overly chlorinated).   Towels at the indoor pool to use,so you don't need to bring towels from your room.   Locker rooms, so bring your padlock!!  Showers in the locker room area.  Staff:   Very attentive.   Excellent food.   Chicken taco bar and plated steak meals were served.    Fresh fruit, rolls, and oatmeal, along with beverages were served for breakfast at the conference provided by the hotel. Valet parking:  polite and helpful staff.   $34 parking per day. However, on our last day we had to get our car by 2:00 unless we wanted to be charged another $34.  Our conference went until 3:30. We got our car on our lunch break and were directed to go two blocks to another, cheaper parking ramp.   It was full and so were the next two were full.  We ended up parking at another ramp for $15 and walking 3 blocks back to the hotel.    In total, it took 30 minutes to move our car and get to our played lunches, that were waiting for us, late.  I wished the hotel would let you park until 4:00 or when conferences are done.   It was inconvenient.    Overall, we enjoyed our stay.   The polite and helpful staff was the highlight.    I even requested the plated steak to please be cooked to well done and accommodated with pleasure.  They were serving at least 500 people.I stayed at this hotel for my 5 day stay in Indianapolis. The location is great, but the hotel experience was not so much. Like most others have said:-No warm water in shower all 5 days-Bathroom/shower not cleaned very well-15-20 minute average time to get from room to lobby because of constant traffic jam of the elevators-Very very noisy. This was the most bizarre to me. They had a wedding at the hotel the weekend I stayed, so I am assuming they probably hold weddings here often, the music/people from the wedding were SOOOO loud two of the nights, I couldn't sleep on the 9th floor. The wedding was on the second floor...so I can't even imagine the people on floors lower than me. The bass sounded like I was directly above a club. This went on until 1 in the morning when I finally fell asleep to the sound of the TV. Weddings I've been to are usually over at 11, so I don't know what that was about. Do they just not care about guests wanting to sleep when they book these weddings? Just weird, idk. -Parking your car is ridiculously expensive. I get that we are downtown, but holy cow, give your hotel guests a discount or something. -Upon checking in, they warned me of construction and to keep my curtains shut after showering as there apparently may be workers right outside my window? Interesting. I definitely will be staying elsewhere next time.Disappointed yet again! It would be so simple for them to retain a loyal customer. However, these guys keep messing it up. I've not once thought they were doing the right thing in terms of honoring my diamond status. Marriott and the Hilton treat their loyal customers better. Here however, I was told the corner suites were booked despite the fact that I had just booked my room online and it asked me to upgrade for $40 bucks more. That whole free automatic upgrade thing is apparently a thing of the past. I used to get that all of the time. This place works my nerves. I've never had a stay go right here. It has to be that the staff are improperly trained or the manager doesn't know how to manage his potentially awesome resources. I think this was my last attempt. The Conrad and The Alexander, along with the JW are the hotels to beat. Even the Sheraton has a leg up. I see a lot of 1 stars, so I'm hoping someone at corporate will take notice and fix the problems here.Rooms did not look fresh and clean. A couple of the pillowcases were very worn.  A family of four was scheduled to check in, yet only towels for three were left in room. My kids were hungry around 8:30. It was raining outside so did not want to go outside. The quick serve restaurants were closed. Called restaurant listed on phone and was told you can't carry out.  Went up to restaurant and realized it was very fancy and not what we were looking for. Called room service to see if we could order and pick up food.  She said yes and I ordered kids meals.  Brought back to our room and the PB & J bread was stale - hard as a rock. How can you mess up PB& J?  Too tired to deal with it, so threw it away. After seeing how much that PB&J was on our bill. I complained at checkout and they nicely removed the charge.I'm not sure how this hotel got good reviews. When we arrived we had to ask for directions and an employee rudely answered without even making eye contact, as if we were bothering her. At check in I asked the woman helping us if she could recommend a good brunch and she asked if we wanted Italian. I replied saying we wanted breakfast and she gave me a confused look then told me to ask the concierge (and there was not a language barrier, she was American). The elevators took ten minutes to come. Finally we get to our room and there is no hot water. My shower was cold and the shower wall was slimy.  I'm not sure we will be staying at a Hyatt anytime soon, as it has given us the amenities you'd expect from a Holiday Inn, if not less.Stayed here 4 nights.  Great staff!  Comfortable beds. Clean rooms.  Great location, within walking distance to mall, food, and theatres.  Surprisingly there was not a microwave in the room and no vent in the bathroom to suck up the shower steam or smells that can occur and linger.This location is pretty much like the other Regency's I've stayed at. This is a massive location though, and has been renovated fairly recent. It also has a very nice new gym, with jacuzzi and pool.Parking is quite expensive...$34 overnight. But I guess that's to be expected at most downtown locations.The Regency Club is also fairly nice, although it's one of the smaller ones I've seen. Food was good though, and a nice view, and very attentive gentleman working it tonight.All in all, a solid 4 stars for a Hyatt Regency.Shocking how dirty the Hyatt was!My husband and I wanted to get a way for the weekend and thought we would like to stay at the Hyatt.  We have stayed there before and enjoyed our stay.  This time...not so much.  The staff is wonderful, they all want to know what they can do to make our stay better.  Once we got into our room I noticed it was dusty, not just a little dusty...VERY DUSTY!Bathroom was discussing. Toilet seat was broken, hair on the ceiling, and in the sink. I had to clean the sink myself cause I get grossed by the thought if someone's hair where. I'm going to brush my teeth. I brought it up to front desk. They had someone fix the toilet seat and they gave us a free breakfast. Nice but what about cleaning the room!  I went down later and explained that I have allergies to dust an yet no one cleaned.  Saturday house keeping came into our room and fixed our bed and somewhat replaced towels, but the hair was still on the ceiling and the dust was still everywhere. See I wrote on the desk, TV, table, nightstand, headboard and pictures/frames "Dust Me!" Could not miss it if you were going to clean properly. Later that evening to spoke with who said was management and once again said he was going to call housekeeping to clean the problem. Few hours later we got back to the room and NOTHING was done. My husband normally never complains this time he did.  We must have explained the story to 6 different people at the Hyatt about the cleanness of the hotel.  Very disappointed in the lack of effort. They did give us a free night, for the next visit... Ha ha that is a joke cause I do not think there will be a next time. I could have stayed across the way at the Westin for less and they updated the entire hotel.  We paid more for a hotel that was not clean!!!Eh, it's fine, and convenient for downtown business, especially convenient to the convention center.  Large (though not enormous), atrium-style Hyatt.Clean, efficient, with valet or garage parking (additional cost).  If you're working downtown, you may be able to park and forget your car until departure - this is what I usually prefer.Usual membership / loyalty benefits.  Will go back, without a concern; but nothing exceptional to note.I must preface this by saying I was not actually a customer here, but my wife stayed here for a conference in Indianapolis. It happened to be her birthday while she was staying here and I called the hotel to see if we could put together a little surprise for her. I was connected to Ms. Vicki in the Room Service department and she went above and beyond to help me organize a little morning/breakfast surprise. I couldn't be happier with the great customer service and friendliness Ms. Vicki and the Hyatt Regency staff displayed. They helped my wife celebrate her birthday even though she was far from home. Thank you Ms. Vicki and the Hyatt Regency!I stayed here before back in 2010 and had a decent experience. This time around we were traveling with our infant daughter and managed to get an upgrade to a corner king, which made a huge difference. The extra space in the room was great for fitting all the requisite baby stuff. The most convenient aspect for me was the fridge/wet bar located just outside of the bathroom. It gave me a great spot to prepare bottles without using desk space, and was right next to the bathroom where I washed everything. We have stayed at 3 other hotels since then and this was the best layout for my purposes (albeit unique).Parking here has always been awful. It is ridiculously expensive and there are no in/out privileges. The only other design flaw for us was the pathway from the room to get to the mall (which is connected by a breezeway). The conference center within the hotel occupies the 2nd floor, which is the walkway to get to the mall...there are events which always block the halls, rerouting guests to an escalator. Not stroller friendly. In order to cross over, you have to go down to the lobby, walk across, and up an elevator one story...Despite this minor inconvenience the hotel is centrally located and has always been a good spot to access most of the things we needed in Indy.I decided to try the Hyatt when I needed a hotel to call home for the week of Christmas. The price was comparable if not better than the surrounding hotels.Location: awesome! There is a skywalk that connects to the mall for colder months. Fancy (Fogo de Chao) and not so fancy (steak and shake) restaurants less than a block away. Service: great! Everyone was amazingly helpful and nice. I didn't get the typical high end "I'm better than this" attitude. The young and personable staff at valet and the desk were more than helpful and nice. Valet is a $30 per day charge extra, but worth it to me. The front desk even called to let us know our door had been slightly ajar per their security system!Rooms: Good. They have done renovations since the Super Bowl a few years ago, so everything is much nicer. The rooms are spacious and clean. We did have trouble out of our tv (buttons not working, had to set sleep timer to turn off). The cleaning staff did a great job. The perfect mix of give you what you need and tidy up without touching the stuff you obviously wanted to be left alone. I have a pet peeve about cleaning staff touching my toiletries or rearranging my luggage or shoes I leave in the room. Food: who knows? We actually didn't eat at the hotel restaurants at all. But from living here before, I've heard good things. We just had other plans while we were in town. Environment: great! We had no issues smelling smoke (smoke-free) or noise from neighbors, which are major decision-makers when I pick hotels. The hotel was very quiet, but I feel it wasn't very busy due to the time of year. Overall, I give a four-star rating because there are things we didn't experience (food), but loved it!Comfortable and clean rooms, but the beds don't come with a fitted sheet over the mattress. Housekeeping came ever 2 days to tidy up and clean the room. Although I was impressed when I called and asked where the microwave was so I can warm up some food, the receptionist said she would have one delivered to my room in 15 minutes - for FREE! It also came with disposable bowls, and eating utensils. And true enough- there was a knock on my door in 12 mins and I was greeted by a very polite lady with a microwave.  I stayed here for a week or more long convention and I leapt for joy when I saw that there is a STARBUCKS in the lobby!!! There was also a SUBWAY and Pizza place. The Skywalk on the second floor took us to the convention center, very convenient location for different restaurants and it is right next to the Circle Center Mall. The Valet attendants were very polite and helpful. They always made sure I got what I needed and asked me how my day was going and always brought my car on time. NEver had to wait on them guys! The manager should give them a raise for giving great customer service!!Was here for a business conference in early November, and this is one of the better conference hotels I've been at recently (as of late, it seems like I've been at Marriotts and not having good experiences). Even with the hotel full of conference-goers, there was not noticeable hallway noise so the rooms seem to be reasonably soundproofed. The room itself was comfortable, looked to have been updated and renovated within the last few years, and the hotel overall was always well-kept and clean in the public areas. The convenience of having a Starbucks in the lobby is always nice and there is a great variety of restaurants in the area surrounding the hotel at all different price points, so you can really choose what kind of food you want and how much you want to spend and you shouldn't have a problem at all finding a place that fits your needs. I ate lunch one day in the hotel restaurant and they do a pasta bar lunch special for a reasonable price. Only complaints are minor. Everyone around me commented on the elevator doors - they were barely staying open and then slamming shut. You had to zip in and out of the elevators like The Flash to avoid having them slam shut on you. It was a little strange. Also, the heating/AC unit in my room was doing this thing where it would turn on for only a few minutes, shut off for a few, then back on; rinse, lather, repeat. It was noticeably annoying when I was trying to fall asleep, so I finally just shut it off totally and hoped the temperature would be comfortable and luckily it was. Finally - yet another 4-star place that doesn't have free WiFi in the rooms. WHY???? This is the bane of my traveling existence. It is ridiculous that I have to go sit in the lobby to get my work done when these hotels are catering to a work clientele. The lobby was always filled with people using the free Wifi available there, because who wants to pay $10 a day for what I understand was pretty unreliable service in the rooms?I often find that hotels located in excellent areas tend fall short when it comes to the room and service.  The Hyatt Regency was no exception.  There are many great things that this hotel has to offer, but also many things that can be improved upon.  To start with the good, the Hyatt Regency is located in the middle of downtown Indianapolis.  You are literally a few footsteps away from restaurants, bars, the theater, and shopping.  It is also within walking distance of the zoo.  For those who do not wish to go outside, there are several restaurants located within the hotel as well as a skywalk connecting you directly to the mall.  Even though the room was pleasantly decorated, it could use some updates and fine tuning.  To start, the sink didn't drain the water properly by which I mean didn't drain hardly at all!  I would have to stop the water running several times while washing my hands to make sure that it didn't overflow.  The shower was very spacious, however I don't think I have used a more uncomfortable shower-head in my life.  It was literally painful to take a shower, something the hotel should seriously reconsider.  The bedding also had a very strange smell to it and the walls were paper thin.  It was also disappointing to come back to our room the next day at 4pm to find that house cleaning hadn't stopped by yet ( they didn't come until 5:00pm, which at that point we were getting ready for dinner).  Overall, I do not think this hotel deserves the 4 star rating, it was a solid 3 stars.  On my next trip, I would be more interested to see what other hotels Indianapolis has to offer.My boyfriend and I went to Indianapolis for a weekend to celebrate our 5 year anniversary at a Colts game. Upon arriving, we were really excited about the location of the hotel, and the aesthetics of the hotel were beautiful. When we first pulled up and spoke to the valet, he asked us whether we wanted overnight parking or hourly. I was unsure of what we wanted to do parking-wise at this point so I said let's just do hourly. The valet told me there was no point in doing hourly and basically bullied me into choosing the overnight parking, which was $40! When we went to check in, the woman at the desk was not welcoming or friendly whatsoever. She also had informed us that they "ran out of king sized beds" and only had rooms left with a double bed. I was initially thrown off by this, but I figured one of the beds would be big enough for us to sleep in, or worst case scenario we could push them together to make a larger bed. However, we got to the room and came to find two very small beds that were unable to be moved to push together. So, we went back downstairs and informed them that this was not going to work out, and that I had booked our room 3 months in advance so there should be no reason to not get the room we paid for. All they could offer us was free breakfast, which was almost an insult after paying as much as we did for a room that we did not get. It seemed like they were treating us poorly because we booked our trip at a discounted price through Priceline, which they continuously brought up. I did not think that would have affected the service I received. Finally, we just asked for a refund because we were able to find a more accommodating hotel a few blocks down, and they informed us that it would take 7-10 business days to process, which I was fine with. 13 business days later, I called to ask where my refund is, and they have given me multiple problems, stating that their records show that I checked out at the end of the weekend rather than the 20 minutes that I actually stayed there. I will absolutely not be going back to the Hyatt Regency Indianapolis, and I would not recommend it to anyone looking for an enjoyable customer service experience.This place is amazing! Absolutely beautiful  and treats their guests with a high level of respect. The only things is the parking fee is $24 to self park and $35 for vallet per day and breakfast isn't included. Other than that it comes with a mini fridge and GREAT INTERNET SERVICE FOR FREE. :) I stayed in the king bedroom facing the city :)The room was great staff was great BUT BEWARE the bar staff added tips to my room without me giving permission ,me and my friend stayed there for a Colts game and after we were having a few and toward the end of the nite he asked to c my room key to make sure we were staying their to serve us another one and apon check out he added a nice tip for himself after we took care of him the nite of, did not say anything I just won't stay their again so don't show key......Timing is everything. I came in the midst of what must be a major overhaul (October 2012) and you can tell. Sorry, but no business as usual, though I appreciate the attempt. I prefer to blame all that is wrong on the construction rather than to believe that those loud noises that I can hear from my room are normal and to be expected during every stay. There was no space for the taxi to truly pull over to as I got out of the car, luckily there were no cars waiting behind us. One thing that seems to be the case regardless of the construction status is the hotel's adjacency to an office building. I mean you step out of your room and literally see people at their desks. I guess it would be convenient if you were in town to visit one of those offices, but awkward otherwise. The good: proximity to the stadium, the convention center, downtown, direct access to the skyway, a pretty nice restaurant on the top floor and low cost fast food options on the main floors. I'm a fan, but. Definitely want to hold off on a return visit until the construction is done.nice and comfortable. It was a little pricey 170.00 per night and no breakfast so that's a draw back. All in all a decent hotel Great Location.
review_content_40: This a great hotel on the heart of Indianapolis and has all of the great staff and amenities that one would expect in a $200 room but the standard WiFi is so bad that I never connected to a single website regardless of how long I waited. Why can I get free high speed internet in every Mom and Pop and lesser chain but not here? It casts a poor image upon a potentially great hotel experience.A solid choice for a downtown Indianapolis hotel. We stayed here for three nights as guests/participants in a wedding held nearby.Parking: Kind of pricy. I guess you have to suck it up and pay, though, or find an overnight lot a few blocks away and walk. Such is downtown parking. The garage is under the building, you go through the valet/registration area and make a sharp turn into it. Location: A block off Monument Circle. Connected to Circle Center mall and other downtown locations via skywalks and the ArtsGarden. Theaters, shopping, tons of restaurants and bars all nearby. Parks and museums close too.Rooms: Recently renovated (for the Superbowl I guess?) and super-clean, modern, sleek. We had a king room with a view of a nearby plaza and other buildings. The showerhead was great, the bed big and comfy, nice clean decor. Coffeemaker also has a few tea bags; mini fridge is a nice touch too. However: We could not seem to get quite comfortable temperature-wise at night, the AC wasn't working terribly well and we were just a little too warm. Other amenities: It's $9.95 a day for Hyatt wifi. Blows my mind. I hate when big fancy hotels charge for wifi -- something you can get for free at any budget motel. There is free state-supported wifi you can connect to in the lobby but be warned -- it is slow as molasses outside in an Indiana winter. AOL dial-up level slow. Try the Panera across the street.Starbucks, pizza place and gyro place in the lobby; other restaurants and room service available. 24-hour fitness center; pool available till 10.All in all a good place to spend a few days, although I wish he AC/fan had been working a little better.Got a smoking deal naming our own price on Priceline, so I can't complain TOO much. We did have a big issue where we were charged $10 for a long-distance call that we didn't make. I had called a local number, so I paid for the charge thinking it was just hotel-ridiculous fees, but when we looked at the numbers, one of them was a Nebraska area code. Management reversed the charges, but they didn't credit MY card, they credited my friend's card (he had booked the reservation) so he had to send me a check... ugh, just way more hassle than it needed to be.Parking is pricey as expected (I think $22 overnight) and wifi is not free (although I'm paying twice what I'd pay for a motel with free wifi, of course). I would only stay here again if I got another great Priceline deal.The Hyatt is a beautiful property located in downtown Indianapolis a block from Lucas Oil Stadium. The hotel is relatively easy to get to and has an easy entry for registration/valet. (Don't forget that NOT included in your room rate is parking- Valet is ~$30 while self park is ~$23). The inside of the hotel is beautiful with massive water features and 4 LED lit glass elevators spanning floor to ceiling. It has a Starbucks and Subway in addition a bar/restaurant (which I didn't visit).You really can't beat the location if needing to stay downtown. It's near the stadium, restaurants/bars, shopping and a movie theater. The rooms are modern with interesting layouts given the building's unique structure. Didn't have a problem with the beds or rooms themselves. They aren't the largest rooms in the world but don't forget you're staying downtown so didn't surprise me much. I'd stay down here again. The rate was a bit steep but you pay for location/convenience and it definitely served its purpose in that area.Great:-The price. $99 on hotels.com!-The staff. Very friendly and helpful. -The rooms. Very stylish, comfortable and roomy. The bed was heavenly and the shower would have fit five people in it, should that situation ever arise for anyone.-The location. As others have mentioned, it's in very close proximity to a lot of popular Indianapolis attractions, restaurants and clubs. We were there for a dinner at Harry & Izzy's and it was right around the corner.-The Starbucks in the lobby.Not so great:-The seemingly endless waiting for the elevators. What's up with closing off two for the Eagle's Nest traffic at 3:00 in the afternoon? We ended up tracking down the sketchy stairwell and hoofing it up to the 7th floor.-The parking garage. We wanted to save ourselves $8 and park our car ourselves (as opposed to letting the valet do it)... maybe not the smartest move. We drove ourselves into dead ends a couple times. This is seriously the tiniest, most crowded, most confusing parking garage I've ever seen. However, a lot of the reserved spots are only for Monday through Friday, so if you're there on the weekend, you can park in them with no problem.Still, the good definitely outweighs the bad here. I plan on making all of our downtown Indianapolis stays at the Hyatt.Stayed here for a conference and had a great time. The conference staff was extremely attentive and the breakfast offerings were quite tasty. The lunch offerings were uninspired. The bar staff was also very attentive, and one of our group had to wait a few extra minutes for a drink order - the server thought it was too long and comped the drink. Had lunch one day at the restaurant and very much enjoyed the salmon dish. The hotel room was comfortable and well appointed. Had a nice view of the IRT. My only beef about the room was the motion activated footlights. There really needs to be an off switch for those! I had to prop pillows in front of them to ensure the room stayed dark all night. As with all conference hotels, valet parking and internet access were ridiculously expensive. This hotel is in a great location in downtown Indy and a short walk to great eateries and attractions. If you need to stay in downtown, I think this is a spot to consider.I have gotten some great deals at this hotel on Priceline. And even though the staff can see my cheapo reservation at check-in, they have treated me like any other customer. The service here is excellent.The rooms are nicely updated, and the beds are comfy. And I have to admit, riding the glass elevator is quite fun.After an awful day of getting the run around from other hotels this hotel went above and beyond! Amber was absolutely AMAZING!!! She made accommodations that made us feel so at home ... Made an awful day into a wonderful evening! Truly a great experience just to interact with her!!!! Hyatt made such a great move in hiring her!!!!I'll start off by saying that this place is definitely pricey but totally worth it. I still can't believe they charge for Internet, but you can get a free signal in the lobby (or if your room is close to the lobby). My room was super nice and had a view overlooking the Capitol. The bed was huge, nice and comfy and there were tons of extra pillows in the closet. The bathroom was large and the shower warmed up almost immediately. Refrigerator and storage space for your convenience (and it was since I brought veggies and water!).The conference space was really nice and there was a lot of room for all of the meetings, booths, etc. Tons of restaurants in the lobby (since it's connected to the pedway for the Conference Center), a Starbucks and a bar that's open pretty late. Totally convenient and some pretty decent beer on tap. Valet with in/out privileges was about $20 per night, which was pretty reasonable (compared with other large cities in the midwest).This hotel is located right in the heart of downtown Indianapolis, as well, so there's tons of stuff to do nearby. I enjoyed the proximity to nightlife including restaurants, bars and theaters. The Capitol is right across the street, so visit at your leisure! I'd definitely consider a stay here again if I find myself in Indianapolis in the future.UPDATE on 11/29/12: We've finally finished the painful process of ridding our apartment of the bed bugs I brought back from the Hyatt and having an inspection to confirm the bugs are gone. I sent Jeff at the Hyatt a list of my expenses along with receipts (~$750) and the Hyatt sent a check for that amount. They also gave me 16k Hyatt points, which is enough for a night or two at a Hyatt. I've updated my review to 5 stars because I liked the hotel and because I think they went above and beyond by paying for my bed bug-related expenses and also giving me Hyatt points.--------UPDATE on 10/1/12: Just received a call from Jeff, the director of rooms. He acknowledged that they found evidence of bed bugs in my room and was very apologetic. He claims that the Hyatt will reimburse me for any expenses that this has led to. He even mentioned that I might get a free night at a Hyatt hotel out of this. I'll provide updates as things proceed.Jeff also mentioned that they are of course getting rid of the bugs in room 535 and that they have a preventative program that they use to avoid these types of situations. Apparently the last time they had bugs at this hotel was 2 years ago, so I don't think this is a common issue.---------I stayed in room 535 for four nights in September 2012 for a conference. I'm giving a 1-star review because it is very likely that there were bed bugs in my room. These bugs caused me a lot of pain and now it seems they are in my apartment!Two days after I returned, I broke out with a bunch (~50) of very itchy spots sort of like a reaction to poison ivy but not quite the same. I never have experienced anything quite like these bites before. Two doctors have told me these were caused by bug bites of some kind. Probably bed bugs but impossible to say for sure just from the bites. I thought maybe I was bitten after I returned from the trip, but I was never bitten by anything like this before this trip. In 10 days since my return, I have not experienced any new bites (nor has anyone else in my apartment). Apparently bed bugs don't feed every night and it can take several days for one to have a reaction to the bites, so my reaction could have been to bites I experienced while at the hotel.I hired a dog trained to find bed bugs to check my apartment. It checked my apartment about a week after I returned from this hotel. The dog alerted that it smelled bugs when he smelled the bag I brought to this hotel, as well as in my closet where I put back some clothes from the trip and also by my bed. I have not seen any bed bugs or evidence of bed bugs in my bag or anywhere in my apartment yet, but supposedly these dogs are fairly reliable (the company I used is called CemexTek out of San Jose, CA if you want to see their yelp reviews).I won't get into the details here, but getting rid of bed bugs is very difficult and expensive. I'm working with an exterminator to hopefully nip this in the bud, but I could be in for a long battle with bed bugs.While of course it is not certain that I encountered bed bugs at this hotel, I think it is the simplest and most straightforward explanation to the evidence I have. Check your room for bugs before going in and unpacking, or stay somewhere else!I alerted the hotel to this issue, and they said that "due to the complexity of the issues you have described, I have forwarded your concerns to the executive management of this hotel for further research and follow-up." I plan on updating my review to document any further response.I can't speak to the hotel rooms, but the building itself it ok. You can buy a monthly fitness center pass, and the facilities are very clean, if small.The pizza restaurant and Subway are reasonably priced. The service and Charlie and Barney's is great, but they keep raising their prices. The interior and exterior of the hotel are clean and the exterior after the remodel is very pretty. I would like to see security actually enforce the no smoking by the doors rule.Clean, comfortable rooms. Convenient with access to skywalk. Front desk staff were helpful and friendlySo I am a Platinum member with the Hyatt and my domestic partner of 15 years decided that we would get married this weekend. So I called the hotel and booked a room with my points. I called and spoke to Sam from the Front Desk and told him of the occasion and he put us in a very nice executive room on the 9th floor. We could not have been happier with the room. It is about the size of 3 normal hotel rooms. The shower was really nice. I could have stayed in there all day. The view from our room was really nice. Our room overlooked the Indiana Repertory Theater. Parking is either valet for like $35 or self parking for $24. That would be my only complaint, as a platinum member I felt that should have been complimentary. So back to Sam, he was so welcoming and very professional and even allowed for us an early check in. I asked if it would be possible for us to exchange vows and be married in their lovely roof top Eagle's Nest Restaurant and he put me in touch with Tasha who allowed for us to do so and that we will never forget. It was a wonderful evening and could not have asked for anything better. Renee was our server up there and she did a wonderful job helping us make a wonderful life long memory. We got back to our room and had a pleasant surprise from the front desk staff. There was a bottle of wine and Chocolate covered Strawberries on our table. That was so thoughtful and unexpected. They definitely went above and beyond what was required for us and was something we will not soon forget. This is such a beautiful hotel and I highly recommend it. It is close to everything. It has a sky bridge where you can walk right over to the nice Circle Centre Mall which has tons of shops, restaurants and theaters. We had lunch at PF Changs today which is inside the Mall. Also after our lovely dinner and wedding we walked 2 blocks over to the Symphony which I highly recommend. Things to do in this area is endless. There are several restaurants in the hotel here as well including a Subway and a pizza/italian place. We are locals here in Indy but if you are coming in from out of town make sure that you book your room at the Hyatt Regency!! You will be glad you did. I would be very cautious about any negative review of this hotel. I am well traveled and am on the road often and I can tell you this is one of the best hotels that I have stayed in.I stayed here this week and had a very pleasant stay. They have completely renovated the hotel rooms and they are very nice. They are still in the midst of some construction at the front entrance which is somewhat annoying, but it truly didn't take away from the experience. The Regency Club was great - amazing view of the capital, friendly staff and great selection of food and drink. If ever I am back in Indy, I will stay here again!I always want to love Hyatt's, but this stay wasn't quite up to par. While the room was clean and I do appreciate the Tazo tea in room, there were a couple of problems. First, the outlets on the desk/credenza were not functioning. Like not connected. I called Guest Services and they had someone from engineering come plug them in, so that was great and they did resolve the issue quickly. Next, the hotel had a large convention hosting meetings (I believe it was the Knights of Columbus) and the elevators were not equipped to handle the additional traffic. I'm a patient person but I waited for the elevator for 10+ minutes on several occasions and then was stuffed into a service car with many other people - in July...in Indianapolis... it was hot and muggy. You get the picture. If there was an option, I would have walked the 7 flights of stairs up to my room. It was that unpleasant. At any rate, a good value and as I mentioned, the room was clean. I may give this place another shot in the future.Staying for a conference. Parking is over the top in price. In general, it appears fairly well kept, but it's the details that make a place. Checking in, the bedding was still all feathers; there was a very nasty deposit of something on the glass of a picture. There was a house keeping staff close by who I asked to clean it, and I was told that it wasn't her room, and I would need to report this to the front desk. I also found nail clippings on the carpet and bedside stand. I informed the front desk in the a.m., but there was no resolution.Our initial room had a super noisy AC unit that clicked and whistled. At first they refused to move us and were pretty rude about it but after continued discussions they eventually moved us to a normal room.Next was the worst part, the valet said to pay him for self park and he would put it to our account. I paid him and we parked the car. When we left there was no record of the payment. The Valet Manager and Front Desk mangers both were defensive, combative and offered no refund. I've stayed at hotels around the world and of course including some Hyatts and I've never run into a problem were the managerial staff was so rude and unwilling to even try and be helpful. On top of that they basically right off the bat accused me of lying about the whole thing. It was nuts!I was not crazy angry or anything when I approached them, it even took me a second to realize that this was not just a discussion but an actual aggressive confrontation. I was just not expecting that the managers to come off so accusatory and combative.Terrible customer service by any standard, we won't ever be back which is no loss to us because Indy has many good hotels right downtown.Have stayed here a number of times over the years. They seem to have remodeled the rooms. Everything was very nice. There's a Starbucks and a Subway in the building, wonderful when you want a snack of a fancy coffee and don't want to go outside. Nice fitness center. The building is now connected to the Arts Garden, which means, if the weather sucks outside, you can walk over to the Circle Centre Mall or the Weber Grill without even going outside.For being one of the ritzier hotels in town, I would expect a little more. For the 3 days I was here, two out of the seven elevators were functioning make me spend a large part of my Indianapolis existence in front a red button staring at a wall. Extra charges for WiFi is a thing of the past - especially if all the budget hotels are giving it for free. No problems with the house-keeping or checking in/out (which I did using their e-kiosk, also signing up for Gold Passport -which you should too if you're staying at Hyatts). Room service was solid, but it should be if you pay $50 for 2 sandwiches, a martini and a bottle of domestic beer. One yelper mentioned the free yoga videos in on demand TV which is very cool, making this Hyatt a 3.5Location, location, location! This Hyatt definitely has it. There are other hotels in the area too, but this one is great! I stayed here for a conference, so I also had the experience of being in the ballroom and several meeting rooms. My first impression was from finding how to check in from driving in. I pulled into the driveway and the valet told me to park in the garage under the building. It was the weirdest layout of any parking garage I've ever seen - like a maze with haphazard spots everywhere. It was a little confusing to navigate, but I got a spot close to the elevators with ease, once I found them! When I checked in, there was a person helping direct people to open front desk employees. The employee who helped me was very nice and honored my request to have a room without an adjoining door - I'm a light sleeper and those doors always make you hear the person next to you! I got a room that was down a hall, away from the elevators and the atrium. When I walked in, the set up was a little different than other Hyatts I've been to but it was nice! Big bed, desk, chair, TV, and decent sized bathroom. Maybe a little smaller than a normal Hyatt but still roomy enough. I was also pleasantly surprised to find a mini fridge in my room. My room was really quiet and I slept so well! I brought my white noise maker because I always sleep with it. I heard some traffic from outside but not much. What do you expect - you want to stay downtown, you are going to hear it. The meeting rooms were nice and the employees kept them clean and well stocked with water, paper and pens (and without trash) in between meetings. The ballroom was nice and the temperature was good there. Some rooms got a little hot or cold but it happens. I love that they had a pizza place, Subway, and Starbucks in the lobby, as well as a bar and restaurant. Very convenient for someone on a tight schedule. They also have a large gift shop with all sorts of stuff - except of course, what I needed! No stamps, and no books or magazines. Bummer on that. The skywalk to Circle Centre Mall was so awesome - it was really quick and easy to go shop or eat there. There are also a huge amount of eateries within close walking distance.I arrived at 4:30pm on Thursday and left at 5:30pm on Saturday. When I left the parking garage, I paid $50 (!!!!!!!!) for the privilege of parking there. Holy crap! That is awful- DO NOT drive here if you can help it! Wifi is also super expensive - I used my smartphone instead of laptop. There are several area businesses that offer it for free though, so go to Steak n' Shake or somewhere else for free wifi.Other than the parking thing, I would highly recommend this Hyatt!
review_content_60: Connected to the Indy Convention Center is a huge plus!I booked my room and they gave me the 20th floor on the top! Gorgeous view!I actually booked a room with two double-beds and they gave me a king-sized so they brought a rollaway for free.Small swimming pool and jacuzzi, but decent sized weight and exercise room.Came with a complimentary buffet breakfast!Very good and helpful service.Everything looked so modern and a nice waterfall in the lobby. The lounge downstairs is great too!Went here for a conference, cant complain. Nice bed, quiet room, good staff. Having an office building in your hotel is a little weird though...nice place, clean, fantastic staff. read the other reviews, they are spot on. I only give 3 stars because for the price I expect Nice and CLEAN.My room was ballin' and overlooked the theatre across the street. Everything was modern, well kept, and overall extremely nice. This is the perfect place to come if you want to pretend to be a pretentious asshole for a day. Or if you actually are one.Friendly staff and excellent location to the convention center and a bunch of restaurants downtown. Starbucks conveniently inside the lobby. The lobby has an artsy fartsy feel and there were a lot more people just hanging around doing the internet cafe thing moreso than other hotels I've stayed at. The 24 hour fitness center is also nicer than the one I have in my own town and overlooks the sidewalk, so there's decent people watching while you're on the treadmill.My only complaints would be in regard to "environmental friendliness" and parking. Although they advertise they're "environmentally friendly" and encourage you to reuse your towels and not have your linens changed, they changed mine daily the entire duration I was there despite the fact that I hung up my towels and did not request linen changes. Also, be prepared to sacrifice your first born in order to pay for parking. $22 a day. Sonofagun.The photo's of this place (I assume posted by the Hyatt) are ridiculous. My room didn't come close to looking as halfway as amazing as their photos depict BUT my view was AMAZINGOnly problem I had was some a-hole security guard at the main entrance harassing me about wether I was actually staying at the hotel. This was even after I showed him my key card. He kept at it though requesting my name and room number...Would I stay here again??? NOPE I fly in this friday and have reservations at the WestinI have really mixed feelings about this place.  First of all, I was traveling in a group for work, so I really did not choose to stay here.  I prefer boutique hotels if I want to spend some $.  We stayed here because they contracted to give us a lower rate as part of a national high school competition.  I am just going to do a pro and con list to keep it clear.  Here goes:PRO*Friendly and helpful staff, including housekeeping*Incredible view from my room!*Convenient location. . .we could walk nearly everywhere*Great restaurants nearby (I will create a list in a day or two)*A/C unit with fan I can run constantly for white noise*Hardly any outside noise due to open/atrium design.  *Valets super helpful with parking issues*Starbucks, Subway, pizza place, fancy place, and bar located in lobby*Quality linens and comfy bed. I slept like a big baby, which rarely happens when away from home*Spacious bathroom*Fridge and safe*Great fitness center!  Four nice treadmills, three bikes, two elipticals, and several weight machines.  Treadmills look out over downtown.  Also an indoor pool and hot tub, but I didn't use those.CON*Room not ready when I checked in at 6 pm??  Walked in and whomever had been there the night before definitely had a party!  They moved me up one floor, which separated me from my group :(*Laminate strip on front of dresser was halfway off and flapping in the breeze, so I ran into it no fewer than four times, hard. *No hot water!!  Shower water never got beyond lukewarm, if that much.  This made me angry.  Yes, it did.  I want a hot shower, especially when I am paying a lot of $ for comfort.*Housekeeping did not refill toilet paper for two days, and it was obvious two of us were in this room.  Finally had to call the desk.  *Housekeeping randomly distributed towels.  One day we had a bath mat and no hand towels.  The next day, vice versa.  One day our bath towels were not replaced, but the next day they were.  ???*Hairdryer did not work.  I called desk.  Took 20 minutes to bring one up.  This really cramped my style when I was on a tight schedule for work.  *Finally, one of my coworkers had to reserve our rooms on his debit card.  His card was to HOLD the rooms.  This is how all school districts do it.  Then, when we check in, we give the hotel a check for the exact amount.  Well, the Hyatt actually charged the card an ungodly amount (4 rooms for six days. . .not cheap) and this resulted in major overdraft charges for my coworker.  Three days in a row, we went to management, as they kept claiming they were reversing the charges, but the reversals never showed up.  Would I choose to stay here again?  No way!  Many of our colleagues stayed at the Marriott down the street and raved about it.  This Hyatt let me down.  The dealbreaker was charging the card and not fixing the problem.Very cold (in terms of ambiance) - room was fair- ridiculous parking fees, not really a green hotel and ridiculous restaurant prices for breakfast.  This hotel is just and only focused to corporate travelers, not those of us that are here in town and happy to be with our family.  Staff is nice and rooms are clean, but it is way to corporate for us.  Will not return.The rooms were comfortable, clean and the place was quiet which surprised me because I was there just yesterday and the whole city is a mad house with Super Bowl 46 just around the corner. The hotel has numerous restaurants, coffee shops and bars.  They also have a very nice, clean exercise facility with pool and hot tub.  The breakfast buffet is excellent and even though it was chaotic, the staff was pretty good considering they had a full house and masses of people to deal with.  The hotel is also centrally located.  Great restaurants and shops all within walking distance.  The hotel lobby is also very, trendy and comfortable.  If you're a people watcher like I am, it's great to grab a beer and hang out in the lobby watching people and/or the numerous big screen TV's.  Some negatives I've read from other Yelper's:  Wi Fi is not free and parking is expensive.  The company I work for pays for the Wi Fi, hotel and we don't have to deal with the parking issue; So based on my experience, I give this place four stars but I certainly can relate to Alison B. and Kristi M's review...maybe three stars would be more appropriate.I travel to this hotel several times a year for business.  It's spacious, clean, contemporary, but it's also a bit drab... kind of like a rainy day.  I always feel like I need light therapy after staying there.  That said, service -- bellmen, front desk, etc. -- is above average and they accommodate meetings very well.  Great location close to Circle Center.My group hosted their annual convention here just recently and we were fully accommodated and very pleased with the overall service.The rooms were great and you can get a microwave upon request, which is basically the only amenity not already in room.My only grievance is that everything is much more expensive as it is a full service hotel especially the parking. If you're going to be at the hotel for more than a night or two (especially for an event) You're most inexpensive option is actually going to be to valet your car for $30 for the whole event.There is a Starbucks conveniently in lobby for the early risers. They open at 6am every day and close at 4pm M-F and noon on S/S, too early!Overall I had really enjoyed my experience!This place was renovated for superbowl and it is great. Very clean hotel & rooms. Contemporary design throughout the place and in the rooms. Room service is great, staff is friendly. Excellect price for the part of town you get to stay in. Finally, they have the softest towels ever and that makes or breaks a hotel..... doesn't it?Location is good, building is nice, rooms are Hyatt quality. HOWEVER, the Internet connection is no where near Hyatt quality!  I stayed here 4 nights, not only they charge 9.95 for one day Internet or 39.99 for 5 days.  But the connection is worse than 16k modem. How could Hyatt failed so miserably in this aspect. I called front desk, they forwarded me to the technical help desk which doesn't help at all.I recently stayed at the Hyatt Regency for a weekend in Indy and to go to the Pacers/Heat playoff game. This hotel is great! It is right downtown in the middle of everything. Only a short walk to most popular destinations. Nothing seemed to be more than 3 blocks away. Staff was very welcoming and accommodating. I had breakfast at the One South Restaurant and though a little pricey, the food was very good. Also, had a few drinks at Level One bar, which is a great place to pregame or have a few more after dinner. I will definitely be making this my place to stay when I visit Indy in the future.Renovation turned out very nicely. My room was spacious and well appointed with convenient rolling desk which can be maneuvered to your liking for working, playing online while watching TV or enjoying room service for breakfast. There was a mini fridge in my room, always worth a half of a star for me as I don't like to eat every meal out when traveling and I appreciate being able to enjoy some yogurt, fruit or cheese plus cold water/ soda whenever I like. What removed a half of a star is that WiFi is NOT free, in fact it is $9.95 for 24 hours, even for Hyatt Club members. Get with the program please! That is an unacceptable surcharge these days. Valet parking is also expensive, close to $30/ day as I recall, but really the best option for the hotel. The valets were willing to help, but didn't always do a great job of ensuring that the ony exit from hotel (which also serves as the driveway for valet) remained clear so you could leave as soon as your car was brought around. Best aspect of hotel is the location: smack in the heart of downtown and close walking distance to everything from a plethora of restaurants to the sports venues and bars and shopping.Overall, a very appealing business travel hotel and I would stay here again if the price was right, but I will need to take in to account all of the surcharges which nudge up the bill quickly.I recently stayed here while attending a conference for work. I really enjoyed my stay. Staff was super helpful, and the amenities were great. It's also very cool that you can walk all the way to Lucas Oil Stadium and not have to take a step outside. It's a bit of a trek, but the fact that I didn't even have to put on my coat and get snowed on was pretty awesome. I'd recommend staying here to anyone visiting Indianapolis.It takes a lot to get me to write a negative review.  Alas, Hyatt Regency Indianapolis has royally failed in so many ways then I feel compelled to write my first negative review.  I will never every stay at this hotel again.  In fact, unless absolutely necessary, I will never every stay at a Hyatt.Here's my story.  I reached the hotel at around 1am (after 8 hours of travel and a long night before -- work emails you know... you gotta get them done).  I show up at the reception and nobody is there.  I pressed the bell hoping that someone would show up.  I pressed the bell again hoping that someone would show up.  I waited.  After five minutes someone emerged from an invisible door.  Ok, no biggie.  Well, the person proceeded to politely welcome me, which was nice, and then promptly told me that the hotel's computer system was down.  It took ten minutes to look up my reservation.  Up to this point, it's all good.  Because the system is down, a security guard escorts me to my room.  We get into the elevator and go to my room.  The room smells like a sewer.  Not good.  We go down all the way and try to find me another room.  We spend ten more minutes looking for rooms and this time we find me a room which doesn't smell like a sewer.After all the song and dance, and the travelling I was very hungry but alas there is no room service.  There is no food in the room either.Also, the receptionist promised me a free breakfast and free wi-fi.  There was no free breakfast the next day.  And yes, there was no wi-fi in my room either.  I switch on the TV, and guess what, the TV wasn't working -- it's showed me the Windows loading screen -- reminded me of the good old Windows 95 days.  I guess scrolling text is also fun to watch.  By the way, I'm writing this by tethering from my phone.I was exhausted and hit the sack empty stomach.  I wake up the next stay and rush to work.  It's a long day with back to back meetings and lots of emails between back to back meetings.Looking forward to catch my breath, I get back into my room and almost trip over the iron table -- the iron table which I took out in the morning was exactly where I had left it in the morning.  I was a little surprised, but no biggie, these things happen.  No Sir, my bed was also not made up properly.  I was rather amused by this and decided to call the operator.  I was going to complain but I figured what's the point.  Let me just set up a wake up call and get on with life.  I have enough emails and enough work as is.About five minutes ago I hit '0' hoping that the operator would pick up so that I could set up a wake up call.  Nobody picked up.  I tried again, nobody picked up.  Everything I have written up this point I wrote while a phone somewhere was ringing waiting for some operator to pick up.  And... the phone just stopped ringing... but not because someone picked up.  I guess the phone gave up, and I'm about to give up as well...on Hyatt.Absolutely terrible hotel.  Never ever will I stay here again.  On a positive note, I must say, the lobby is well designed and I like what they have done with the lights around the elevators.  Sadly, that's not worth much at this stage.I was disappointed with m room after hearing all of the good things about the recent renovations. Our bathroom was dirty, the tub had lots of hair in it. The comforter was turned the wrong way and I realized that when the tag was in my face in the middle of the night. There was no actual cover on the comforter, it was laying between two flat sheets, so it was sliding around the whole time. Our room smelled a somewhat smokey despite the fact that I was under the impression we were in a non-smoking room. The overall value for the money was not great and I think the only "renovating" was replacing the carpets and changing out the paint color. The staff was very nice during our brief interactions. Bottom line: I would expect a cleaner, more impressive hotel for the price point.@HyattConcierge @HyattIndy All shower curtains in this hotel are 6-8" too long so they lay in tub. #Sanitary violation in any city. They don't change shower curtains between guests. Ugh.Nice TV's but all channels are analogue. So you have a bigger TV but 2001 signal. Sure miss the crisp digital channels available elsewhere.Nice hotel, good staff, but stupid things like this need to be challenged by any guest. The maids all know the problem, but the mgnt won't do anything about it.Really had a wonderful stay here.  Really nice venue, close to anything you would want.  The nicest restaurants, shopping, and football all right around the corner.  It was under construction during my stay here, but after being at the Hyatt Place in Raleigh the week before it was honestly refreshing.  Wouldn't hesitate to stay at this location again next time i'm in town on business.One of the nicer hotels in downtown Indianapolis. Beautifully decorated and modern art. Very spacious and uncrowded. The hotel has Starbucks, subway, and sit down dining. Attended a dental convention here and it was quite nice.
review_content_80: I was impressed.  I usually stay at Hilton's or other places, and I can't remember the last time I stayed at a Hyatt.   The bed is super comfortable.  The staff is amazingly kind and attentive.   Not sure if my watch was right...was the bar in Eagle's nest really closing early?  They are supposed to be open until 11.  Maybe my clock was still on CST.   Pool is small, and glad they have a lift for ADA needs.  The gym is modern and the equipment is very nice.  Valet parking is $30.  They should offer other options to those with handicap placards to save on the $30 daily rate.  Overall an excellent experience.I stayed here during gen con and they were just as courteous to us con attendees as you would expect them to be to anyone else.I'm with the rest of you guys on the wifi.  Who charges for that anymore?   Also the TV charged to stream music which was a bit obnoxious.  I did like that the alarm clock was an ipod dock as well, my sister plugged her iphone in and while she was in the room at least we had some tunes.Our beds were twin not queen which was odd so I don't think we'll stay here next year.  I love my husband but that was a squeeze.The keyed entry door for afterhours on the skybridge was really really wonky.  It wouldn't work if you were next to it, it wouldn't work if someone was coming from the otherside at the same time you got within sensor range it really was quite a pain. The hot tub and pool were having problems and wern't as warm as I would of liked plus they close at ten which is wayy to early.  The pool boy was pretty polite when he came to check on it and fix it so it probably wasn't a problem for long.We started off on the wrong foot.  I found out that (a) they charge nearly $10 a day for their wifi hookups to the room and (b) the hotel pool was outta commission.  Double bogus there.But this place slowly redeemed itself.  A corner room with two comfy chairs and a king-sized bed with all the pillows a gal could want was a good start.  Oh, and free yoga on demand on the TVs.  Not gonna lie, I did downward dog my way awake one morning thanks to that little feature.  The gym was very nice.  Four treadmills, two elliptical machines, a few bikes and weight machines and a set of free weights made it a totally acceptable place to work out.  Free towels, headphones and chilled towels for post-workout cool-down were a nice touch as well.  Oh, and if you were really jonesing for a swim, you could head over to a nearby hotel to get your fix.  Unfortunately, I did not get to partake in hotel hot tubbing during my stay.  I did look at the pool set-up while it was under construction and it looked very nice.A bar in the lobby, a restaurant on the first floor (and adjoining mall type of food services a la Subway and Starbucks) made it convenient to get a bite, a drink or whatever.  The Eagles Nest on the 20th Floor was very lovely as well.  I didn't get to eat there, but the server graciously accepted our raucous party and served us expediently.I'd stay here again if ever in the Indy area.  Close to downtown and a whole host of restaurants (there are some non-chains close by, you just have to do a bit of searching), the hotel has a great location for all the sights in downtown Indianapolis, including the fabulous government center, which was my sight to see.  Kidding.  Not about it being my sight to see, but about it being fabulous.  You get it.My little bonus tip to you...if you're flying into Indy and staying downtown (at the Hyatt or wherever), there is a bus service called the green line.  For $7 charge, you can get dropped off right in front of your hotel.  Better than spending $50 for a taxi...just sayin'.The group I was traveling with had to stay an extra night in Indianapolis. The Hyatt lowered prices due to ice storm and deadly cold definitely a way cool thing to do with life threatening conditions. They also had helped us park our handicapped van even with there lot being full. They when out of there way to help our group find handicapped accommodations on last minute request.  We stay at many hotels so giving them above average. We did not like how small the room was and the buffet needed a little more for it to be the price it was.  Nevertheless their staff saved them from a lower rating.  I would stay there again.Website stated that rooms were recently updated - ugh! No!!  They will be updated in July 2011 according to the front desk clerk.  Big Disappointment!  Anyhow, room on the 15th floor was musty and linens were VERY WORN.  Not to mention the dingey carpeting.  Sheets were thread-bare and fuzz-balled!  Ooh!  Went back to front desk and asked for a cleaner, more well-put together room.  Got a room on 20th floor-smelled cleaner, sheets were crisp.  One small problem...toilet smelled badly of urine.  Upon further inspection, I discovered dried urine pooled on the base of the toilet!  Ooh!Mentioned cleanliness issue to clerk upon check out.  He was very apologetic, and offered to add reward points to my account.  I accepted-what else could I do at this point, right??!!  I have been a dedicated Marriott customer in the past.  I think I'll go back to staying with the chain that knows excellent service, while providing great service with super value for the price.
